    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2012-03-22: When I first got my Samsung Galaxy Nexus LTE version I bought an expensive Verizon case at the store. I came home and looked on Amazon and realized I coudl get a better case for cheaper. I ordered this case in clear and purple and a glitter case. I took back my Verizon one immediately and am so happy with my decision. Now, a few months later, I have ordered the pink and black, so I have a case for every mood.This case is awesome. It adds viritually no bulk to your phone, so you still get the sleek, thin feel of it. The side of the case have a grippy texture, making it easy to hold and feels good in your hand. The sides do not come over the front of the case much, but it is raised slightly, so offers some protection if your phone is dropped. It's thin, so it's not the most protective case out there, but I love it for keeping my phone nice and thin, I realize I can't have everything. They come on and off really easy, just takes a few seconds. For the price it's worth getting them in a few colors. Thie pink is cute on this one, looks just like the pictures.

    2014-07-06: I got it about 3 weeks ago and decided I was going to write my review after I had a while to learn it. First things first was my gear 2 was labeled as New, the security tags were off making it an Open Box (not a positive thing for Ideal Xpert), but I ignored that. The UI is pretty simple, was not difficult to pair with my Note 3 and made it easy to get some of the application notifications from my note 3 to the watch (ex: facebook, hangouts, CNN). My major issue is it is NOT waterproof, no matter what they say. I did the research before hand and saw people putting it in a tub of water for about 5 to 10 minutes, saw that there were no issues. So it being 111 degrees in Vegas, I went to the pool. Wore my Gear 2 with me, took a few pictures of my friend's dog splashing in the pool water then the screen turned off. Seeing that the battery had about 30% left anyway, I thought the battery was dead, so I plugged it in the charger. I left it alone to charge until it got to 100%, then turned on my Gear 2. The touch screen was not responding, and the date was stuck at December 31st and was stuck charging somehow. So I called amazon about it and thanks to not buying it from the amazon.com retailer, I could only get a refund not a exchange of the product (which was what I wanted originally, but now waiting for the moto 360) Amazon refused to help me contact the seller for an exchange, and insisted I would get a refund and go with them (adding the 8.1% tax to the cart). The supervisor was rude, not even willing to help, and had I probably contacted someone else on amazon's customer service, they would have been glad to help me.So instead of buying a smartwatch from amazon, I have decided to send it back, and wait until the release of the moto 360, not only is it cheaper, but seeing as Samsung actually failed on this smartwatch makes me not want to get a watch from them. I will stick with my note 3 and my note pro, but as far as a smartwatch, I am going to go with Motorola.

    2014-05-17: First of all I have a smart watch, an early cheaper smaller one but I had a base expectation. Compared to that one and features of others I decided to finally shove my money at this one with all the features it has. At first I had a little buyers remorse...I just bought a 300 dollar watch just cause it added a camera feature that was 2mp! Hmm was that really smart. Well after getting it and downloading the samsung app I was pretty impressed with every feature of the watch, after tweeking some features in the app settings I was blown away by all it could do! Can make phone calls, text, add to schedule/calander, and more with out ever taking your phone out of your pocket! Now the 200 dolor one does that too, so is the camera/ 720 hd video feature worth the extra 100? After using it a ton I will say it was way worth it...it is by far the best 2mp camera I've ever used! My phone has a 2mp front camera and doesn't even come close to the quality the watch does! Even when cropping the quality is still there! Can even take pictures with a voice command! I now have no buyers remorse what so ever and am really impressed with this watch...and look forward to more apps and playing around with it, just feel bad for my phone now...don't have to use it as much anymore lol> POSITIVES<+ S Voice commands+ Voice to text feature+ Can make calls with speaker phone+ Built in microphone and speaker+ Built in heart rate monitor and IR blaster for controlling your TV+ pedometer, sleep tracking, and weather (preloaded)+ calander/schedule add/display+ Voice memo, stop watch, timer, media controler, music player, email, notifications, and exercise apps all pre-loaded! Wow+ water resistant and scratch resistant+ vibrant color screen and great touch response+ Built in memory for music, pictures, and videos+ Many adjustable settings+ Amazing 2mp camera and HD video+ great wrist strap and changeable+ nice looking metal design> NEGATIVES <- battery life (2-3 days if off at night and with medium use)- not the best app store but has all the important ones pre-loadedOverall best smart watch I've used slash owned, for right now and can't wait till they add more apps!

I called them personally and they said they were in back order and their was no telling when they would recieve product.I look up amazon I see the device and sceptical I ordered the item it was a little cheaper with them anyway.     Rating: 3

    2014-04-13: The biggest things I was worried about was the weight and the size. Reading the reviews of the Samsung Gear Manager (which can only be seen within the Samsung App Store) I was worried about it not pairing, but it paired just fine for me on the first try. Very nice screen, seems nice and customizable while still being locked down into only what they've provided (you sure don't have the 1000+ faces like pebble, but what they do give you is nice and functional and customizable. Camera is fairly decent in good light. Notifications so far are working well.It's pretty compact, and for its size it weighs a good amount without feeling heavy. Not a huge fan of the strap, but it can be replaced. As far as size, it's smaller than a larger Casio watch (the kind with a compass built in). A little larger than a Pebble, but also clearly of higher quality. Screen is nice and bright and the interface is simple and easy to get used to. The charging cradle is nice too, it's tiny, very light weight and just snaps onto the back. You plug into it with a standard micro-usb.I got mine at a Sprint store that happened to have them in stock. Overall I'd say if you can afford it, you'll like it. I can't attest to the health/fitness abilities of it, just not really my sort of thing. I was looking for a watch with good notifications and functionality and I think this'll suit my needs.In my opinion, if you're undecided between this and the Neo on the basis of weight alone, go for this one, you won't notice the difference and the camera is nice to have for Evernote, translations, etc...If this watch was two hundred dollars it'd be a no-brainer. For three hundred, it's a bit of a stretch, but there are worse ways to spend your hard-earned money.Update: Unplugged it from the charger this morning. After looking at it quite a lot, 80+ email alerts, using s-voice to send a few texts and a factory reset (on purpose, swapped it to my new G5) it's at 88% battery life about 12 hours later. Which I think is pretty good!

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-22: I received my new Gear 2 last Saturday morning via USPS, three days after ordering from a third party seller. I decided to order from a third party seller earlier in the week due to the fact that Amazon was still "Temporarily out of stock" on this item with no updates in over a week on when they'd get their stock and start shipping to customers. I had originally ordered from Amazon around a week prior and they still hadn't shipped or updated me at all, so I cancelled the order afterwards because I had no information on when Amazon would have the Gear 2 in stock. Being a Prime customer, it was upsetting that I had to "resort" to purchasing from a third party seller since usually shipping times are much longer. I expected better service and more specific communication from Amazon, especially since the demand for this product was so extensive. Luckily though, it seems that I made a lucky choice of third party seller to buy from because they shipped same-day and the product was packed safely and securely and arrived in about 3 days.Something important to note is that some sellers are currently selling the Gear 2 for around $320. People avoid these prices, believing they are overpriced, not realizing that Amazon applies sales tax in most states only for items purchased from Amazon directly, which would have made the total cost rise to around $320 at checkout. In this case, there was pretty much no downside purchasing from a third party seller considering there was no estimate for when Amazon would receive their stock, so I decided to make my move and purchased from a seemingly reliable seller. It's also important to note that customers purchasing from third party sellers are exempt from sales tax if the customer resides outside of the seller's state. So, the Gear 2 was around the same price no matter where I purchased from.Anyways, after having used the Gear 2 for a few days, my thoughts and views are overall positive. Something I found odd was, being in the Computer Science field and having done extensive online research before purchasing, I quickly realized that my views and experience with the Gear 2 hardly matched what negative comments were being spread by the media in news articles, reviews, and opinions and commentaries throughout the past week. The media's stories focused on the belief that the Gear 2 added no benefit and didn't provide any increased functionality due to the fact that it didn't offer anything "special" and didn't provide any extra functionality that couldn't be found on a typical smartphone. Various news articles blatantly state that buying a Gear 2 was a huge waste money.I took these articles like a grain of salt. I saw the arguments mostly as opinions than anything else, I wanted to test it for myself and make up my own mind, and that's exactly what I did.At first use, it was really easy to notice the key benefit of the Gear 2, the fact that it's an incredible time saver. Smartphones are not very when you're on the go, because they aren't generally something you can just glance at without diverting your attention entirely towards it temporarily. If this is at work, smartphone use negatively affects your productivity. If this is while driving, smartphones are unsafe and illegal because they take attention completely off the road.For me, increase in time efficiency is the most important and obvious benefit offered by using the Gear 2. Unlike others, I don't care that the Gear 2 replicates smartphone functionality because of the aforementioned benefit. That doesn't make it any less of a useful device. What makes the Gear 2 useful is the fact that information that would have taken me 20 to 30 seconds to access on my smartphone can be accessed in just a couple seconds on the Gear 2 with a simple tilt of the wrist, swipe and tap. The Gear 2 clearly me saves time and effort, and it's shown me that it's an extremely handy device that has incredible potential.Anyways...enough of me defending the Gear 2, that's not the purpose of reviews.I've gotten in the habit of wearing the Gear 2 almost 24/7. I even keep it on while going to bed since it has so many uses. Just as a series of examples, right before bed, the Gear 2 allows me to: start tracking my sleep time, to set alarms for next morning just by speaking, check my appointments and calendar for tomorrow as well as the weather forecast, and replace the need to track down the TV remote control when I want to watch a late-night show right before bed.Looking back, I can see that the Gear 2 has helped keep me on track, focused, and organized since I started using it. You've got to push yourself to improve though, you can't expect improvement otherwise. However, the Gear 2 seems like a Swiss Army knife in the form of a tech gadget. There are just so many features and so much beneficial functionality included just via the default Samsung apps, and these apps completely fulfilled my expectations and personally justify the expense.Now, for the negative remark of my review, and as to why I took off a star.Although Samsung provides excellent built-in apps, I'm sure there is a huge potential for development of even better, more beneficial apps. The possibilities are endless for user-developed apps. Unfortunately however, the major downside right now is that user-submitted apps are pretty much non-existent in the Gear 2 market. The reason for this is that the Tizen OS, which the Gear 2 runs on, has still been left largely unembraced and unsurpassed by most mobile app devs. This whole situation is upsetting since the lack of apps for the Gear 2 takes away from the device's potential and its ability for users to customize the app to fit their needs most closely. I honestly didn't expect the app store to literally have less than total 15 apps in the entire market, none of which are really any good at all. That's not the quality that I expected from Samsung. It seems like Samsung dropped the ball by not succeeding in stimulating the early adoption of Tizen by developers.Although I feel the lack of apps is a mistake on Samsung's part that could maybe have been avoided by better planning, being knowledgeable about the Tizen situation I'm also sympathetic because it makes sense to me why there are almost no apps developed. The Gear 2 line of devices are essentially Samsung's first mainstream products to make use of their Tizen OS. Not many people have experience with how the OS works yet and people are just starting to become more acquainted with development for Tizen. In time, I don't have much doubt that developers will embrace Tizen, because where there's money to be made, they will come.However, as someone who purchased a Gear 2 so early on, it's unfortunate that people like me need to wait, who knows how long, in order for the atmosphere to improve for Tizen.Although it's not a deal breaker for me, for others who consider the current lack of user-made apps a much greater issue, I can see why they wouldn't be able to justify the expense until they start to see a community thriving around Gear 2 development.Some further negatives that I feel are noteworthy for prospective buyers:- The Gear 2 frame that covers the front face of the watch is aluminum, but the bottom half of the watch is actually a black plastic cover. Based on a description, I had expected that the entire watch exterior would be made of aluminum and I was disappointed when I saw the plastic bottom as it is more easily damaged.- The Gear 2 expects to be firmly and statically strapped to your wrist, otherwise while operating the touchscreen by swiping fingers, you'll make the watch perform loops around your wrist, which starts getting annoying pretty quickly.- The IR sensor's location being in the front-middle is slightly awkward to aim at the TV. It's something about having to tilt my wrist and tap on the screen with the other hand that just feels uncomfortable. It takes getting used to. In Samsung's defense I can't really think of a better place to put it to make it universally compatible with however a person enjoys wearing their watch. Same with the camera.- Flicking left and right can sometimes be noticeably laggy. I expected better performance from the 1.0ghz dual core processor/512MB RAM and didn't expect to see basic swiping animations lag so noticeably. I suppose I'm so used to my smartphone operating seamlessly without any slow-downs or lag, that I was not used to the slower animations on the Gear 2 hardware. Note that although there is noticeable lag, it barely impacts usability in any way at all.As a final note, nothing is ever 100% perfect, and there's always room for improvement.For the current state I'm very satisfied with the progress Samsung has made with its Gear smartwatch line of products. The Gear 2 is well worth the money and I highly recommend it due to its elegant aesthetics, faster hardware, and software which offers useful features with an easy to follow and very functional user interface.I'll continue to update my review if there's anything important to mention in the future that people should know, either positive or negative. Thanks for taking the time to read my thoughts, I welcome any questions or comments based on what I said.

    Rating: 4

    2014-06-05: I love the watch because I don't always want to be tied to my phone. That being said the pedometer is totally off by 1/2 mile over the course of 2 miles. I am 5'10 and had to make myself 5'2 to even come close to being accurate. The heart rate monitor does not work at all if you are walking or running. I found that the only time it works correctly is if I am lying down and not moving.

    Rating: 2

    2014-04-24: I've only received mine on April 23rd, so I will continue to update this review as I spend more time and familiarize myself more with it. Let's get down to the nitty gritty:Pros:* Lovely screen. 320 x 320 resolution on a 1.63 inch display means 277 PPI, the highest resolution on a smartwatch so far. sAMOLED technology means it's very bright with great saturation and contrast.* Very fast and smooth. A dual-core 1GHz Samsung Exynos 3250 processor and 512MB of RAM means you can scroll and run apps without any lag. It has the fastest processor of any smartwatch so far.* Good fit. The face is not too big or clunky, so even with my tiny wrists it goes on and stays on fine. It only weighs 68g(2.4oz), so you will not notice it much. By comparison, the Neo weighs 55g, the original Pebble 38g, the Pebble Steel 56g, and the Sony SmartWatch 2 is a whopping 122.5g. As for the dimensions of the watch face: Sony - 42 x 41 x 9mm, Pebble Steel - 46 x 34 x 10.5mm, Pebble - 52 x 36 x 11.5mm, Gear 2 Neo - 43 x 37 x 9.5mm, Gear 2 - 47 x 37 x 9.5mm.* Good functionality. The main thing is you can use the watch for actual phone calls, not just a reminder to pick up your phone. Meaning there is a speaker and microphone on the watch for you to be Dick Tracy. I was going to buy the Sony Smartwatch 2, but found out it can't make/receive calls.-The watch has a heart rate monitor and pedometer built in, so you can use the S Health app on your phone to record and keep track of your heart rate, or how many steps you've taken that day or segment.-Another functionality that I like is I can control both my TV and cable box in one. I can control the power of both, change the volume of the TV, and change the channel of the cable box. I can also change the source input, and get info on the programming from the cable box. It has an IR blaster, and uses its own WatchON app. Pretty nifty.-There is also an email for you to check and delete your emails(but can't compose or reply), check and send text messages, check notifications from many apps on your phone, check the weather, has the Feedly app for health/fitness people.* 4GB of memory(2.9GB free) means you can store music and media to play. So not only can you stream the music from your phone, but you can also store them directly and play your videos and movies straight from the watch!* Bluetooth 4.0 connectivity to your Samsung phone, and also to your Bluetooth headset. It connected to my Note 3 right away and without any hiccups. And you can still connect and use your Bluetooth headset to make private calls if you don't want to use the watch's speaker.* Gorilla Glass 3 screen means it more scratch-resistant than other smartwatches. But why even risk it, just get a pack of screen protectors for $6.* Interchangeable straps - you can change the strap with any 22mm watch strap in the world. Awesome!* Apps from Banjo, BMW, CNN , Conde Nast, Expedia, eBay, Evernote, Feedly, Garmin, Glympse, GM , iControl, Line, Path, Paypal, Runtastic, Volkswagen, Weather Channel and Under Armour will come to the Gear 2 and Gear 2 Neo. Apps on the original Galaxy Gear will probably be ported over to the new version. Source: Pocket-Lint.com* IP67 dust and water-resistant. Don't take the ratings word for word though. In real-life, this ratings means: 1- you can wear it in the rain. 2- you can wear it while rinsing your hands. 3- You can wear it while exercising and have your sweat all over it. Basically, water can splash on it. But DON'T submerge it in water and expect it to 100%. This rating is about water pressure - it is SUPPOSED to last up to 3 feet in water. But if you submerge it and enough water pressure gets to it, it will malfunction. IT IS NOT WATERPROOF.Cons:* Call quality could be better. It isn't as good as on a phone, because it has to project the sound externally, the same as when you route your phone call to the external speaker. The volume could be louder, so using it outdoors or in a noisy environment is not ideal. It is mainly for when you are at home or in your car.* 2MP camera. Common, really? This is no more than a gimmick. First of all, it is really awkward to position it to take the photos in the first place. You can't hold it like you can a regular camera, or even your phone. You have to do it Dick Tracy style, which is not as cool as it sounds. It's really hard to see what you are shooting and to frame your shot right. And then when you see your photos..the quality is barely passable. Let's just say if you want to take photos, just use your phone. You might think it's really cool that's it's always there and you can just take a photo quicker and better than pulling out your phone. Maybe you're right, for when you see a UFO and you just have to shoot it as quickly as possible. Otherwise, USE YOUR PHONE.* I am a heavy gadget user. Although Samsung says the watch can last up to 6 days, for me constantly checking my notifications, using the WatchON app, fooling around with the watch, from 10am to 2am it went from 100% to 30%. Your battery usage will vary, and when I just use it to check my notifications when they pop up, make an occasional call with the watch itself, use it sometimes for the fitness and music apps, then it really does last about 3 days. I just wish it can really last a week as I know it might be a problem later, especially on my travels. Which brings me up to the next con:* The charger cradle is tiny and proprietary. It attaches to the back of the watch for when you want to charge it, and the included micro-USB charger connects to the cradle. It is a small piece of plastic which I fear will be far too easy to lose.* Finally, it can only connect to your Samsung phones(because of Tizen, and its proprietary connection method). The Pebble and Sony Smart Watch can connect to any Anroid, and the Pebble can connect to the iPhone too.Conclusion:This might be the biggest issue for me with this Galaxy Gear 2 line. So this is what happened: Samsung wanted to have a smartwatch before the end of 2013 to get a leg up on the competition. The success of the Pebble smartwatch told Samsung that it needs to be an innovator, not a follower. The launch date of the Note 3 was the perfect opportunity. However, at that time, the Android Wear platform/coding had not existed yet, so Samsung had to take the regular Android coding - which is NOT made for a smartwatch platform - and make all the changes on their own to fit with the original Galaxy Gear smartwatch. They quickly came to realized that is was a much harder task than they had thought, so what happened with the original Galaxy Gear was a rush job that although had a lot of potential, turn out to be something everyone hated. The most egregious shortcoming was that it would only last up to 3-4 hours, which is totally unacceptable. So in reality, version 2 was what the original Gear was supposed to be had Samsung not overestimated their skills, or had more time to develop the original Gear. But since they realized regular Android would not make a good platform for watches(the battery length issue), they switched to their very own Tizen platform instead, as during this development the Android Wear platform was not yet ready, and Samsung did not want to wait(they will have at least HTC, LG, and Motorola to contend with). Now, the biggest issue with Tizen is that it is an unproven platform, and that it is not Android. Several smartphones were supposed to have already been perfected in the Tizen platform, and so far only one has came out, and was quickly buried. So, there are simply not enough developers out there to progress this platform outside of Samsung. So for all we know, this could be another Nokia Symbian OS situation(Maemo and Meego, anyone?) where this Tizen platform is already obsolescent, and might be obsolete once Android Wear comes out and everyone else jumps on board and leaves Tizen in the dust. So although there is huge potential for this watch, we simply just don't know, and to support $200-300 to a soon-to-be defunct possibility is a lot for many consumers to bear.So should you buy this Galaxy Gear 2 line? I say if you don't already have one, and are itching to have such a cool gadget to complement your phone(like me), then I would recommend the Neo version over this more expensive brother. The ONLY 2 differences are that the Neo lacks the camera, and has a rubber band, instead of a metal one. But the $100 difference is more than enough to justify these 2 omissions. The 8-13MP camera in your phone will take much much better photos, trust me. And although the metal band does look cooler and more luxurious and sophisticated, the money you would save can go towards buying new bands, as they are interchangeable with any 22mm strap out there.Otherwise, if you are on the fence, I would say stifle your itches and urges, and wait for the LG and HTC watches that will be out in about 2 months from now. If I have learned one thing from their phones, LG and HTC will make beautiful and very functional smartwatches.

    Rating: 3

    2014-07-04: Great hardware! Nice watch!

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-11: I just got mine today at Best Buy, I would have got it here but yeah rewards and same day availability. Anyways, this is a great device. You can set any picture as a background, you can change the fonts etc. The whole thing is easy to use and fun. I work as a hotel security agent and this makes reading and responding to messages fast and easy while still looking professional. And its cool to talk to your wrist lol

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-06: It also fails a little too often and drains the battery without any warning. It is not worth $300 at all.

    Rating: 2

    2014-06-06: By far the best Smart watch I have purchased to date allows excellent navigation. Great utility to accompany my cell phone. Can't wait until Tizen OS is fully functional and shows me how much more this device can do. Only drawback would be that for fitness tracking, nutrition intake would be better if they were to collaborate with my fitness pal. They do not yet at this time, therefore I have Barcode scan on fitness pal and have to transfer to S health. Best Smart watch to date can't wait for glitches in programming but also sent Spanish version. Was angry but found out that didn't make a difference other than looking up free instruction book download on Samsung site.

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-17: This has been the best investment I have made in a while. I absolutely love this thing. It has made my life so much easier. From speaking reminders, to taking phone calls with hands full, to texting on the go. Love the step counter, yeah it's not 100% accurate, but it really helps give me an idea. The heart rate is great, yes you have to be still, take it easy and wait, but I have had this happen to me at the doctor's office, or at the machine that measures your blood pressure at the pharmacy. You need to be still to find out your heart rate and blood pressure, it's common sense. It is also really accurate. The camera is great. It takes really good pictures. I was at an event with celebrities that would not allow me to snap pictures with my phone, guess what I did. Yeah, they were far and it wasn't HD quality, but I still was able to have pictures for memories. Love the sleep tracker. The first thing I do when I wake up is see how i slept. It has helped me plan better to get better sleep. I connected it with bluetooth earphones and listen to music without my phone. Love the color and style.My friends are absolutely jealous. Especially the iPhone people, since Apple still has not figured out a smartwatch yet. Apple is on their downhill slope people, they are they next Blackberry. Samsung is just getting started.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-15: This samsung gear 2 is perfect, it has a good design, it looks like pretty good and I recommend it for everybody, it is very usefull

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-21: Got my Gold/brown version loaded a Rolex watchface with watch styler app looks like a several thousand dollar watch many expensive watch faces are available for free Tag Heuer, Dolce& Gabbana, Citezen, and lotsa of customized watch faces as well, you literally could have a different watch face every day for a month.The camera is surprisingly pretty good (had a common problem with first watch blurry focus, amazon replaced great service amazon) The watch is a camera, a speaker phone, a message center (texts,emails, notifications), game player, music payer, voice recorder, fitness tracker, remote control oh yeah schedule tracker, weather reporting and it tells time too.S-voice also allows you to ask some basic general knowledge question like tallest buildings, age of famous people, who is prime minister of UK stuff like that its actually pretty cool having all that info on your wrist. as well as allowing voice control of opening apps responding to calls and or messages, emails.The screen is by far the best one on a smart watch you can place your own pictures as the homescreen backround meening your watch can be as unique as you are.So glad they made it IP67 certified no longer have to worry about washing my hands or taking a shower with my watch on.App store is growing lots of useful stuff showing up on regular basis, calender apps, calculator apps, games like Pacman, Tetris, photo viewer, messenging app with keyboard (fleksy)Samsung is getting better with this newish wearables segment others have some catching up to do.Battery life is good 2-4 days depending on how much you play with watch

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-14: Basically i am an Iphone or windows guy. I hardly owned any android phones.I waited for a smart watch for windows phone but couldn't get any. So i switched to Samsung s5 to own a smart watch. S5 didn't appeal but Gear 2 did. Initially i ordered Gear 2 Neo thinking Camera is the only difference.But quickly realized the metal face makes a difference. Neo 2 is all plastic where Gear 2 is metal on face. So i bought Gear 2.Pros:Light weightclear displayScreen unlocks whenever i lift phone.Always ON pedometer.Apps may be build with awards and encouragement to use it in full potential.Unlocks phone if near to it.notifications.     Rating: 5

    2014-04-11: I like how cool it is and I recommend it. Great tech =D. Samsung keeps impressing us. Life is good with good products.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-18: This is a great smart watch. I tried the Pebble first and sent it back within a week. I just did not work on my SamSung Galaxy Note 3. The Gear 2 is great. It does everything that I want it to. It just works. If you have a SamSung Smart phone this is the smart watch for you. It cost a little more than the Pebble but believe me, it is worth every extra penny you might spend.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-11: I have an AT&T; Gear 2 and have used it for 3 days now; it's coupled to a Note 3.I'd like to preface this long-winded review by stating my negative rating is based on the fact that I bought this device for its health-tracking benefits. I don't find most of the Gear's general smartwatch functionality particularly useful for me as it would for most people. If you don't care about the health tracking benefits, this is a very fine device. 4 or 5 starsThe bad -There are virtually no apps available for the phone. Fitness oriented apps like Strava and Runtasitc were supposed to ship with this device but there are literally no third party apps that come with this watch. The Samsung app store is also devoid of anything useful.The heart rate sensor is utterly useless. I've owned a Mio Alpha wrist-based heart rate monitor for over 8 months and wrote a fairly critical two-star review because it would (about 25% of the time and only under vigorous activity) provide erroneous feedback. Note that the Mio cost $200 for the HRM feature ONLY... because that's all the Mio Alpha does - track your heart rate. So dropping $100 more to have pedometer functionality along with a much more intuitive and feature-filled watch was very attractive to me. Despite the Mio's shortcomings, it's still leaps and bounds more accurate than the Gear. To give you an idea of how inaccurate the Gear is, it's not uncommon for the Gear to report a RESTING heart rate of 170+ which for me would be the absolute max output under the most intensive training. When it's reporting 170 it should really be 55-60 max. When I took it trail running it was all over the place. When my heart rate was actually at 120 it would report 50... or sometimes 180. It's all over the place. The readings were off even if I had the strap on so tight it would be uncomfortable to wear for extended periods. I've done a comparison where I would wear the Mio Alpha on my right wrist and the Gear on my left... the numbers were often within 2-3 beats but every now and then the Gear would shoot into the stratosphere at 160-180 while my Alpha was sitting in the 55-65 range where it should be. The accuracy is so dismal that I'd be inclined to believe that Samsung may recall the units (if hardware related) to save their reputation rather than have all these utterly useless "health monitoring" devices floating around. Hopefully the problem is firmware/software related and an update will fix it. For now the heart rate function is useless to me. My friend tried the watch and also had the same erroneous readings so I'm sure it's not my wrist being "odd" shaped or have blood flow/skin issues. There is always a chance my HR monitor may be defective but I'm leaning towards a firmware or software issue that can hopefully be fixed.The watch does not offer continuous heart rate monitoring. Of course this depends heavily on a properly functioning heart rate monitor which this device does not offer. But for a device you wear all day the Gear should have an option for continuous heart rate monitoring as it will provide much more accurate caloric burn numbers when combined with pedometer data. I would have thought Samsung would have combined the two data points to provide a vastly more accurate daily caloric expenditure. Especially for active individuals that participate in sports or high intensity training. This higher level of accuracy would put their product in its own league when compared to pedometer-only devices like the Fitbit and Nike Fuel band. Hopefully a developer provides something soon. I'd definitely buy it. To get continuous monitoring (not logging) you could technically go into EXERCISE and choose WALKING and just have it on all day (which I have done for the last three days to check the accuracy of the HR monitor) but then you'll have logs of walking sessions when you're clearly not walking all day and night. It's also annoying to have in this exercise mode because even if you choose to have the clock screen show when you lift your arm, it will always default to the exercise program if it's currently running. Finally, the data is useless if not used in conjunction with and compared with pedometer data. Samsung missed a big opportunity here.One thing I was looking forward to was the automatic unlocking feature of the Gear. Basically when you're within a few feet of your phone (and wearing the Gear), the phone will automatically unlock without the need to enter a password. Unfortunately you are forced to use the pattern lock to even use this feature. From a security standpoint, pattern lock doesn't cut it for me. You don't even have the option for pin security - just the extremely low security pattern lock. There should be an option to keep password lock in place and still offer the same proximity unlocking feature. This feature is more for kids, not professionals that rely on a secure device.The watch is a pain to silence if you are a light sleeper and charge your watch bedside. There is a nice shortcut where you can double tap with two fingers any screen (while on) and you can adjust the volume/vibrate and brightness. However, you cannot put your watch on silent with this shortcut. It's either volume 1 or vibrate. No silence with NO vibrate. So either I have to hear the phone beeping or vibrating on my nightstand or I have to go through this exercise - press menu key, swipe to settings, press settings, swipe to sound, press sound, press sound mode, then finally press mute. I have to do that every time I go to sleep. The odd thing is when I wake up I just double tap the screen with two fingers and press the up button to vibrate and I'm set. It just doesn't work the other way around.There is no ambient light sensor. I would have given up that gimmicky IR blaster in favor of an ambient light sensor. When transitioning from bright sunlight to indoors (and vice versa) it would be nice to have it auto dim or auto bright. Also at night it's too bright in darker rooms or when driving. And when you do something as simple as turn your steering wheel when driving, the sensor activates the screen (as if you were lifting it to look at it but really you're just driving). The screen going on and off all night while driving can be annoying even at the lowest brightness setting. There needs to be a feature to quickly turn on and off the wake watch when lifting wrist option.I use a headset (wired) on my phone and I love that I can answer phone calls without pulling my phone from my pocket. But for some strange odd unknown reason when I swipe to answer on the Gear, instead of my phone's headset being activated the speakerphone on the WATCH is activated. I have to press another button on the watch to get it to transfer to my headset. There should obviously be an option to have it answer directly to the phones bluetooth headset OR wired headset by default.And a few nice things about the watch -I never thought notifications on my watch would be something I'd want but it's definitely grown on me. Not having to pull the phone out of my pocket and unlock it to view what's most likely not a text or email that needs immediate attention is a big plus. Notifications however do not work consistently for Gmail and Go SMS. They work most of the time but not all the time. I have no idea why that is. There is a setting that the watch won't notify you if you are currently on your phone using it but when the screen is off and it's in my pocket it still won't notify my watch on occasion. Notification for gmail (when it works) shows the name of sender on the initial notification and when you click on it the entire email can be read. Notification for Go SMS will show the name and text when you click on it but if you receive two or more it will only show that 2 or more messages have been received and there is no way to read them off the watch. Didn't try it with the native messaging or email app as I don't use them. I'm sure it probably has more functionality and may be more reliable in receiving notifications.The watch band seems durable and is fairly comfortable. Not quite as comfortable as the Mio Alpha when on but it's easier to take on and off. The band clasp is simple to use; the watch quickly comes on and off your wrist and no need to readjust once you get the right fit. The fit and finish is nice to me but this is all very subjective.Even with my fairly heavy use the battery was consistently at 45-50% by the time I retired it to the nightstand at about 9 p.m. That's 14 hours of use to a half full battery. Not bad at all and definitely within the 2-3 days of "average" use purported by Samsung. I should note that I have my brightness setting on a "3" all the time and I haven't taken the watch out on a daytime bike ride or run which would require a much brighter screen setting.The vibration module is strong enough that you don't really ever need to use sound notifications on the watch... at least for me. That was a big plus for me because it's very common that I won't feel my phone vibrating away in my pocket when I receive a text or phone call so I'm required to have the ringer and notification volume on all the time. Now I can live in complete silence and not annoy everyone around me yet still receive all my calls, texts and emails.The Gear's speaker is fairly loud and clear... But I can't see myself ever using it.The "find my device" feature is great at finding your phone after forgetting where you left it. It uses your default phone ring tone as the locator sound; as an added bonus it works great in getting out of meetings or mundane conversations with coworkers... a couple sly presses of the watch screen and voila - phone rings and you abruptly say "Sorry that's my wife and I'm late to our anniversary dinner!!".The camera surprisingly takes decent pictures. Haven't tried anything in low light yet but those taken with plenty of light are very acceptable. I'm sure it will come in handy when my phone's battery is too low to take pictures. Unfortunately the artificial shutter sound and beep is so loud (and impossible to turn off) that incognito snapshots are a no go. At least until someone comes out with an app to silence it. It would come in handy at presentations and meetings where taking pics isn't disallowed per se but obnoxious and generally frowned upon. Video quality is also decent but I don't see myself using it often if at all.Oddly the watch doesn't have a calculator. Back in my younger more nerdy days I absolutely loved my old Casio with full functioning calculator. Luckily there are third party options that cost only a buck or so. The one I found is a bit hard to use as the buttons are tiny but it works great when I need to run fast and dirty calcs while I'm working on my note 3. No more switching back and forth from the phone's calculator or pulling out the pen and going through all those steps to get the tiny calc to pull up on the screen.Summary -The Gear 2 with its purported health/mobility/exercise features, particularly having a (reliable) built-in heart rate monitor and a more accurate pedometer than what my phone offers, pushed me into the "buy" category as I'm a pretty hardcore fitness freak. Unfortunately the huge selling point that pushed me to buy the Gear doesn't even function as it should. I'm hoping Samsung comes out with an update so their Fitness app can actually work with the phone/watch. But most importantly, they need to fix the accuracy problem with their HR monitor. For me, the fitness/health tracking aspects (alone) are what made me take the $300 plunge and therefore weighs very heavily on my paltry 2-star rating. If they can get the HR monitor to work at least as good as the Mio's I'd give it 4 stars.

    Rating: 2

    2014-05-30: Honestly I think the watch is ugly but I changed the band with a stainless steel one and it looks a lot better. I like that there are a lot of features but honestly I don't use most. The notifications are by far the most useful to me. I like using a custom watch face to match my mood or attire. Oh, the heart rate monitor is unreliable. I have a Note 3, so pairing wasn't a problem. The build quality is good, but the price is a little steep. A charge will last me a solid two days with moderate use, but I think I may be able to push it for maybe three days. All - in - all I think it's a good watch worth 3 1/2 to 4 stars.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-15: It is a game changer in so many aspects. Connection is super easy, setup can be done in 5 minutes. Easy to see messages and reply with a touch. No more looking at the phone in the car. Not to mention it is smart enough not to send notifications to the watch when you are in the actual app. Great design and not heavy. My wife loves her Gear Neo as well.

    2014-01-03: Have had a lot of problems with chargers not providing a true 2.1 charge and those that do, usually result in a very hot phone!This charger does not suffer from either of those problems.The only issue I have with this charger is that the cord is a tad on the short side ...

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-27: I'm often in the situation where I want to charge my phone or tablet in the car but don't have a cable to connect them to the car charger. This charger includes a coiled cable that is permanently attached - perfect!The build quality is very good. The charger feels substantial, with no rattling or poorly-fitting seams. It also looks quite nice - matte black finish that has more styling and visual interest than the typical power adapter. There's an indicator ring at the end that lights up (blue) to confirm it is working. The blue light is soft and is not horribly distracting at night. However, I would have preferred a single pinpoint indicator light rather than a ring.It fits securely into the power outlet without having to force it in or struggle to take it out. It did not jar loose when going over rough spots in the road.The attached cable is coiled and can stretch quite a distance. In its coiled state it extends about 20 inches; fully stretched out is about double that distance. I had no problems having the cord reach a tablet in the back seat from the center console power plug.The coiled cable cannot be detached from the power adapter, but since it is coiled, it does not get in the way if I leave the adapter plugged into the power outlet. There's also a conventional USB outlet at the end of the power adapter so you can use your own cable, or connect 2 devices at the same time.Zero problems with this, and I absolutely love the design. Highly recommend.[Sample provided for review]

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-13: The Steepower Micro USB Car Power Adapter is one of those perfect on-the-go car chargers for most people. Any device that uses a micro USB cord such as a Smartphone, MP 3 player, Kindle, or a digital camera can readily be charged. I especially like the built-in cable. No need to carry one along with you ... simply take the charger out of the glove box and you're good to go.Another interesting thing is the fact that the micro USB spring cable, a full six feet in length, can uncoil and be used in the backseat of your vehicle. It's one of those plug and play type devices that make life so much easier. It's also very convenient in that you can charge two devices at once. One built in USB cable, the other you'll have to bring along.The basic specs are on the side of the unit. The spring clips nicely secured the Steepower Micro USB Car Power Adapter into my lighter socket. Once inserted into the socket there was about 1 1/2" sticking out. The adapter works well, is very handy, especially when you're on-the-go and your phone or other small device needs a charge.WHAT'S IN THE BOX:► USB Car Charger with a coiled Micro USB Cable► Quick start guideSPECS:♣ Input: 10 - 16V DC♣ Micro connector output: 5VDC, 1A♣ USB port output: 5VDC, 1AFEATURES:► Charges Many Micro USB Devices► Simultaneously charges a second device using the additional USB Port► Works in any vehicle that has a lighter socket or accessory outlet► Compact one piece design with coiled cable► Micro USB coiled cable can expand up to 6 feet► Illuminating blue LED light to indicate that the charger has power (on the interface around the additional USB port)Sample provided for review.

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-01: I was provided a Steepower 12W / 2.1A Dual-Port Car Charger with Built-in Micro USB Coiled Cord for testing and review and was asked only to give my honest review, so this is what I found.What You Should Know Before You Buy:♦ "Dual-Port" for this cable means one built-in Micro USB cable and one normal USB port, not two actual ports.♦ Had no problem charging two phones at once, including an iPhone 5.♦ Had no problem charging an iPad.♦ Each port has a maximum of 1 Amp output.♦ Has a built-in cord with a Micro USB plug, so no extra cable needed for Micro USB devices.Detailed Review:♦ Look - The product came in a hanging display box with product information on the package. Inside the box was the Car Charger and a small instruction manual (which is mostly warranty information). It is a standard looking car charger with a coiled cable with a Micro USB plug and a standard USB port for charging other devices. It has an illuminated blue ring on the front of the charger. It looks good with a nice, solid build.♦ Use and Performance - I went on a road trip this weekend with the family and replaced my usual dual port AmazonBasics car charger with the Steepower for the trip. I used it the entire weekend to charge my iPhone 5 from the USB port and to charge my wife's Micro USB port phone with the included coiled cord. It worked perfectly for both with consistent and fast charging results. I also tried plugging in our iPad 2 and it also charged just fine. The coiled up cable is convenient when you need it and stays out of the way when you don't. Everything worked great.Conclusion:Overall, the Steepower 12W / 2.1A Dual-Port Car Charger performed perfectly during my road trip. It had no problem charging two phones at once and was also able to charge our iPad. The coiled cord made it compact for car use. The performance is great and it is built very well. If you need a Micro USB car charger with an extra USB port for an additional device, this one is worth a look. Highly Recommended!

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-03: Works great. I've had it for around a year and no issues yet.I definitely recommend buying this over some cheap car chargers which last only couple of months

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-18: I have been using this for over a month now and it is great. Fast charging and looks good in my truck. The build quality is just what I was hoping for.

    Rating: 5

    2014-01-31: quality feels really cheap. was replacing an oem charger that stopped charging. I don't think this will last very long due to the feel and build of the charger, but it does work at this moment.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-27: iPhone charges fast anyway but I am pretty sure this helps, regardless it works and I can plug in the mini usb cord too

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-28: Car chargers are one of those gizmos most people have to have today. I've used several good ones, but the Steepower dual-port charger is one of the most innovative ones. It has a fixed cable with a micro-USB plug, plus a USB port for another cable (not included). The fixed cable is coiled, the first coiled cable that I've seen on a car charger, and a very nice touch that keeps the cable short but stretches to allow using a cellphone without first unplugging the cable. Each of the two ports provides up to one ampere, which is adequate to charge cellphones and tablets.I tested the charger with my Kindle Fire HD 7" and my wife's iPhone 4. Both were about 50% charged when we left the house, and both were turned on. After a 45-minute drive, making a couple of calls with the iPhone and playing music from the Kindle Fire, both devices had recharged considerably even while being used.This is a nice charger. It's solidly made and fit snugly but smoothly in the 12V outlet in the dashboard of my car. I was impressed with it enough that it's the power adapter that I'll keep in the car now.A product sample was provided by the manufacturer for review purposes.

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-01: TheSteepower 12W / 2.1A Dual-Port Car Chargeris ideal for the road warriors out there. This charger features one (1) USB charging port and one (1) USB coil cable featuring a Micro-B charger allowing you to charge up to 2 (two) devices simultaneously.This charger appears of great quality and functions as it should. Individually, the coil cable and the separate USB charging port can provide up to 1A of power each. It's important to note the total maximum output is 2.1A. The charger features a dim blue circle indication light to let you know it is functioning properly. I find this light useful and the dull nature of the light helps to keep it from being too bright during nighttime driving.The included and attached USB Micro-B cable is about 22" long and can stretch up to 6' in length. This is perfect for reaching the back seat to keep the kids games and gadgets powered during long car rides. It's also perfect to know you do not need to go looking for a spare cable to use with this charger and that it is always attached and available.Over that last couple days of use, I have found the charger to work great with my Android phone, and have had no issues charging my Asus Nexus 7 at the same time. I have really grown to appreciate the permanently attached charging cable. The spare USB charging port allows me to charge my MP4 Player or GPS at the same time making it really versatile.Overall, I think theSteepower 12W / 2.1A Dual-Port Car Chargeris a great charger, perfect for those who own devices that charge via Micro-B (most Amazon Kindle and Kindle Fire devices, most Android Devices, and so on). The additional USB charging port leaves room to share with passengers or whenever you need to charge two devices at once. This product is priced right and is a really good buy.Disclosure: I received a sample product from the manufacturer for the purposes of providing this review. A review in exchange for the review sample was not promised. The views and opinions expressed in this review are my own, and in no way represent the views or opinions of the manufacturer or vendor.

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-04: I received a review sample from the manufacturer and, frankly, expected another variation on a common car charger. How wrong I was.Specs first: this charger has a fairly wide operating range of 10 to 16 volts DC for input and outputs 5 volts at 1 amp on the aux port and the cable (that is 1000 milliamps per the markings on the body). This easily charges my Samsung Galaxy Note II, which I connect to the cable and my friend's iPhone 4S (or her iPad when she brings it along) via the aux USB port. Each port outputs the 1000 mA, unlike some chargers that will split the output giving each device 500 mA. The micro USB end flawlessly inserts into my phone, which is something my previous charger did not. Indeed, the previous charger's micro USB plug has slightly distorted the phone's power port from poor tolerances.Right out of the box the first thing I looked for was the weak link in every other changer I've owned: the nut that holds the spring loaded tip and fuse assembly in place. On others the nut covers the entire barrel of the portion that plugs into the lighter socket and typically has coarse threads that will inevitably back off. When that happens the fuse, tip and spring will fly in different directions and this has happened more than once. Not so this. That assembly is housed in a separate assembly that is screwed into the body. It's practically impossible to come loose on its own, but still makes it relatively easy to change the fuse if ever you need to do that.The body of the device is solid and hefty. More importantly, it inserts and removes easily from my lighter socket, and the housing on the end for the second USB port is solid. In fact, the port is well designed and made because some ports - even on computers and other devices - require a little fumbling (and sometimes cursing) to insert the cable connector. This one does not exhibit that problem.Finally the cable, probably the most important part of this charger, isheavy-duty. In the past some of my chargers actually picked up my ignition system firing because of cheap cables and the fact that my car has a lot of radio frequency activity from the bluetooth connection to an FM retransmitter. This cable is ultra quiet and does not pick up external signals. If there is one complaint it's the cable is a tad too stiff. I have to exert a little more pull to extend it, but in the overall scheme of things that is a very minor complaint.Bottom line: this charger is a keeper and I am betting that it will long outlast the others that I have used - most of which fall apart of fail in some way after four to six months. This one is truly the Rolls-Royce of chargers.

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-22: Great product. Works as expected. The extra USB connection is really nice to have.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-27: Bought this as a gift for my mom who recently bought an iphone 5s. This charger is perfect for a "divided" household. My mom with the iphone and dad with an android. The extra usb slot allows the android user to use their own usb cord to simultaneously charge their phone from the same plug.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-29: The Steepower 18W / 2A Dual-Port Car Charger with Built-in Lightning coiled cable is a great option if you need to charge a lighting port device and another device. I have used this to charge my iPhone 5 and my iPod touch 5. The lightning cable has a max output of 1 amp while is great for your lightning port device. The USB port can charge your device at 1 amp while is great for any non-tablet device. This car charger gives a max output of 2 amps. The coiled cable is great so the cable does not get knotted. The lightning end is small so it will work with most cases. The lightning cable is Apple Certified/MFi Certified meaning that it will not give any errors when you go to charge your device. This is very important.I highly recommend this car charger.I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, and I promised that my review is fair and honest.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 1

    2013-03-05: I have had problems with this item. I purchased it on January 18, 2013 so I've had it about six weeks.First, the good news:The silicone part fits well. Its purpose seems to be as a cushion for the hard case (which makes sense). If you intend to use the hard case to completely enclose the phone and to holster it onto your belt (or what have you) it will provide adequate protection for you. I've used it for this purpose a time or two and for this reason I gave it two stars.and then the bad news:If you intend to have the case only on the back of the phone so you can use the phone, this item will not provide the protection you need. It is solid, however, the corners of the case do not wrap far enough around the phone to hold it in place. It slides off - not completely - but enough so I don't have confidence it would protect the phone in the event of even a minor fall. Also, if you intend to pull the phone out of the holster quickly enough to answer a call you will be disappointed. It is an extremely tight fit.All in all, I would look elsewhere.

    2013-02-21: The gel case fits my phone well, the plastic cover also fits well. It all fits snugly into the holster with belt clip. I am not sure why you would want to use a kickstand to see the back of the phone.Overall, I believe this is a good item and well worth the money. One note is that with a little persuading, like getting into a car, the holster will release from the belt clip. It will snap right back on but the first time it happened to me, I though I might have broken the holster.I have not done any real drop tests, so I can not speak to the protection factor for the phone. But with the gel case and the hard plastic cover, it is definately better than the phone by itself. Over all this is a great value.

    2011-04-25: This item failed on first use. When I opened it up (I'm an electrical engineer... I had to open it, didn't I?) I found a decent circuit board, average components and the worst soldering job ever. What failed? The wires that were soldered to the back of the steel plug blades were cold soldered and came apart. Plus the blades were held in place with a friction fit which also failed, leaving exposed metal in the socket when the plug came apart. Construction is so bad that I estimate that the electrical integrity is likely just as bad and may actually harm delicate electronics like cell phones. Be careful and avoid this one!!!!

  • B008ER2U3Q

    $B008ER2U3Q

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2012-08-24: Do you ever get tired of buying cases for your iphone 4s just to be disappointed case after case? I bought this case based on the product descriptions, the videos I saw online (company's website and on youtube) and high star ratings from reviewers here on Amazon.com. It seems like a reliable case, smaller than the Otterbox Defender(which I have on my 4S right now), less bulky and it looks cool. I am all for the cool factor (second only to protection and reliability). But much to my disappointment, this product did not meet half of my expectations. Here are the reasons why:1) I expected it to be life proof. It is not. I am a runner and I use my phone apps and music while running. To run with this case, you have to purchase the belt clip (MSRP $29.99), not included with the case. I think for $79.99, it should come with a case, shouldn't it? The Otterbox Defender, while bulky and also expensive, comes with a belt clip. So you probably are saying, "stop being frugal and just buy the belt clip." I was doing just that when I read the reviews for the belt clip. It seems that there are complaints about the clip scratching the case itself, some pin not engaging all the time, etc.I also listen to music on my 4S while driving(connected to a AUX via headphone jack). I find this a little cumbersome with this case because it has that screw cap on the headphone jack & you have to unscrew that cap every time you need to access the headphone jack. Now, why is this a problem? Because you always have to know where you keep the cap. Mind you, it's a small piece, which can easily be lost. You are probably saying, "oh that's your problem and not the case design." Trust me, when you lose that small screw cap, you will be thinking, I wished they designed the case in a way that you don't have to detach anything to access the headphone jack.The charger cover(bottom of the case) is also poorly designed because it gets in the way of the charger cable. I opened it a few times and tried to plug the iphone car charger--it is not as accessible as I wanted it to be. It also looks like it would easily break from the hinge. I am not risking that.If you are a dynamic iphone user like me (meaning you access your phone a lot; be it charging it, using your earphones, etc.), this case will not keep up with you. Don't take my word for it. Try it.2) The buttons are stiff. Try it on your iphone and you will understand what I mean.3) You will later realize after your purchase that this is not worth the $79.99 that you paid for. Again, do not take my word for it; try it.Right now, I am back to my Otterbox Defender case until I find the next best thing. This is my personal experience with the LifeProof case and I understand that not all users are the same. I just want to share with you that this case did not meet my expectations.

    Rating: 2

    2012-12-29: I really like the concept of this case. Finally, I don't have to worry about dropping my phone in the toilet after one too many shots of Crown. I could use my iPhone as an underwater camera while on vacation. I could take a long bubble bath and watch YouTube videos or text message. It's a wonderful concept.So far, I really appreciate the protection. I have showered/bathed multiple times with my iPhone and have come to discover that this case is the real deal in terms of guarding the iPhone from water damage. I have yet to drop my phone in the snow or confront it with an electric shock, but am incredibly pleased thus far.However, the design of the case (obviously fortified for maximum protection) compromises some aspects of the phone. First off, the ports are harder to access with this case. The headphone port requires an extraneous device in order to connect with headphones. Also, several third-party chargers will not fit in the charging port with the case intact.I've also noticed that the speaker quality is disreputed by this case. While talking on the phone, it's a bit harder to hear the person I'm talking to, and I've realized that it's due to this case.Overall, I love the quality of the case itself. I dislike how difficult it causes other aspects of the phone to be.

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-20: My sixteen year old son wanted this for his bday we got it for him and it does what it says! He loves taking pictures in the water. It does muffle the sound on the speakers and on phone calls but he is 16 he text more the calls.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-19: I bought this case for my boyfriend who dropped his iphone all the time! I figured he needed a case that would stand up to being dropped and this one is perfect! Not only does it prtect the phone from scratches and cracks but its also waterproof! how canyou go wrong?! He takes it on the shower with him and listens to music! If your looking for a case to protect your iphone the lifeproof is the way to go!

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-17: ONLY buy this if you MUST have a fully water/dust proof case !!! Its a great product for what it really is and really admire the o-ring design and perfect fit and slim design but this is not for the very large majority of people. I was very patient trying to get use to it but ended up returning it:- Speaker is muffled and at least 25% less sound- Microphone is muffled ... had to keep repeating myself and speaking much louder on phone calls- Speaker phone echoes- Phone reception was a little worse causing dropped calls ... don't really know why but this is definitely a true- I had an Otterbox previously which also has a built in screen protector and easy texting from day one and the Lifeproof was not near as sensitive/produced lots of mis-entered typing- Only OEM charger will fit ... had to buy adapters for all my chargers- Overheats much quicker if leave it in sun in Arizona when outdoors- The door design for charger makes it a little tricky (you get use to it) to insert the charger- No silicone on backside so my phone hit the floor 10x as much as it did in any other case as slides around on all surfaces- Design does not feel well in hands in general- Annoying to have to take out the headphone plug to insert headphone jack- Screen protector seems to get marked up easy- ExpensiveDon't know what I was thinking, if its waterproof there are going to be some major downsides for general use. Really surprised how amny of these have sold and are pushed heavily in the big box stores too ... it should be a niche only product.

    2013-11-15: Probably not the best thing I bought for my cell. Yes it was longer lasting, but my cell wouldn't fit in any of my holders in the car or on my desk. I stopped using it.

    Rating: 3

    2012-07-11: I was a bit skeptical of these so called extended batteries for three reasons. 1) I did not recognize the maker 2) there were some bad reviews 3) I did not know anyone who purchased this product prior to me that I can consult with. The last reason was somewhat cleared, as my brother purchased an extended battery for his Samsung Note. He loves it!Coming from an iPhone 4, knowing the cost of the accessories are usually exuberant, I decided to take the plunge given that the cost was less than $18 for the battery and a new back cover. I purchased it on June 10th 2012. I received it the next day and popped it right in to my phone. From the first moment, I could not be happier. No issues whatsoever. I drained it completely (with ease), per the instructions that came with it, the first day and charged it overnight. I did the same thing the next day. By the third day I noticed that my battery was taking a lot longer to drain. Following the instructions did help and I can tell you that I have trouble draining this battery; I have tried many times and only succeeded four times, including the first two times when I first got it.I consider myself a power-user as I am always on my phone for my emails, personal and work, pictures of my family, YouTube videos (for review of apps or accessories) and Hulu Plus and Netflix at night. I unplug my phone from the charger at 6AM and leave it on all day until 10:30PM when I shut it off and plug it in for the night. Usually it would still have between 4% and 14%.I could not be happier. It has since been my only battery I use and love. I would buy again and will recommend to all my friends who own a Samsung Galaxy S II Epic 4G Touch.As a final note, I did read in one of the reviews for the battery + cover made by Tim (http://www.amazon.com/review/R2CG1LAM5427T8/ref=cm_srch_res_rtr_alt_1) to purchase the Trexcell Black Thermoplastic TPU Cover Case for Sprint Epic Touch 4G Extended Battery, found here (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006X1FZXC/ref=oh_details_o05_s00_i01) Great case and it fits like a glove. It needs a little Mod/Hack to the ports, charge and headphone with a Dremel to make it bigger. Other than that, I love it.I hope this helps you.

    2012-07-25: I bought 2 Trexcell Batteries with covers for the 2 Samsung Android phones we have in the family. (We have The US Cellular Galaxy S2 SCH-R760 which is the same physical phone as the Epic Touch 4G SPH-D710) After following the direction included with the new batteries...and now after a weeks use...I can report that the phones duty-time is amazingly increased with these new batteries compared to the original batteries. I get a full days heavy use from these phones now without recharging all day long. The new covers that came with the batteries are also better than I expected them to be. They are made well and have a silky finish to them. They snap on just like the original covers and all the surfaces match well. I can say I am very pleased with the purchase...so far so good.I had to search the internet to find holsters that would be compatible with the now fatter phone. Not a lot of choices that I could find that allow for the fatter battery cover area. I ended up ordering the Seidio HLSSEPTAS Spring-Clip Holster which I have not received yet. In the mean-time to get me by, I took the old slide-in holsters that I bought with the phones and used a dremel tool and cut out the back of the old holster to allow for the new fatter cover area and surprisingly it seems to work well. I now am not sure I even need the new holsters that I ordered but they have already been shipped. I might do a review of the holsters when I have had chance to try them out.I read some reviews about bad covers being supplied with the batteries but I assume these were an older design...the ones that come now are in my opinion very good. I can't speak to the batteries life span as I have only had them for a week but there is no doubt in my mind that the early returns are good! I will edit this review if I find quality problems down the road.T Johnson East Winthrop Maine.update Dec 4 2012 I am still very happy with the batteries. Working just fine since I bought them about 6 months ago.

    $B005B3RFTU

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2011-12-01: This the best possible accessory you can get for your sensation or any other phone this battery works with. I used to hate my horrible battery life with my sensation even after I rooted it. I mean it did improve by rooting, installing custom roms and kernels. But can you really have enough battery life? You always want more and more. I initially tried the stock htc battery for the evo 3d since I heard it works with the sensation but wasnt much of an improvement from the stock htc senstaion battery. Plus as I noticed htc batteries just get hot way too much and way too easily. With the anker battery it doesnt get hot as much. The cooler it stays the longer the battery life. In addition the anker provides more capacity at 1900mAh. Im getting about 30% improvement in battery life and usage from the stock htc senstaion battery now. Since my phone is rooted and I have ARHD 3.6.5 and the 1.4r1 bricked kernel installed I may get more or less battery life than others. My usage battery life for light usage is about 40 hours and about 16 for medium usage. I can get about 8 hours of continuous talk time. The batteries are a incredibly good deal at 2 batteries and a charger for $29. I am very happy with them so far. Have owned them for about 2 months now. If your trying to decide between the anker and the stock htc evo 3d battery for your senstaion then get the anker its way better by far. Much better value. Im tempted to get more just so I always have a spare. You never know when you will need it.

    2012-04-29: Sensation 4G. These batteries are amazing. My phone used to only last about 3-4 hours on heavy WiFi hotspot, WFi, internet radio, and GPS use. Got ridiculously annoying having to keep it charging all the time. These batteries have saved me. With the same heavy use plus some gaming and talk time, I still get around 8 hours usage. If I dont use my wifi, GPS, and games too much, I can pretty much still go to bed and have about 10% battery life left. I bought two of these with the universal charger whose contacts can be adjusted and I'm pretty much set for two days. I would say that the only drawback is that once the battery life does show around 3%, the phone just dies. I'm thinking this is due to the batteries being from a 3rd party. The awesome battery life is worth it though.

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-04: Don't know if it was the battery or not, but after I started using these batterys, my camera went dead(hardware not software)have better than stock life, and fit the mytouch 4g slide perfect

    Rating: 3

    2012-10-21: Two Scenarios:Scenario 1: You own an iphone. You can't even change the battery. You're forever in search of the nearest plug to charge it up yet again, hoping against hope you'll have enough plug time to keep the battery going until lunch!Scenario 2: You own an Android phone and you can easily remove the battery and replace it with a fresh fully charged one.Scenario 2 with Anker batteries and chargers will radically change your life for the better! I previously owned an HTC Sensation and had two Anker batteries and a charger. It was awesome! The batteries were so much better than the stock battery that I ended up just throwing it out. The Anker batteries would last, depending on use, anywhere form 12 - 40 hours, IF I charged them in the Anker charger. For some reason charging in their charger made the batteries last far longer than charging through the phone.Now, I own the Samsung Galaxy 3 and two Anker batteries. I kept the stock battery and keep all three in rotation. The Galaxy 3 uses a lot more power than the Sensation but I'm getting about 8 hours of heavy use out of the Anker batteries. I only get about 6-7 out of the stock battery.But here's the magic. I start the day with three fully charged batteries. When the first one gets to about 25% - usually around 4:00, I put the second one in and the first one goes back to the charger. It will be charged long before I'll be able to deplete the other two. If I'm going to be out all day I'll take all three with me. But I've never had to use more than two.It's so amazing to know I can use the phone as much as I like, power up all the accessories and background apps, including the GPS - and still never have to worry about finding a plug - until I get home. When I do get home, I have a cradle that charges one battery while it's in the phone, and it charges one additional battery. And I have the Anker USB charger for the third battery. So I can charge all three batteries simultaneous - and still use the phone at the same time.The Anker batteries are 2200mAh compared to the stock battery's 2100mAh. And they last noticeably longer. If you get these two and keep the stock battery you could have your phone on non-stop for 24 hours before having to worry about finding a socket.It's Power Heaven!

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-09: Still working like a champ. Still get good life from the batteries, but now getting ready to retire the phone and the batteries. The bottom of the rubber is falling off on both batteries. I think a little superglue will fix it, but it doesn't seem like its built to hold up physically like the oem. But the charge life is much better then the original battery. I would probably say atleast 1.5-2 hours longer than the original. Also depends on what you use your phone for. I can last a full day before charging at night. Recommend that you charge often with the original Anker charger to keep the cycle counts consistent. Noticed the charge lasts longer that way versus connecting the phone to an AC to micro usb. I think the trickle charge makes the difference.

    Rating: 4

    2012-03-27: Decent batteries, It does increase the battery life for my htc sensation by a couple hours on a normal day with low usage. That could be the difference in finishing the movie or game. I don't really like the charger cause it takes forever and a half (about 4 hrs) to charge a battery. Plus it's sensitive to being plugged in via the microusb, doesn't always work. I really wish atleast one of those annoying prongs was fixed in place. After the second use, I noticed that all the rubber/plastic on the battery between each lead was broken. I've seen friends chargers that are a heck of a lot easier to put the battery in, and they don't damage the batteries, and they charge fast. I give it 4 stars despite the charger because the batteries do extend life, and it's nice to have a couple backups.

    Rating: 4
