    Rating: 5

    2013-08-23: I tested iFlash 4400mAh Power Pack with with Nexus 7 Tab (running ICS 4.3), Galaxy Nexus Phone (running ICS 4.2), Samsung Galaxy 7.7 Tablet (running ICS 4.0.4) and iPad Mini. Overall, this battery pack performed very well based on the test described below.I received this power bank from the manufacturer for an honest review be it positive or negative. Top reviewers are often asked to review new battery packs and one of the benefits of being asked to test different power banks is that it gives me an opportunity to compare them to each other using the same charging test, so I can compare them using "apples to apples" comparison. This set of tests allows me to provide unbiased results as the numbers speak for the performance of each unit.My methodology is to charge each mobile device on each port of the unit for 10 minutes and measuring how much each unit was charge in that 10 minute period. In addition I tested charging two mobile devices at the same time. Each line in the table below represents a separate 10 minute test.I use Battery App by Elvison to determine how each device recognized the charging source. 'AC' status means the charging is at full charging rate. 'USB' status indicates charging at a lower charging rate. 'Discharging' status means that the charging rate is below the power that the device is consuming so it slows down the discharge rate but does not re-charge.➨ General features:======================iFlash 4400mAh external battery weighs 4.1 oz. Its size is 2" x 4" x 7/8". It has nice rounded edges and feels nice in your hand. My husband, who is normally oblivious to such things, said "Oh, it is a cute one!" It comes in both black and white colors, and the manufacturer of this battery send me both. This gave me a chance to test both and compare their performance. Ideally, one wants to see identical performance from both units as it would speak to a good quality control at the factory. And this is exactly what I saw testing these two units with my 4 mobile devices.This external battery has 1 USB output port. The package includes 21" USB to micro USB cable and a carrying pouch. Galaxy tab connector and lightening cable for iPad Mini are not included. The battery pack a small LED flash light built into it. The flash light is not very bright, but I found it handy to use in the car while driving at night without creating too much glare for the driver.➨ Test Results:======================✔ Samsung Galaxy 7.7 tablet (using my own Galaxy tab connector cable)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~White unit: AC ~~~~~~ 2% change in charge in 10 minutesBlack unit: AC ~~~~~~ 2% change in charge in 10 minutes✔ Nexus 7 Tab~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Black unit: AC ~~~~~~ 2% change in charge in 10 minutesWhite unit: AC ~~~~~~ 2% change in charge in 10 minutes✔ Galaxy Nexus Phone~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Black unit: AC ~~~~~~ 6% change in charge in 10 minutesWhite unit: AC ~~~~~~ 6% change in charge in 10 minutes✔ iPad Mini~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Black unit: AC ~~~~~~ 1% change in charge in 10 minutesWhite unit: AC ~~~~~~ 1% change in charge in 10 minutes➨ Key finding:======================✔ This external battery worked very consistently in both units I have tested for all 4 devices I have tested. It did a very nice job charging the phone. It is not the fastest external battery I have tested for charging the tablets, but it has a very convenient size and makes a good travel companion. All factors considered this external battery earned a 5 star rating.Ali Julia review

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-11: I have used (and reviewed) a variety of different external batteries over the last 6 months (actually about 20). The iFlash 4400mAh is a small lightweight external power bank that will fully charge your smartphone and provides a LED light. This external battery pack is small enough to carry around for a smartphone, but still can provide several hours of additional power to a tablet.Notes-- 4400mAh power bank has enough storage capacity to fully charge an iPhone almost 2 times - it will also provide about a 50% charge to an iPad 2 and a 40% charge to an iPad 4- Has one 5V 1A output which has enough power output to charge an iPhone and an iPad- Has an LED light built in - on a full charge the LED light will shine for 200 hours- Comes with one charging cable which connects to a USB port to a mini-USB - for charging the external powerbank from a standard USB 5V power source.- Roughly 2/3 he size of my iPhone- Has an indicator to show how much charge remaining - each light represents an increment of 25% charge- A very sleek look- Comes with a blueish padded nylon caseFinal Verdict - The iFlash 4400mAh external battery is a small lightweight power bank that offers enough power to fully charge an iPhone, Blackberry, or Samsung Galaxy for a relatively low price. There are Power Banks that have have more capacity and additional USB outputs, but the iFlash 4400mAh is a small and sleek alternative to the larger and more expensive powerbanks.4 1/2 StarsPlease Note I received this product in exchange for an unbiased review

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-17: While this power bank is not suitable for large battery devices such as tablets, the 4,400mAh capacity is more than adequate for at least one full charge (or a couple of partial charges) of a smart phone and a couple of full charges for a more basic phone.The build quality is quite nice, especially given the price. It's all plastic, but put together well, with smooth seams throughout. All the edges are rounded making it easy to slip into a pocket. However, while it is narrow (a bit under 2 inches wide) it is rather thick (about 3/4 inch thick). It's about 4 inches long.The USB output port is on the top next to a pretty bright LED flashlight. The input port for charging the powerbank is on the side. All ports are solidly built and well-anchored into the body of the powerbank.It has a "gas gauge" indicator to display the charge level left in the powerbank, and a nicely done round power switch to turn it on for charging and to use the flashlight.It comes with a decent cloth storage bag and a USB cable. It does not include an AC adapter or adapters for phones that don't use a standard micro USB port.I only have one complaint - the glossy case is a fingerprint magnet. Looks nice when it's clean, but it's nearly impossible to keep it looking glossy. It doesn't interfere at all with functionality, but if you're bugged by seeing fingerprint smudges, this is probably not a good choice.But other than the fingerprint issue, it's a nicely done powerbank with ample power for a typical phone. Well worth considering.[sample provided for review]

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-18: I am so dependent on my iPhone that I cringe when I see the battery depleting with no options in the near future to recharge, and that's why I never travel without an external battery. I own several of them with varying amounts of power for exactly this reason. This iFlash 4400mAh carries the least charge, but it is also the least expensive, making it an attractive option for anyone who rarely needs to recharge but who wants the security of having extra power nearby. The construction is solid and smooth. I can't believe I'm saying this about a battery, but . . . I love the way it feels in my hand because of its rounded, glossy case.I can get about 1.5 charges for my iPhone 5 out of this. The amount of charge will increase slightly after you charge and drain it a few times, but the capacity/power transfer is too small for more power-hungry devices such as the iPad. For those kinds of devices, you would be better off with an 8400mAh external battery, although the trade-off is a larger, heavier power source. This iFlash is sized perfectly to stash in a handbag or briefcase.This iFlash battery comes with nothing more than a blue mesh pouch for storage and a USB charging cable. You will have to supply your own device-specific USB cable to charge your device since the package doesn't contain any adapters. If you want to charge the battery via wall outlet, you'll also have to supply your own USB outlet adapter. You may want to get an extra but short smart phone cable to keep in the pouch; otherwise, you may find yourself in need of a charge without the ability to do it. Charging the battery takes a few hours and can be done at home. I do my charging overnight, although it takes much less time than that. But charging my phone takes just a little more time than it would plugged into a wall. My iPhone 5 went from 14% to full charge in about an hour and a half.Because of the price, this external battery would make a great stocking stuffer, particularly for teenagers and college students. This black version (there's a white-and-blue one, too) is a fingerprint magnet; however, the sleek look and feel is more important to me. (Note: I received a sample for review.)-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-05: When I first tried out an iFlash battery pack, I had no idea of its capabilities. I've since tried out several of them and have come to appreciate how well they perform. They are right up there with the best of them and I've discovered that they are quite impressive in the power department. This particular battery pack is more user-friendly, especially if you only want to have a battery pack on hand to power up your iPhone or iPod. This unit also comes inwhite with blue trimif you prefer.There are several ways to charge the iFlash including through your PC, an AC wall charger, or even a car charger. I usually charge this type of battery pack by plugging it into my PC and leaving it overnight. You will of course, have to provide your own USB cables, which usually isn't a problem. This is a minimalist unit for those who don't want all the extras that sometimes come with the battery packs.When I test any battery pack I usually use my iPad to see how well it performs. It's rather informal, but is quite telling. Can this battery pack cut the mustard?iFLASH Performance:Start: 75% (4 LEDs)15 minutes 79% (4 LEDs)30 minutes 83%45 minutes 87% (3 LEDs)60 minutes 90%75 minutes 94% (2 LEDs)90 minutes 97%115 minutes 100%The the performance was really impressive for a 4400mAh battery pack. Mind you, I didn't sit on it watching it every second as it charged, but was quite surprised at how hard to work to try to get my iPad back up to snuff. My iPad was 75% charged, but that last 25% can pull a lot of power from a battery pack. If the 4400mAh iFlash can chug away powering up an iPad, no doubt it will keep your iPhone or iPod in business.This is a small, sleek unit and could easily be carried in a purse, knapsack, or briefcase. The top of the battery pack has the four blue LED indicators. Beneath that on the front side is the small LED flashlight, and one output port. I suspect that LED flashlight would be able to stay on for more than 200 hours continuously given the power of this battery (just a guess). It's small, but would be great in emergency situations. On the right-hand side panel is the micro 5-pin input port. The power switch is conveniently on the top face.WHAT'S IN THE BOX:~ Power Bank 4400mAh~ 70 cm (27.55") Micro USB 5-pin Cable~ Quick start guide~ Blue mesh travel pouch with an iFLASH logo on a red tagSPECS:~ Weight: 4.1 ounces~ Input: Dc5V/1A~ Output: Dc5V/1A~ Output: Charging speed for mobiles: 1000mAh/hours~ Input charging time: 5 - 6 hours~ Recycling time: > 500 times~ Six month limited warrantyPOWER INDICATORS:~ One LED light on: <25%~ Two LED lights on: 25% - 50%~ Three LED lights on: 50% - 75%~ Four LED lights on: 75% - 100%Sample provided for review.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-13: This is my review on the iFlash 4400 external battery pack. The packaging is really nice, it comes in a nice box and is packaged very neatly inside. Included is the power bank itself, a small carrying bag and a standard micro USB cable that can equally be used on the power bank its self to replenish the batter on it. At 4400 mAh this external battery is of decent battery capacity and it is sure to provide enough power to charge most phones today about 2-3 times or more depending on the battery capacity of your phone. I tested this on (3) devices.* Apple iPad 3rd Generation* HTC EVO 3D w/extended battery* Kyocera HydroThe power bank functioned perfectly with all of these devices, although it isn't intended for most tablets due most tablets having a much larger battery capacity than this power bank, but it will provide some extra time on the device. As for the (2) phones that I tested this on It charged them multiple times without any problems at all.Durability seems pretty good, I have tested other power banks, some of them seem fragile; however, this one seems sturdy considering its lighter weight than others. The LED flashlight on this is pretty bright and it's a nice feature that they included in this. It makes the product more versatile and allows it to be used in more situations.Overall I really like the design and capabilities of this power bank, I am sure that you will enjoy it just as much as I did.I ultimately rate this product a perfect 5 stars out of 5 stars!I hope this review has helped you out!I was provided this product for testing & evaluation, my review of this product is completely honest & unbiased, the words stated above are my own.** Note since this has a 4400 mAh battery you might not want to recharge the power bank via a USB cable connected to a computer or a low output charger, I would advise seeking for and using a higher output charger such as one that has an output of 2.1 Amps or greater, this will ensure that the product doesn't take a substantial amount of time being charged. **

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-10: The battery pack is very lightweight and stylish in design. It only weighs 4 ounces. It would fit nicely into a purse, pocket or briefcase. This small size is ideal for charging smart phones and for a student to toss into a backpack to boost their phone during a long day of use. It also comes with a cable and connectors that you need to make it more useful to charge your smart devices. You may need to use your original charging cables for some devices so take them with you if you need them. It has a USB port rated at 5 VDC at 1 Amp. It also contains a built in LED flashlight that makes it useful for travel, looking for your keys in a purse, a seat in a theater or in a dark unfamiliar hotel room at night.It is a good power resource to keep your USB recharged devices operating on those long work or school days or while you are traveling. It is ideal for charging a smart phone and its size makes it easy to carry. This battery uses Lithium Ion battery technology and carries a 4400 mAh capacity. I have included a video of the battery's features and I hope it is helpful to you.Many people like me are power users of their smart phones. If you are constantly using them then you know that they will run out of power sometime during the day or evening. If you are not near an AC wall outlet with your charger or in your car with a charger what can you do? It is especially important to have some way to recharge if you are traveling in a plane, in the middle of a school classroom or on a bus or train.When I test a battery I do an extensive set of tests that fully charges the battery and then I use it to charge devices and make sure that it is fully depleted when my tests are done. I time each test and document the results as the test progresses. I then calculate the mAh of capacity that the battery supplied and I then calculate its charging efficiency. This process takes from 3 hours to, in very large batteries, about a day for testing. I don't take any short cuts or guess and every battery has these tests performed on it and documented. This is to assure that the battery is tested and it performs well. If a battery has performed poorly I then run the tests again to verify the results.This battery pack is also available in a white color and here is the Amazon link:iFlash 4400mAh Backup External Battery Pack Charger with built-in Flashlight for iPhone 5, all iPhone, iPad, iPod models; Android Smartphones: Samsung Galaxy S3 S III I9300, Galaxy S2 S II I9100, Galaxy Nexus, Galaxy Note / HTC Sensation, One X, One S,...]What's in the box?* The iFlash 4400mAh battery pack* The battery pack comes with an instruction manual* The battery does not come with an AC wall charger. Use the Micro USB charging tip for charging the battery. You can use a computer USB 2.0 port to charge the battery pack but it is 4400 mAh and it will take a long time to charge (10 to 12 hours). The manual states to use a 1 Amp USB wall charger and charging will take 5 to 6 hours. I used a 2.1 Amp wall charger.* One charging cable for the battery pack or your smart devices. It is 28 inches long.* A carry bag to put the battery pack into.This is a good product and below I have listed its features and benefits as well as my test data for your review. Please take the time to quickly watch the video and if you have any questions send me a comment and I will try to help you.The iFlash 4400 mAh battery pack Features:* A 4400 mAh capacity specification* The unit is compact in size and weighs in at 4 ounces.* Attractively designed in a black plastic case.* There are 4 LEDs that indicate the battery's charged state and one LED means 0 to 25%, two LEDs means 25 to 50%, three LEDs means 50 to 75% and 4 LEDs means 75 to 100% of charged capacity.* This battery pack is nicely designed and easy to carry and it is ideal for smart phones for a quick charge after a long day at school or work.* There is one USB power output port. The USB port is rated at 5VDC at 1 Amps.* There is an ON button to allow you to check the existing charged battery capacity available. You must also press the on button to start the charging process of your device.* The battery uses Lithium Ion battery technology.* The battery pack can be recharged 500+ times* The battery pack contains a LED flashlight that can stay on for up to 200 hours on a fully charged battery. You double press the on button to turn the flashlight on or off.* Warranty is 12 monthsTest charging an iPad 2 to measure the output capacity:Start iPad 2 at 35% and the battery pack at a full charge* The next morning the iPad 2 was at 88% and the battery pack was deadTest results summary:* Charging an iPad 2 from 35% to 88%* 53% x 6944 = 3680.32 mAh of charge taken from the battery.* 3680.32/4400 = 83.64% efficiency* This is an excellent result.Here are some of the mAh charging requirements for common devices:* iPhone 4 battery 1,420 mAh battery capacity* iPhone 4S battery 1,432 mAh battery capacity* iPad 2 battery 6,944 mAh battery capacity* iPad 3 battery 11,560 mAh battery capacity* Kindle Fire battery 4400 mAh capacity* Kindle Keyboard battery 1750 mAh capacity* iPhone 5 is 3.8 VDC at 5.45 Wh = 1434 mAh battery* iPad 4 battery is 11,486 mAh 3.7 VDC at 42.5 Wh* iPad Mini battery is 4490 mAh at 3.72 VDC 16.7 WhAs you can see the iFlash 4400mAh will not fully charge a totally dead iPad 2, 3 or 4 because it only contains 4400 mAh of capacity. You have to consider the losses in the charging circuits of both the battery pack and the device you are charging. Energy is lost during the voltage conversion, used by the electronics of the battery pack and your device and by the generation of heat.iFlash 4400 mAh battery pack device charging real world experience:* iPhone 4 or 5 approximately 2.59 full charges out of a fully charged battery pack.* iPad 2 approximately 53% of a full charge* iPad 3 or 4 approximately 31.8% of a full charge* iPad Mini approximately 82% of a full charge* Kindle Fire approximately 83.6% of a full charge* A normal estimated usable storage is 70% of capacity or .70 * 4400 mAh = 3080 mAh charging capacity available for your electronic devices.* In my testing I was able to use approximately 3680.32 mAh of capacity or roughly 83.64% of the 4400 mAh capacity. This is an excellent performance for this battery.This is a good product and deserves a 5 Star rating.I received a sample product for evaluation and I promised to provide a fair and honest review.

    2013-02-11: Before I opened the package I did not like this case. When I pulled it out I liked it even less. Right away the glossy plastic seemed cheap.     2011-11-15: I bought this battery replacement kit from BestDealsUSA for my Apple iPhone 3G. The kit arrived with all the tools necessary, although it would have been more helpful if the screwdrivers were magnetic. As for installation directions, I just followed videos posted on YouTube and it took me about 45 minutes to complete (I could have finished earlier but those tiny screws were hard for me to handle).After installing the battery, I re-calibrated the iPhone with the new battery by doing the following:1. Reset the iPhone by pressing and holding the Sleep/Wake button and the Home button for at least 10 seconds until the Apple logo appears (you will not lose any apps or data stored on the iPhone).2. Drained the battery until the iPhone shuts off automatically (by playing music, videos, games, making phone calls, etc).3. Fully charge the iPhone (yes, you may use it while charging).After two days, I can definitely say the new battery is holding up very well on my iPhone. Let's see how it does after a month or so...

    2014-03-18: (Note: This product was given to me in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. This doesn't affect my review in any way.)This is the perfect accessory for an iPhone 5/5s. It's no secret that the iPhone 5 and 5s have three major problems. Well this case deals with 2 of those. Number 1 the iPhone's poor battery life. I'm always hearing my friends complaining about how bad battery life is on their iPhone. Number 2 is the new lightning port. If your cable breaks you can't use that old cable you still have from the older models.This case fixes both of those issues. LifeCharge battery case holds a 2300mAh battery that extends the battery life of your iPhone by just over double the battery. The way it handles the other problem is by simply covering the lighting port. Since it is connected via the lighting port you can charge your phone with a normal Micro USB port on the case itself.When you charge the case, if your phone isn't fully charged it will charge the phone first and then the case will start charging. In my experience the case charges really fast. With this case on you don't have to worry about that lighting cable that you broke. You have yourself an easier way to charge your phone now. Since almost everything now a days uses a micro USB.The case has a built-in light indicator to show you how much battery is left in the tank.4 lights = 100 - 75%3 lights = 74 - 50%2 lights = 49 - 25%1 light = 24 - 1%What's in the box:- iPhone 5/5s case- Micro USB charging cable- InstructionsPRO's:+ Slim Case.+ More then doubles battery life.+ Charges fast.+ No more Lightning cable issues.+ Doesn't add much bulk to the phone.+ Has a light indicator on the back to know how much juice it has left.CON's:- Those of you will extremely small hands might not like the added bulk (even though it barely adds anything).Conclusion:If you have an iPhone 5/5s this is a case that I would recommend 9/10 if not 10/10 times. It's an excellent case for anyone. No real CON's here. If you want to get more out of your phone each day this is the way to go. Hope you guys enjoy & thanks for reading.

    2014-02-23: When I first got this case I charged it up, slipped in my iPhone 5 (that was very easy and, it turns out important), and began using it.Right away, I noticed:- Tap the case power button and it starts charging my phone.- Connect it to a charger with the phone still inside and it charges my phone first and then its battery.- It easily doubled the "battery time" available between charges.- The case was a tad larger than cases without batteries.Shortly I noticed:- I started to fall into old habits and occasionally forget to hook the phone+case to a changer and *still* have times when I would run out of batteries.- The phone+case didn't fit into my car ProClip or any other iPhone cradle I own.How I use the case now:- I charge the case and keep it in my briefcase, separate from my phone. If I notice my phone battery is low and I need to be somewhere I pop it out of whatever case I'm using and slip it into this battery case. Like I said, no effort at all.Only using this case on an "as needed" basis works out very well for me. The two-piece design is what makes it easy for me to install my phone quickly and what sets it apart from other battery/cases I've tried. Being able to easily remove the phone also means I can charge the case and phone at the same time.UPDATE: I've had this for a while now and use it pretty much as described above. I DO NOT use it as my regular case. Instead, I use it when my phone runs low or I know I'll be away from a place to charge up for a while. As I said in the (updated) title, the case will take my iPhone battery from almost empty to 100% while I'm using the phone. Then, the first chance I get I go back to my regular case and charge up the LifeCHARGE. (The case will charge from empty to full long before my phone battery will run down. That way it's ready to go when needed and can, if I choose, keep my phone active 24 x 7.I was sent this case so I could use it and provide an honest review.

    2014-02-25: When the folks at LifeCharge asked me to take a look at this case, I was happy to do so, but I was also slightly guarded. I've heard good things and bad things about case/charger combos.If you glance through my reviews, you'll notice that I'm kind of a geek about chargers. I love having a way to charge my electronics when I'm not near a wall outlet. So right away I was interested in this case.I'll address my major misgiving first: the charge/discharge issue with portable chargers. This isn't usually an issue with larger chargers, but this problem is magnified with smaller chargers. With chargers smaller than about 3,000 mAh, or even with larger chargers that aren't fully charged, you can get to a point where the appliance you're trying to charge (your iPhone, in this case) has more power left in its battery than the charger does, so the charge actually goes in the wrong direction and your phone ends up getting drained until the charge in the phone and the charger reach equilibrium. That's not good. Even though the battery and the phone still have some charge left at that point, the slow reverse drool of power between the two batteries works against you and ends up draining both batteries. I've done the same thing with my Kindle tablet and a larger power bank that wasn't fully charged.Anyway, that's a geeky point, but it's a crucial issue with a small 2,300 mAh charger and an iPhone. LifeCharge's solution is simple and effective. They put a power switch on their case. That may not seem like a big deal, but it's huge. Just use your phone normally until the battery gets down to whatever percentage you're comfortable with (say 10%-20%). Then press the power button on the charger case to begin charging your phone. The charger will quickly charge your phone back up to nearly 100% again. Awesome!My second misgiving was that this would add too much bulk to the phone. I'd seen a couple of guys in the past who had charging cases and they looked awful. This one isn't as bulky as I'd feared though. It adds about a quarter inch to the thickness and a half inch to the length of the phone. It's really not bad. I don't leave mine attached to the phone all the time, but I keep it in my briefcase. If I know I'm going to be working late or stuck in a meeting, I can grab the case and not have to worry about my battery life.The case has two parts: a top and a bottom. The two pieces slide apart and make it very easy to install/remove the case if you don't want to leave it on all the time.It feels kind of funny to charge it with a micro-USB cable (provided). I'm so used to connecting a lightning cable to my phone, but the case uses the more common micro-USB cable. I guess the nice thing about that is if time is short I can actually use two cables to quickly charge my phone and this case separately before I have to run off again.The case also provides decent protection for the phone. It is made of a rubberized hard shell that protects the back and all four corners (but not the face). Everyone is different, but that's just how I like my cases.So I initially had my doubts about this case, but they were all addressed in the product itself and I was really worried over nothing. This is a good case. It's useful to me and does what I need it to do: It gives me about one good charge (plus a little extra) for my iPhone. Well done.I was provided this item for review.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-10: This is the first extended battery case I've ever used with my I-PhoneS. I wasn't really sure what to expect. I've been using the case for two weeks now. Here are some of the pros and cons of this case. Which overall I highly recommend:Pros:1) Easy to slip on and off the phone.2) Comes fully charged so its ready to use.3) Light weight.4) Looks sharp - the gold case gives your phone a classy look.5) Long charge - between the regular charge of my phone and this charge I can use my phone for email; texting; games; videos; streaming movies; etc., all day and into the night without having to recharge!6) Good value for the money!Cons:1) Protection - It's probably good enough for white collar work; but if your using your phone in a harsh environment (construction; dirt; etc) you may want something with more protection.2) It makes the phone longer, heavier, and a little more bulky - however - I don't know how you can get away from this with any extended battery on your phone!That's about it! The pros definitely out weigh the cons! I definitely am impressed with this case and enjoy the extra time it affords me without having to plug in my phone. I no longer have to worry about my phone dying!

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-23: Ever since I bought my first iPhone, I consider a battery case a must-have accessory, and this LifeCharge case fills that need. There seem to be two common designs of a case like this, both two-piece: one that detaches at the top third of the case, and the other that uses a top frame to secure the phone. This LifeCharge case uses the first design. I like this design best over the two because the iPhone can be slid out in a straight line instead of approaching the lightning connector at a slight angle. I don't have to worry about damaging the lightning connection in my phone. The only disadvantage to this design seems to be a slightly longer case by about 1/4".Yes, a battery case will make your iPhone longer, thicker, and heavier. After all, you are attaching an extra battery to the back of your phone. The good news is that batteries are getting lighter and thinner, and so are the cases. I can fit this in my back pocket without a problem, although people who carry their phones in their front pockets will likely find it uncomfortable.I get about 1.5 charges out of this case. I like that it has an on/off switch on the back so that I can preserve the charge for emergencies OR charge my phone throughout the day until the battery charge is depleted. This case charges through the included (or any other) microUSB cable, and plugging it in will charge your phone first and then the battery. All the cut-outs match well and allow accessibility to all the controls, although you'll likely have to use an audio jack extender if you plug in earphones.This is a strong competitor in the battery case marketplace, especially if you like the slide-off top design and don't mind a little extra length. Note: I received a sample for review.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-16: Even though the battery capacity of an iPhone has not increased over the years (and has in fact slightly decreased), thanks to the clever design and many iOS improvements iPhones last much longer today than they did when the first generation of this revolutionary device came out. Nonetheless, I am rarely able to go for more than a day without recharging my phone, even with a very light telephony use. I have several external batteries and power banks that I carry around with me at all times, but they can be annoying to pull out and use, especially if I am constantly on a move. Life Charge is an ideal product to have for iPhone power users, but only if you don’t mind the extra bulkiness that it provides.The LifeCharge Case looks and feels very well designed. It sits comfortably in your hand, although you will certainly notice the extra bulk. All of the iPhone’s ports and controls are easily accessible. The case channels the audio output from iPhone’s own speakers to the small speaker-like openings of its own. The case was easy to use, and iPhone 5/5S slides into it very easily.The 2300 mAh battery capacity is substantially more than iPhone’s own battery, and it’s on par with some high-end Android phones, such as Samsung’s Galaxy line. Use of this LifeCharge Case will more than double the lifespan of your iPhone. Charging itself was very quick and effective.What distinguishes this battery case form some of its competitors is that it’s MFI certified by Apple. This means that you will not have to worry about whether it will stop working with your iPhone if Apple changes its specifications in some future version of iOS ar the phone firmware.One issue that I have with this iPhone case is that it uses the micro USB port for its charging. This is an odd choice of charging input, especially considering that this case is Apple certified. iPhone charging case that doesn’t use the lightning cable is also not a very appealing marketing move. This choice of charging input will mean that you will not be able to sue any of the iPhone specific accessories and stands (like some external speakers for instance) that you might have. Many of them, however, would have been made useless thanks to the thickness of this case anyways.**** Product provided for review purposes. ****

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-06: I was provided a LifeCHARGE ONT-PWR-35171 Battery Case for testing and review and was asked only to give my honest review, so this is what I found.What You Should Know Before You Buy:♦ Nice battery capacity increase for your iPhone without adding too much bulk.♦ Fits an iPhone 5/5S perfectly, but case provides mostly cosmetic protection, not protection from major drops.♦ Great design that allows you to slide in your phone and then slide on the top, no forcing or snapping bumpers around your phone.♦ Passed the "Does it Work" Test with flying colors and MFI certified to work with Apple iPhone 5/5S with Lightning Connectors.♦ Charges with an included Micro USB cable.♦ Has "Sync-Through" capabilities that allows you to sync your iPhone without removing the case.♦ The case covers the headphone jack, so you will have to use the included headphone extension to use regular headphones.Detailed Review:♦ Look - The product came in a nice hanging box with a lift up flap that showed the contents through a clear plastic cover. Inside the box was the battery case, a Micro USB charging cable, a headphone jack extension cable and an instruction manual all wrapped in a form fitting plastic holder. It is a nice looking battery case that doesn't add a lot of bulk to your phone, while giving you a nice battery boost. The case is built more for protecting from light bumps and scrapes, not major drops. The back of the case has a power button to turn on the case battery and four capacity gauge LED's. Overall, it seems to have a nice quality build.♦ Installation - Installing the case was great. It was much easier than most where the top slides off, you then slide in your phone, and then slide the top back on. There are no bumpers to force around your phone and no twisting or snapping to get your phone in the case. It locks together pretty solidly. Much easier and better design than some of the other battery cases I have tested. No problem and the fit was nice and tight.♦ Use and Performance - To activate the battery case, you press and hold a button on the back of the case and the battery turns on. My phone immediately indicated that it was charging and everything started working as expected. The battery did a good job of charging my phone with no problem and the case felt good in my hand. Charging speed was as fast as typical chargers and added 10% in 10 Minutes and 15% in 15 Minutes of charging. Right in-line with your average charging speed. In addition, it did a great job of syncing my iPhone with iTunes right through the included Micro USB charging cable without having to remove my phone from the case. An essential feature that working well. It was a little larger and heavier than I was used to with my typical Incipio Dual PRO Case, but not too much. Overall, it worked very well.Conclusion:Overall, the LifeCHARGE ONT-PWR-35171 Battery Case performed very well. Installation was great with one of the better designs on a battery case that I have tried out. It extended my iPhone's battery significantly while only adding a little bit of bulk. It charged quickly and synced my phone without having to remove the phone from the case. If you are looking for a battery case for your iPhone 5/5S, this one is a great choice. Highly Recommended!

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-08: I have tried several iPhone 5 extended battery cases over the 18 months I have had the phone. Most look like somewhat swollen versions of the phone itself and work fine. However, most rely, as does the phone, in the (proprietary) Apple Lightning connector plug. This case does not. The convenient and readily available mini-USB port allows for this LifeCHARGE case to be 'loaded' pretty much anywhere. The appearance is quite distinctive - I have the Gold one. It does not look like other battery-pack cases but, on the other hand, it is considerable heavier than most of the others. For me, this was a bit of a problem because, when driving, I mount my iPhone with a disk that adheres to a small magnet. The magnet will not support something of this weight.When I am where I am going, however, I find this case to be quite handy. The battery gives me at least one full additional day of use. The indicator LCD bars seem accurate and indicate charge levels at 25, 50, 75 and 100%. Because the case, unlike most others, is quite easy to slip on and off, I simply remove it when driving long distances. The earphone jack issue does not phase me as 1) this is the situation with every battery case I know of, and 2) I rely as often as possible on Bluetooth devices. The Bluetooth functioning of my phone is not effected at all by the case. I do note, however, that like all other battery cases I have tried, this case seems to reduce/impair the strength of WiFi signals and this might be very important to some users.The bottom line is that this LifeCHARGE case is attractive, easy to charge, take on and off and charge. If I could alter one design element, I would reduce the weight a bit. It is a reliable, though somewhat expensive, case for the iPhone user looking for a solid battery case with a distinctive style and reliable functioning.

The battery is very easy to use. I just have to make sure I don't lose them.* Review based on a sample product provided by the vendor.UPDATE: Being a klutz I have dropped this phone on the pavement twice since using this product.     Rating: 5

    2014-02-26: These days there are so many battery-included phone cases from which to choose that sometimes I have to get down to the picky, nitty-gritty details to differentiate one from another, because they all work. And if you compare cases with equal amounts of mAh capacity, they will deliver equal amounts of power for your particular phone and your particular usage patterns.This case with incorporated extra battery power is nicely made. It performs as stated on this product page. You can buy it with confidence; it will perform.What makes it different from the many others that I've reviewed in the past few months? Two things: One of which I like, one which I don't like. Turns out, after giving it a lot of thought, I dislike one feature more than I like another feature: Hence, a four-star rating, rather than a five-star rating. You, on the other hand, might feel that my dislike is no biggie. Anyway, I'll make the point and you decide. I just want to help you decide.As far as size goes, this case is so minimally heavier than the last case I reviewed as to be a non-issue: It weighs a tiny one-tenth of an ounce more than some other battery-included cases I have been experimenting with. Move the phone from one hand to the other and you cannot notice extra weight. Comparing dimensions, this case is a little longer than some, but no thicker. Yes, it is thicker than a regular case, but the battery has to go somewhere. It is definitely a more convenient and lighter-weight and less bulky choice than a separate external battery.This is my nit-pickiness: I do not like the angled edges compared to rounded curves of other cases. It is not bulkier, the "faceted" edges just make it feel bulkier and not ergonomically correct. I just don't like to hold this phone. My complaint has nothing to do with the case's performance, which is great. (I have long, thin fingers; not meaty at all.)This is what I consider a very nice feature, and I've not seen it done this way before: The top third of the case slides off so that you can slide your phone in. It is very secure. Other cases have a removable frame around the whole phone.Another nice feature are all the speaker holes that go across the entire bottom-front of the case. Other cases have limited holes or a cut out for where the phone's speakers are.*I received a sample product from Ontrion.

    Rating: 4

    2014-03-20: Wow. And you don’t hear that from me a lot with electronic accessories. If you are looking for a case that gives you excellent battery life that will literally last you all day plus, then stop here. Even if you are a heavy iPhone user, I think you would be hard pressed to run through your iPhone batter AND this one.If you do then you seriously need to get a life.I had my phone on wireless, while streaming music, the screen on high, Bluetooth on, Netflix from time to time, and I was still only able to get through my entire iPhone battery and 40% of the LifeCharge battery. And I was trying pretty hard.So I just stopped because I was getting tired. If this thing is able to withstand deliberate battery abuse then it will have no problem handling my normal amount of usage.I do, however, have a few gripes. The case itself is slippery. Very. Not good for everyday usage. Because the iPhone fits inside the case to have room for the lightning connector, it adds a bit of length to the iPhone. I didn’t like that at all. The iPhone is a gorgeous device and anything that changes that irks me. To most people it wouldn’t matter, but I’m pretty… picky so it does.This case also doesn’t offer much protection. While I was very happy with the extra battery power, I found myself being way to careful when using my phone while in this case. I come from an Otterbox background and when I have that case on I pretty much don’t worry about my phone. And I’ll be honest, I don’t work in the oilfields or construction or anything burly like that. So my phone won’t be going through anything crazy nor am I that clumsy. Still… I need protection.But I use my phone enough to where I don’t want to have to think twice when I pull it out. I found myself doing that with this case. The experience of having crazy insane battery power was great, the experience of having a case that was slippery and not as protective as I needed was not.So there is a tradeoff here. What do you want more; battery power or protection? This is a very good case for extra power, just not a very good case for extra protection.

    2014-04-20: This battery case for iPhone 5 or 5S has a soft-touch plastic finish that feels nice in the hand and is easy to grip. It is slightly under 5/8 in. thick and has beveled edges.It is dead-simple to install: the top section just slides off, the phone is slid into the case, and then the top section slides back in place. It doesn’t interfere with use of the phone as all the openings are in the right spot. It provides good protection to the back and sides of the phone and has a slight lip to protect the touchscreen, as well. It even has a speaker grille at the base.The battery has a nominal 2,300 mAh capacity to effectively double the length of use of an iPhone. There are four blue LED indicators for remaining capacity in 25% increments. Just press the recessed button on the back of the case to show remaining capacity and to start drawing the reserve power.A USB-to-micro charging cable is included as well as a short 3.5 mm audio jack extender cable and an user guide. With this case, the included charging cable eliminates the need for the sometimes-finicky and usually expensive Lightning cables.A sample was provided for testing and review.

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-12: LifeCHARGE was kind enough to provide a case for review.The case is actually three different benefits. First, it's a sturdy case for the iPhone. Second, it redirects speaker output on the bottom to face toward the user. Third, it essentially re-charges the iPhone when it goes down to a point, providing roughly a day and a half of heavy usage.The case acts the same way as external battery packs, used to charge the iPhone rather than keep it charged. The iPhone will discharge as used, but then receive charge from the case. That means that the charging priority is to the case, rather than the iPhone, if you have them both plugged in together. That's not a negative, but it is important to understand that if the case runs out of charge, and your iPhone runs out of charge, and you plug the case in with the iPhone inside, the iPhone won't charge immediately. The case has to get to a certain level of charge before the iPhone will pick up - which means you may need to begin charging your case before it runs completely out of juice.Another side note is that the charging is not via Lightning cable, but microUSB. If you've had nothing but Apple's iPhone, this will throw you a bit, because unlike Android users, you probably don't have 5-6 microUSB cables laying around. If anything, it should hopefully irritate you to see how inexpensive they are compared to the ripoff that is the Lightning cable.In testing, the case simply wouldn't charge when plugged directly into a computer via USB. This is likely because the USB port doesn't provide enough output to charge; it's more probable that the case is picky about the port type, just like Apple and Motorola do with their products. Some might find this frustrating, because other external chargers can charge via USB just fine, though slower. If you're good with electronics, you might be able to short a USB cable to "trick" the case to charge at full speed. Plugging directly into an outlet using a USB adapter (the one that comes with the iPad works perfectly) took roughly 3 hours to get sufficient capacity back from a completely empty state.Grip was improved using the case over the slim, "slippery" form factor of the iPhone. The only issue is that the power button opening makes pressing the power button more difficult than it should be. Hopefully a revision of the product will address this small issue. Of course, the weight of the phone is increased dramatically due to the weight of the battery, so if you're used to the feather light iPhone, this will either shock you or turn you off. If you're coming from larger Android devices you might find this to be a positive.

    Rating: 4

    2014-03-13: I wanted to use this for a while before reviewing it, and I've had excellent luck with it. The case is made of a good, solid, satin black plastic. Very simple in appearance with good gripping properties. The battery life is exceptional, allowing a full day of heavy use of the phone. Even better is the ability to charge the battery (and then the phone) with a standard USB charger (cable is included). This is a nicely integrated product.

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-26: The Apple 5-series (5S) with which I tested my review sample has less than spectacular battery performance, so I have more than a casual interest in this case. Let me say up front that there is a trade-off, but one I am glad to make: this takes the sleek 5S and adds a little extra size to it. Width wise the increase is nominal as is the weight. It does make it about a half inch taller, so if you love the phone's original size this will detract slightly from the aesthetics.Looks aren't everything, though, because use time is more important to me and I am not always around a charger. The 2300mAh capacity of the integrated battery is almost 1.5 times that of the 5S' internal 1560mAh battery. Even accounting for loss from charging that is still twice the use time of a 5S without this case, which is why I love it.Another feature I love is the way the case protects the phone. While Apple builds their phones to withstand a lot of abuse, this case adds another layer of protection. It is shock resistant, and the way the outer lip is slightly raised gives the screen more protection if you drop the phone in a carpeted office.Others have described how this case works and fit and form, so I am not going to repeat that information. I will say that the final selling point for me is this case earned Apple's MFi (Made for iPhone) certification, which gives me peace of mind. There are too many products on the market that are of shoddy quality or from fly-by-night outfits, so the certification is not only meaningful, but worth a premium price to me. Considering that this case is competitively priced is yet another value point and one of the reasons why I awarded it five stars.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-14: The LifeCharge case is awesome at doing its job: extending battery life. Installation is easy because the case breaks into two sections. Simply break it into top and bottom, slip your phone in the bottom portion, then slip the top on. I’ll address the pros first then move to the cons.First of all, like I said, this case does what it claims: extends the battery life of your iPhone. You can easily plug the case and phone in for charging without separating the two, which is a perk. There is a button, along with 4 lights, on the back bottom right of the case that are used for charging your device and allowing you to see how fast the case is charging itself. After a full charge of the iPhone and case, I can use my phone until it’s almost dead, switch on the charge and bring my battery life up to 100% again with juice still left over. If you are a heavy user of your phone because of business or other things of that nature, this definitely will get you through the day and then some. To switch the phone to charging mode, you actually have to hold down the button on the back of the phone which I really like. This ensures that it won’t be switched on unless you need it. Charging the iPhone and case together takes about an hour or so, which isn’t bad at all. I found the rate at which the case charged my iPhone varied, but it would charge my phone from almost dead to 100% in about 1.5-2 hours, and that was with continued use during charging.I received this case in the gold color which has a glossy finish: I hate it. I have been using the case for about 2-3 weeks and it definitely takes getting used to when you usually have an Otterbox with a mix of rubber/slick. I wish they put some kind of rubber on this case because I feel like it would be really easy to drop. I, personally, am super careful with my phones so that’s not an issue, but for someone who works in construction, or similar jobs, or is just clumsy, this case is not for you. I also understand that the case has to become longer to accommodate the battery but I also don’t like this. It makes the phone even longer and slightly more awkward to hold. I definitely wouldn’t bet on your iPhone staying safe if you dropped it in this case. As stated previously, I’m used to an Otterbox that’s going to protect my phone from the back and front. If I dropped my phone face first in this case, the screen would certainly shatter. This case is primarily for extending battery life, not protecting it from a 10 foot drop, so you choose your battles.All in all, I do like the case. It does what it claims extremely well. However, I don’t feel safe keeping my iPhone in this case and therefore will be switching back to my Otterbox. This is just too slick for my liking. I will definitely keep this in my purse or car in the event of an emergency where I need extra battery power. I have actually bought portable batteries for my iPhone that are at least half the cost and, while they do require cords and the like, they also extend battery life without having to switch out your favorite case. I’d rather do that and keep my phone safe. I was provided with a sample for review purposes.

    Rating: 4

    2014-02-20: First this gives you the ability to basically double your battery life on the iPhone 5 which is a prolific user of power.But this case is much more than an extra battery. You also have a case that just feels right in your hands. Just plug it into a usb charger and all is taken care off. You never need remove the case. All controls are easily reached and with the case on it still syncs just fine to the cloud. No interference.I think this is a high quality case. I have gone through two cycles and it seems to function spot on. You have four blue lights on the back and when you push the little button it clearly indicates how many of the four bars you have left.I have twice gone down to one bar on the LifeCharge. Did not notice any hiccups when my phone switched over to the battery. so it is a smooooooth operator.Just based on this short text time I can find nothing I dislike about this little helper.So if you are tired of looking for power jacks during the day this is the answer. You can go easily a whole day with very heavy usage and still have some spare life left in the charger.Get one and I promise you will be a very happy camper.I received a free sample of this product for writing an honest review. I WILL update this if I have any issues and you should feel free to contact me with questions via my profile email address.

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-27: As usual I received this item free of charge in exchange for a review. Also as usual I will give my scrupulously honest opinions about it.* This is a very solid and very protective case. Between the case and the battery as protection you could probably run over your phone with a truck after putting this on.* The instructions, while not especially necessary, are actually well-written, easy to understand and attractively designed.* The case is a delightfully deep and satiny black color.* Exterior of the case case has a firm non-slip grip* The case charger takes a standard USB plug charger and comes with a data cable. This means you don't have to have the Apple-proprietary charger any longer to charge the phone. That's brilliant all by itself!* The packaging of this device is just immaculate. Easy to unpack and even with magnetic closures on the packaging cover.In summary, a truly professional product from an exterior evaluation standpoint. I leave the technical specs to the other reviewers but as a simple user I'm pretty impressed with this.

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-22: This LifeCHARGE extended battery case is awesome. This is for use with Apple iPhone 5 and 5s. The Polycarbonate case has a satin rubber. 2300 mAh lithium-polymer battery augments the iPhone beautifully. LED indicators make it quiet easy to monitor. This has USB connectivity to recharge.MFI (Made for iPhone) Certification) should give everyone peace of mind as this is an approved case! Sine several apps are resource hogs, the case makes sure iPhone is really on full charge. Absolutely great as it doubles as a protection. Obviously I did not drop the phone in concrete to test, but I can say the design is rugged and definitely looks fine. I really count not find any con with this unit. very well made!I was provided this product in exchange of a fair and honest review.

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-24: I admit that I'm not really the target audience for phone battery cases in that my daily usage is typically low enough that I end the day with power to spare. I do have a separate battery that I carry if I think I'll need it. But I know that's not true for everyone, so battery cases have their fans. The manufacturer sent the ONT-PWR-35171 to me and asked me to review it.The first thing I noticed was how large it was, in all dimensions. It adds a half inch on the bottom, an eighth of an inch on the top and sides and a bit more than a quarter inch in thickness. The back edges and top are beveled, though, somewhat minimizing the bulk. Still, the bottom headphone jack of my iPhone 5S was now deep within a recess that would make it difficult to plug anything in. On the sides and top, the buttons were accessible, but I had difficulty getting my fingers deep enough into the recess to push them. The opening on the back for the camera and flash is fine. The space below the phone has openings for the microphone and speaker - in use these did not interfere with sound quality at all.This case has a top part that pulls off. You do that, slide the phone in, then replace the top. If you have a screen protector that comes close to the edges, the case might dislodge it. Once reassembled the phone is secure and protected on all sides. The case is made of plastic with a matte finish that is attractive but I found slippery in the hand, Initially, it all felt very heavy, but the more I used it the more reasonable it felt. The case itself isn't really all that heavy - it was I think more the significant increase in size that made me think otherwise.I don't particularly understand why so many of the cases made for the iPhone 5 series have MicroUSB charging connectors. It would make more sense to me to have a Lightning socket. A MicroUSB cable is provided. As other reviewers have noted, you can't use this in a dock due to its offset MicroUSB connector (and certainly not with a dock that has a Lightning connector.)The battery charged fine - on the back are four LEDs, two of which flash when charging and the others indicate higher charging levels. A button can turn the battery on and off as desired. With it on, my phone stayed at 100% nearly all day.Functioning as an extended battery, the ONT-PWR-35171 worked just fine. I just wish the sides and top, in particular, were thinner allowing better access to the buttons. The bottom part seems a bit taller than what I see with some other similar products.

    Rating: 4

    2014-06-06: I've had this case for about a week now. I was using a lifeproof prior to this. I live in Hawaii. It's summer. I'm in the water every day and love that I can take my phone with me and take pictures and video with my kids. I was provided this case from the supplier to review and here are my thoughts.This case does add weight and a little bit of bulk to the sleep 5s. I already expected that. Installation is very simple. You just drop the phone in and snap the top piece on. It does come with an adapter for plugging in your headphones. The well is deep with the case on. If you plan on using headphones other than the stock ones, you will need the adapter.What I love:I was able to go almost two days without ever plugging my phone in to charge. That was awesome. I normally run out of juice halfway through my work day. I listen to music, watch videos, surf social media, and play games aside from talk and text throughout the day.Although the case does add a little bulk and weight, it's not drastic. I could still fit my phone into my thirty one every wear crossbody bag easily.The case is a literal spare battery. When you need more juice, you power the case on (small button the back. Hold down for a few seconds). When you're done, power it off. So you're not constantly juicing your phone up unnecessarily.I never had to worry about not having a charger nearby. I always have enough juice remaining until I could get to a charger.The case uses a micro usb charger. So, I no longer need an extra cord on my desk for the phone. I can use the same charger I use for my other electronic devices.This is great for those traveling or commuting who don't have easy access to an outlet on the go.Because there is no "sheath" that covers the lens, pictures come out way cleaner than when trying to take pics with a lifeproof case on it.The bottom of the case acts like an amplifier. So the sound is great!I like that it's easy to take the phone in and out of the case when needed.What I don't like:The case is not water proof and I don't think it protect well if the phone is dropped.It is also a very slippery case. No silicone or grippiness to it (if that's even a word). I was so used to the security of my lifeproof that I felt naked without it the first few days. I still have the fear of dropping and shattering my phone.There is no protection for your screen. This is just a two piece shell that snaps on and off.The depth of the case does make it slightly inconvenient when adjusting volume, muting, or if you need to hit the top button to power off/on. Not a huge deal, but should be noted. Good luck to those with long nails.One thing I do want to note is the charging time. I completely drained the case out this morning. I have had it plugged in for the last 8 hours and it's still not fully charged. Not a huge issue for me since I just keep it plugged in while I'm at work. I just wanted to notate that.When plugged in, it will charge your phone up first and then the case.I have not needed to plug my phone into my computer for any reason. So I don't have any commentary regarding the syncing.Overall this is an awesome case for those who need the extra power. I personally don't really need since I have a charger at home, one at my desk, and a vehicle charger. So, I'm always prepared to charge up when needed.When we go on our trips, I'll be switching over to this case so I have extra power when I need it.I will continue to update my review in the future with updates as I use it.

    Rating: 4

    2014-02-23: If you are looking for a great on phone battery extender, there are plenty of options. I have reviewed a few other extended batteries and have used them all. The LifeCHARGE doesn't bring anything outstanding or innovative to the table, but that's hard to do when these things are pretty close to perfection as it stands.That being said, the LifeCHARGE is a great choice if you need an extended battery. The price is good and the performance is just what you expect. The internal battery is a 2300 mAh battery, a little more than the iPhone itself. This extra bit is actually wasted energy as no battery is 100% efficient. So that extra bit of power ensures you get 100% more phone time than what you have now.In terms of using the battery, slide the case apart, slide your phone in, connecting the Lightning connection into the port. Slide the piece back on and now you have a phone cover and 100% more battery life with the ease of USB charging.When you want to use the battery, you actually have to press a button on the back of the case to begin charging the phone's internal battery. All of these cases are designed like this and I believe this is to extend the life of both your phone battery and the charge case battery by only charging when needed. The 4 bars on the back of the case indicate charge level, and once charging is complete they shut off.A nice feature that some of the original cases I used didn't have is that this is designed so you don't need an extender on a headphone jack. One less thing to carry is one less thing to carry.And the one less thing to carry goes with not having to carry a Lightning charger. Chances are pretty high you have other digital devices in your life that charge with micro USB. This means if you travel you can just take one USB micro charge cable and you can charge your phone, the extended battery and whatever else you need. And of course, that assumes you don't need to charge more than one device at a time, in which case you will be carrying multiple cables anyway...Overall this is a really well designed case that fits on the iPhone 5s perfectly. Highly recommended.I received a free sample from the manufacturer for review purposes.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-21: Most of what I would say has already been said so let me start off with something new. This case actually makes it easier to take Selfies! LOL This may seem like a silly thing...but basically, the extra weight and size actually makes the phone easier to hold and use for me. The extra length at the bottom actually allows me to have a firm hold of the phone and puts my thumb right in position of the shutter button. It actually makes it easy to take selfies now with the forward camera.Pros:1. Makes it easier to take selfies with the forward camera2. Works seamlessly with the iPhone 5S3. Has holes up front so it actually directs the speaker sound toward you instead of just shooting out the bottom of the phone.4. No distortion of sound at all.5. Micro USB makes it so I don't have to rely on the more expensive and delicate iPhone charging cable. The micro-USB cable charges the phone, the battery case, and many of my other accessories as well. This makes it so 1 cable is now all I need for most all my charging needs.6. Excellent extension of battery life. I now have more battery life than I need for a full day of use.7. You push a button on the back of the case to get it to charge the phone - this is great so you can control when it charges.8. There are 4 indicator lights in the back to let you know how much power is left in the case.9. All buttons are readily accessible10. Feels good in the hand - yes, it does end up being bulkier and heavier, but it actually feels good in the hand. It's like I can have a really firm grip on the phone and not have it just flip out.What I don't like:1. It makes the phone bigger and bulkier. Yes...on one hand I like it - on the other hand, sometimes I want a slimmer phone. Luckily, it's super easy to get the phone in and out of the case.2. You need earphones with a straight connector to use with this case. This is pretty standard with all cases and I wish they'd change that. I like using my nicer earphones and they have the standard, larger jack. That will definitely not work with this case as you only have a skinny hole for access.For all the pros, I can only think of these 1.5 cons...pretty good. I would definitely recommend this case if you're looking for a battery extender of any kind. I have the power banks that are separate and it's just clunky to be holding two devices connected to a cable when you run out of power in your phone. This one is so nice because it's all together and it can recharge your phone without being a bother.

    2011-12-07: I'm all for inexpensive things... but I still appreciate quality. Don't trust the picture--these are super thin. They create air bubbles like crazy. Even if you think you've removed every trace of dust from your phone surface, as soon as you put the screen on, the screen will find any spec of dust within a 15 foot radius and create a huge air bubble around it--preferably right in the middle of your screen--that will annoy you daily as you use your phone. You can try to push the air bubbles out to the edge, but these screen protectors don't work that way and your efforts will be futile.These screen protectors are also magnets for fingerprints and the natural oils that our skin produces. They love it. They love to give you a nice, smeary look on your otherwise impeccable iPhone screen.These is a reason why you get three in this pack for such a low price: THE COMPANY IS GIVING THEM AWAY.You know what I do like though? I like that there is a protector for the back of the phone as well. Even when I replace the front one--which I absolutely will because these air bubbles and fingerprints are the bane of my existence--I will probably keep the back one. It has the same issues with the air bubbles and fingerprints, but at least I don't look at the back side nearly as much as I do the front.

    2011-11-27: Once your phone is heated, skin temperature on a hot day/battery heating, screen heating, the protect itself will displace and "slide" off the screen. I have experience it quite a few time during the use of the GPS and leaving it in my pocket while driving. The screen just slide off like 1/4 of the screen and I can use force to push it back but it got dust on it by then.Future buyer might consider paying a bit more to get a more reliable screen protector.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-05: I've installed quite a few screen protectors and I could NOT get these ones to install without bubbles! The glass was clean, but I could not get them to install properly.

    Rating: 1

    2013-09-09: These do a decent job for the money, but don't expect professional results. There is a bit of a rainbow glare in direct sun, but that is usually countered by using the Auto-Brightness feature. I switched from these to an anti-glare b/c fingerprint oils tend to accumulate in the most touched spots.Application is a little tricky. Read through this, but know it will make more sense in the moment.The protector comes in three layers: two peel-off coverings labeled by pull tabs marked '1' and '2' and the third layer in the middle being the protector itself. One tab exposes the side that will be placed onto the phone screen and the other exposes the side that you will touch. The directions indicate to remove the layer that exposes the side to the phone screen, place onto the phone and smooth out, then remove the layer that exposes the "touching" side. If you aren't careful, you can pull the protector off the phone when you try to remove the layer for the "touching" side, thus exposing the screen to dust and more bubbles. Your finished result will most likely be bubbly and unusable.I prefer to remove the layer for the touching side first, clean the phone screen, then remove the phone screen layer, apply quickly, then smooth out bubbles. Inevitably you will get some dust trapped in and have a few bubble spots, but they should be minor. Don't use a credit card or anything abrasive to remove bubbles - you will make marks on the protector. A softer piece of plastic works better (think a key ring card - cvs card, kroger plus, etc).

    Rating: 3

    2012-12-24: was perfect with having the front and back screen protector. very easy to put on and does prevent scratches :)

    Rating: 5

    2012-03-18: Both protectors apply easily. The plastic is smooth, feels good, and doesn't scratch or pick up fingerprints as easily as other cheap protectors I've used. And with both front and back protected, the phone is pretty much guaranteed to always look brand new if taken care of.

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-19: It really helps protect the phones from scratches. Instructions are easy to follow, anyone can put them on. they last a long time.

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-07: I Love the price and love how well they work on my iphones! Def recommended if your interested in front and back covers as I am!

    Rating: 5

    2013-03-22: This item is a good thing to have to protect the screen. It's a little difficult to apply it on your phone without any air bubbles.

    Rating: 4

    2011-07-13: Ok let's be realistic, this stuff isn't the same extreme quality as the $20 stuff that is scratch proof even when using your keys on it... BUT it is still very durable and protects your phone very well. This I know from experience as these screen savers have saved me many deep scratches from dropping my phone on concrete and asphault (i'm a klutz!). Again, you get 3 SETS OF FRONT AND BACK for only $1.20!!! The average life span of these screen protectors under heavy use is about 4-6 months before they have noticeable scuffs and scratches on them which you can see while your iphone is turned off (you can still clearly see the screen when it is on). So for $0.40 cents each set of front and back, you got your phone covered for over a year! And if you're not very good at applying these things on your phone like I wasn't at first, you have 3 TO PRACTICE WITH! I have gotten good at applying these and now can do so without having EVEN A SINGLE air bubble or piece of dust underneath.INSTRUCTIONS:The key is to wipe the phone clean, go to a non-dusty environment, take off the step one screen. Next, hold the protector from the edges (DO NOT GRAB THEM OTHERWISE YOU WILL LEAVE YOUR FINGERPRINT AND SKIN OIL UNDER THE SCREEN PROTECTOR, DUH!).After you line the protector up with the push button and speaker/front camera area, bend the protector (convex shape facing the phone screen) and apply it to the phone from the center first, then release and allow the rest of the protector to make contact with the screen. This process makes sure that no air gets trapped in the center of the protector. Next, use an old credit card or something similar to work the air bubbles at the edge of the protector out from under the protector in an OUTWARD motion from the center of the phone to the edges. And presto, protected phone screens for everyone!

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-27: It works and its cheap. It goes on easilly and stays on with a perfect fit. What else do you want? Im just gonna add these other words because amazon wont let me submit this review with so little to say. But hey. What else is there to say?

    Rating: 2

    2011-12-30: The back protectors are great and do the job well. For the front protectors, the holes are not aligned well and are a bit off. The hole for the home button is too big. You have to align the protector based on the hole for the camera so that it doesn't interfere with your pictures, but by doing so, it makes the screen protector not completely adhere to the glass at the bottom. You'd have to cut the screen protector yourself by a hairline to make it stick flat. These protectors scratch a bit easily as I can see some hairline scratches after having them for a couple months.Overall, they're okay screen protectors being at less than a dollar. Be sure to take your time applying them and use one piece of tape to lift the screen protector and another to remove the dust that gets trapped underneath while you're applying it. You really don't need to use another film if you mess up. It takes me around 20 minutes to get a screen protector on perfectly without bubbles or dust.

But that's not the product's fault.Installing was simple, having done this many times before, but there was not enough "adhesive" or "magic" or whatever it is that holds down the edges, so there is a cosmetic problem right off. Again, that might be due to the curvature cause during the shipping damage. I know that the interior bubbles may vanish after several weeks, but the edges simply won't stay down. The product is cut exactly to fit, so you must take time to adjust the fit, but that is a plus as it doesn't leave unprotected glass around the perimeter.As this is my first iPhone, and part of my reason for getting one is the fit and finish of the Apple product [Don't start... I use Android's too!], I am not happy with these screen protectors, at all.Thanks again for playing. Good luck.
