    Rating: 5

    2013-11-04: Test devices:HTC OneHTC EVO LTE 4GSamsung Nexus 4G LTESamsung Galaxy S2Samsung Galaxy S3Google Nexus 7Acer Aspire V5Ok, I'll admit it, prior to be contacted, I'd never heard of VOXOA, and I'd never think about dropping a bill and a half on a set of headphones. The VOXOA isn't my first set of wireless headphones, but it could be my last. Well, until I end up breaking these I suppose. VOXOA claims they are specialists in wireless audio headphones, and from their website, this seems to be their first product to market. So, let's see how they did.Compared to my two most recent headphone sets,CyberBlue BSH10andSatechi BT Lite, the VOXOA is certainly a step above in just about every respect. It comes packaged like a premium device, complete with travel pouch, instruction set, charging cable, and aux audio input cable. Wearing them is quite comfortable, even after hours and hours, which is something I usually can't handle. A bit of adjusting was needed for them to fit just right and not feel like they would fall off if I shook my head. The padded adjustable band also folds, for tucking the unit into its pouch for travel. During the initial charging, I had to refer back to the instructions as I couldn't find an indicator for the charging. The indicator light is so unobtrusive, small, and tucked in, that it's easy to miss. A few hours later and it was ready to go. Pairing up via NFC was as easy as pie, though I could wish for the headset turning itself on when the NFC pairing is done, but that is probably beyond what can be done with NFC. And for you iPhone or otherwise non-NFC users, pairing manually was as straightforward as you could ask for.I thought the sound quality to be excellent, as well as the level of volume that can be achieved. In what reminds me of listening to a record, the sound is full, no matter the volume. At max volume, as across several different music genres (my usual metal, electronic/industrial, dance, hip hop, and a minor bit of classical), I was unable to detect any distortion coming through the line. The bass thumps the skin of the ear nicely. The headset might not be noise canceling, but it didn't take much volume to drown out everything around me while at work and home. Every possible control is built into the right earpiece, but set up so that they are easy to operate without looking. Volume up/down on one edge, and the other with forward, play/pause, and back. The button action is soft, but with a sure "click" feeling to let you know you did indeed press them. Across each device and the apps I used for testing (Pandora, Google Music, Amazon MP3, and BeyondPod), the buttons worked correctly for each function, but with something almost like a hesitation. Press, pause, action. That pause was something I didn't see in either of the two previously names units, and was long enough to make me wonder if I'd hit the button I'd wanted or not. A little annoying, but livable. Total run time on one charge was in the range of 15-16 hours of continuous music playback at 3/4 output volume.Something not (currently) mentioned in the ad here on Amazon or on the VOXOA website is that that headset does have an auto-off feature, which activates at around 5 minutes. The unit doesn't make a peep if it gets disconnected from your device, but does give a tone upon connection. Testing disconnect/reconnect, I found that headphones to have no problem reconnecting repeatedly, nor switching back and forth between devices. I'm unsure how many total devices can be paired with the VOXOA at a time and the information was not available on the VOXOA website, but only one device at a time can be connected. *EDIT: 8 devices can be paired, according to VOXOA.* On the volume controls, note that they control the volume for the headphones, not your device's bluetooth media volume. Low volume from your device to the headphones will result in low maximum volume from the headphones.The VOXOA has another neat little feature, which is that you can use it as a wired headset, should you want to save battery or the battery is already flatlined. The sound quality in this mode is still very good. The biggest change in this mode, besides the wire of course, is that none of the controls work. As soon as the wired connection is detected, the headphones switch off battery power, and all control must be done from your device directly. If you have the volume cranked up, prepare to have your ears assaulted.The one feature I haven't tried yet is using the built-in mic and phone functions. That's coming in the next update to this review, as are the answers to some questions I had on the unit that aren't covered in the manual or online.*Disclosure: I was contacted by VOXAO and given a sample of this product specifically for the purpose of reviewing it.*

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-07: Watch out Dr. Dre, the VOXOA headphones are out to get you. Well, they are better than Dr. Dre's headphones, they sound good with most music, not just hip hop and dubstep; and they have subtle good looks.The first song I played happened to be fairly bass heavy, they sounded good, gave my head a good thumping in a clear clean way. That first impression made me think of Dr. Dre or Beats immediately, only better. I then decided to move on to a lot of other music, probably the widest end of the spectrum from dubstep would be classic Delta Blues - a singer, guitar through an overdriven amp, and the occasional harmonica. Oddly, the headphones sounded really good with that cleaner, sparse music. It seemed that no matter what I threw at these, they seemed to act like a chameleon and sound good. They cut across most music genres (I don't think they would do well with opera or classical music).These are comfortable headphones, they are super lightweight and the padding is in all the right places. I have a big head and they fit around my glasses and do not press hard against my head. The construction is super top notch - the buttons feel solid, the whole thing is creak free (unlike the much more expensive Sony MDR-1RBT). I like the flat panels on these headphones; it makes it easy to find the buttons to control volume and tracks. Pressing the buttons or touching them doesn't set up vibrations or make noise, the exterior feels expensive and of a high quality. The headphones fold at the adjustment point (where you make the headphones larger or smaller) to make them slightly more compact.These are on ear headphones, meaning they sit on top of your ears. The padding is soft and the ear cup cover doesn't get hot after wearing them for a long time. Honestly, these headphones look really nice; they have subtle black tie good looks. There is a tight, well manufactured float for each ear cup, they gimbal slightly back and forth, and up and down.These have aptX built in for the Bluetooth. AptX elevates Bluetooth to near wired sound; it is an added expense that makes a big difference. Bluetooth pairing was as easy as any other Bluetooth device. Holding down the large rectangular button on the back side of the ear cup activates pairing mode. The flashing LED is gratefully located on the bottom of the ear cup, making it virtually invisible. These headphones pair in a secure mode, a four digit code pops up to finish the pairing on the device.On iDevices, there is a tiny battery icon that appears next to the Bluetooth symbol. That symbol shows the charge level of the headphones. I love this function; I've never seen it before and think it is outstanding.Bluetooth range is not great - I could really only get about 10 feet before the headphones started to break up. I couldn't get the theoretical 30 feet pairing distance. Personally, I carry my phone with me or it is nearby so that distance isn't a big deal.Controls worked seamlessly with my iPhone 4S. On the front of the right ear cup there are two buttons for volume. On the rear there are three buttons for play and track control. This is a simple and efficient arrangement, no need for more than that.The box contains the headphones, a nice crushed velvet carrying pouch, a microUSB cable for charging, and a 3.5mm cable to physically plug the headphones into a device. The jack is located at the bottom of the right ear cup.There aren't a lot of really great sounding Bluetooth headphones in this price range. I think these hold their own against the next level up, the $200-300 range. They aren't as precise or as open as the Bowers & Wilkins P5 or the Sony MDR-1RBT. They are tuned more toward warm low end, but maintain clean well maintained highs. These are comfortable, easy to listen to, lightweight, reasonably priced headphones.I was provided a review sample.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-09: I just received my set of VOXOA headphones and *wow* I am thoroughly impressed. The sound is absolutely incredible, but let me start at the beginning:The unboxing: The VOXIA people have taken note from Apple and all the other premium brands and created simple, yet elegant packaging that perfectly follows the aesthetic of their product.The looks: These headphones are refreshingly inconspicuous. Lately it seems like headphones have to look like pair of Nikes with big logos and bright colors. These are black, beautifully matte, and don’t feature any huge logos at all. In fact, I had to look hard to see the tiny, size 16 font VOXIA on the left ear. Also of note is the unobtrusive *tiny* status light, which only comes on during charging. Compared to the several other sets of gaudy headphones I own, I’d describe these as *sophisticated*Weight: This is important to me. Too light and they’re flimsy/cheap feeling, too heavy and they’re annoying to wear. The VOXOA headphones, I am happy to say, are just right.Comfort: I wore these for hours without any discomfort. The padding, in combination with the great shape of the headphones, makes for a put-it-on-and-forget it. I might just be lucky, but I can hardly feel them on when I’m wearing them.The size: I have a big head, so some headphones don’t fit me the best. These fit like a glove, and not in a cover-your-entire-ear-like-those-guys-that-direct-airplanes kind of way. In the world of headphones, these would be a small/medium in terms of the size of the unit itself.Bluetooth pairing with my iPhone was easy.Controls: Buttons on the right ear allow you to adjust volume, skip tracks, and pause/play.And finally, the sound: The sound is beautiful across all ranges and really provides and immersive experience while listening to music. I listened to a variety of artists across a good sampling of genres and really couldn’t find a weakness. Everything sounded incredible, especially for the price tag.All in all, this is a great option for someone wanting performance without needing the perceived prestige that comes with a flashy name brand. Ultimately I think this set beats out the brands that it’s trying to compete with, and it does so at a better price point. And, for you audiophiles out there (I’m not one, btw), take a Google and you’ll see that I’m not the only one loving the sound.Highly recommended.[unit provided for review by manufacturer]

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-09: I've used a number of different earbuds, and while some of them have surprisingly good sound for such small devices, I'm old school, from the days when I used to pull weak shortwave signals out of the ether using a pair of big headphones with rubber cushions that covered my whole ear. Well, The VOXOA HD headphones don't quite cover my whole ear, but they're close enough. Some earbuds do a pretty good job of reproducing bass notes, but the VOXOA headphones have nailed the bass - it sounds great. All of the music I played came through with excellent clarity and volume. Unlike some earbuds that completely block ambient noises, I could still hear louder background noises, which I prefer in case the phone rings or any other sounds I need to hear.Besides audio quality, the headphones beat any earbuds I've ever used for comfort. With the adjustable arms, the headset fit very comfortably on my head, and with the 1" of adjustment allowed in the arms, I think the headphones should fit just about anyone.The headphones worked fine with a 3.5mm audio cable (included - 39"≈1 meter), but the real fun was enjoying the freedom of Bluetooth. Pairing was simple, with the headset pairing with my Kindle Fire HDX 7" as device "VOXOA Headphone 33X" with no passcode needed. All controls are on the right side and are raised so your fingers can find them.I used the headphones for a couple of Skype calls. I was having problems with my Bluetooth dongle, so I used the headphones plugged into the 3.5mm audio jack on my laptop. The sound quality was very good, and the built-in microphone on the headset picked up my voice very clearly.A USB charging cable is included for recharging the headphones' internal battery through a USB port or an AC adapter.My verdict: This is a sweet pair of very comfortable headphones with great audio. They've quickly become my favorite listening device for music, Skype, and other audio applications.A product sample was provided by the manufacturer for review purposes.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-10: These headphones are adjustable and foldable, they come with a nice carrying bag, a USB charging cable, a 3.5 audio cable, and a short instruction guide. They have NFC auto-syncing technology to work instantly with your bluetooth devices and the battery power charge lasts a long time. The earpieces are nicely cushioned although they don't wrap around the ear. These headphones are not too big/heavy while they are fairly solidly constructed and should fit most people fine. For both wireless and wired applications these work well. The built-in microphone and controls allow you to use these with mobile phones (the bluetooth signal is probably not as bad a source of EMF radiation as having your ear right next to a cell phone). The cost of these is still pretty substantial, though competitive with similar high quality wireless headphones from other manufacturers. If you are looking for multi-purpose wireless headphones these may be a good investment,

    Rating: 4

    2013-12-31: Note: I received a free sample of these headphones from the manufacturer in exchange for an honest review.While I have never considered myself an audiophile per se, I have built up a really nice collection of various headphones over the years. Between headphones I've bought myself and those that have been sent to me from various manufacturers for review, I have tried just about all of them. I have everything from $20 airport kiosk headphones to $400 studio quality designer headphones. I can also attest that while price does not always correlate to performance, it is often a strong indicator. A pair of $100 headphones that do not perform as well as $300 headphones are not rated lower. You don't compare the acceleration of a Ford Focus with a Jaguar, even though both can be quality cars in their own right. Sound quality and price are just linked.All of that being said, it is also hard to rate headphones in isolation, so I have to compare them to something. I have a pair of Creative HN-900 that are sub-$100, Audio-Technica that are about $150, Jabra Revo that are about $200, and a few Monster headphones that are $250-$300 (and I used to own a Bose QC3). In conclusion, these Voxoa deliver quite impressive performance and feature set for their cost. I certainly don't rate them as high as my Jabra Revo, but they are quality headphones that I am quite glad to use.First thing to consider is comfort. These are nice and light, weighing in at just 6.3oz. They fold for storage (in a nicely included carrying bag), but unfold into solid headphones. They are on-the-ear rather than over the ear pads with a soft foam. It's not memory foam but feels very similar. I have a bigger head and found the headphones sat comfortably. The top of the head band has a soft pad on the underside as well. They were great for extended wearing.The headphones sound great connected either direct wire or with bluetooth. One thing that surprised me was that they are not recognized as a USB device like my Jabra Revo. The USB is only for charging, not for audio itself. So to use it with your PC, you either need to use the analog audio out or Bluetooth. Onboard controls are fairly simple to use, with dedicated buttons to advance the track, pause the music, and adjust the volume.As far as sound quality, these were nice and balanced but nothing really phenomenal. They are probably outclassed by my Audio-Technica headphones which cost about the same price, but don't include Bluetooth. For a bit more, my Jabra Revo have a much full sound. I found the audio quality more on par with my lower cost Creative headphones. The bass isn't particular strong and the trebles are a bit muddy. That being said, they were pleasant to use and to listen to music through, and the difference only showed up when I went back and forth between these headphones and my Jabra or Audio-Technica.The biggest pluses of these headphones are overall comfort, styling, and the Bluetooth functionality in a low cost package. The biggest downside is audio quality which just isn't on par with headphones that cost just a bit more, but is quite passable at this price point. As a result, I rate these as 4 stars and recommend them for a good pair of value headphones.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-10: These VOXOɅ HD VXG33X Bluetooth Headphones are a nice surprise: a high-quality set of portable headphones from a brand previously unknown to the U.S. market. They are very handsome, with attention to proportion, detail, materials and construction. They are a pleasure to use, combining quality audio with painless Bluetooth connection, intuitive controls, and a comfortable fit.The headband is about 1 1/4 inches wide and is padded with at the top. Unlike some over-the-ear headphones, these apply just the right amount of pressure to stay in place yet remain comfortable over extended periods. Each earpiece can be precisely adjusted within a 1 1/2 inch range for exact fit. They also swivel about 15 degrees in all directions and have exactly the right thickness of padding for comfort and isolation without bottoming out. The padding is covered with a protein leather that is very soft and is not prone to retaining heat and moisture. I am very pleased with the fit and comfort of these headphones even after several hours of continuous use.The Bluetooth is the latest generation and the CSR8645 chip uses the aptX codec so it is audibly equivalent to a wired connection. Range is about 30 feet, the same as my other Bluetooth devices. The microphone for telephone use is clear, although it does pick up ambient noise. They are HD voice-enabled, and that technology began being implemented by U.S. telephony carriers in early 2013.The VOXOɅ headphones are intended for use with portable devices but the sound quality produced by the 40 mm drivers is pleasant enough for everyday use. The sound is as good as similar headphones selling for twice the price and is up to the standards set by their appearance and comfort.Sound isolation is good for on-ear headphones, so that while listening to music, ambient noise is dampened but not completely excluded. Spatial ambiance and soundstage are better than most on-ear headphones, although certainly not as good as what would be expected from an open-back, over-the-ear headphone. Impedance is average; as with all headphones, it is best to turn the source volume up and then adjust the listening volume with the headphone controls.The sound is well-balanced with the slight bass emphasis that is expected in portable headphones—but it is not at the expense of treble. I was pleasantly surprised that flutes and violins were just as full and detailed as bass instruments. I have never noticed any muddiness, sibilance, or other distortion. These are quite versatile headphones and the sound quality is higher than average, certainly much better than would be expected in this price range.They are shipped in a sturdy box that can be used for storage or they can be folded to under 4 x 7 x 2 1/2 in. to fit in the stretchy sueded storage pouch. A USB charging cable is included as well as a 38 in. 3.5 mm audio cable; either will to allow them to be used as wired headphones without relying on the rechargeable battery or Bluetooth.The instruction pamphlet is easy to follow and organizes control functions in charts for easy reference. I didn't actually need to refer to it as there is nothing tricky about the way these headphones work. There is also a very generous warranty.Three hours of charging the lithium ion battery will give at least fourteen hours of listening at moderate volume. Fully charge the battery before first use.A sample was provided for testing and unbiased review. I have enjoyed using these headphones because of the combination of comfort and enjoyable sound quality and would definitely recommend them to others.Specifications:Sound pressure level - 108 dBImpedance - 64 𝜴Frequency response 10-20 HzBluetooth - 4.0NFC-enabledAACaptXHD voice with echo cancellationBattery - 430 mAhSize - 176 x 165 x 32 mmWeight - 173 g (Actual 179 g or 6.3 oz.)

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-12: Disclaimer: I received a sample set from the manufacturer for review. However I write unbiased reviews and will not risk my reputation as a reviewer for the sake of a free product.The bottom line is that these headphones are far and away the best in their price class, and I liked them better than a high-end set that costs more than twice as much.I am a former professional audio engineer; I did location recording of orchestras, choirs, etc., for public radio and other clients. I relied on headphones to get the job done, and I compare everything with my "gold standard" Sony professional models.In professional headphones, accuracy and reliability are everything. Consumer headphones can maybe be a little less rugged, and can have a lot of nice convenience features, but they ought to be accurate. Too many consumer headphones, including expensive ones, shape the sound to give a result that the manufacturer thinks the buyer will like. The problem with this is that taste in audio varies, and sound customized for one genre of music may sound terrible on another. The biggest sin is overemphasized bass, something even Bose is guilty of.The Voxoa headphones are clearly designed for accuracy and they meet that goal as well as any consumer headphone that I've listened to. The bass is tight and natural. It has plenty of punch without being overdone. It sounds like it is supposed to sound. The mid-range is also accurate, although I thought I detected minor coloration in the upper mids. The high end is nice although a little short in what is commonly called "airiness" or "transparency." Overall very, very nice for a mid-priced headset.But there are other things that make this headset a good one. It's lightweight and extremely comfortable, probably at the top of the range. I didn't get tired after several hours of use; other headphones are often too tight. These adapted gently to my head size and floated on my ears. By the way, they are strictly speaking on-ear rather than over-ear (circumaural), but I was pleasantly surprised to find that they give just as much acoustic isolation as the larger over-ear units.I used these in both wired and Bluetooth mode. There was no detectable difference in sound quality. Pairing for Bluetooth is very easy and takes under a minute to do manually (I didn't test NFC). The Bluetooth controls are all on one side and easy to identify by feel. They are very simple to use with the exception of the large "multi-function" button. You had better read the instruction booklet, which unfortunately is written in English that could use editing by a native speaker.The unit looks durable and is an example of careful engineering. The audio cord is thin and I don't know how long it will last under heavy use, but fortunately it's got a stereo mini-plug on each end so it can be easily and cheaply replaced. (Some headphones have weird audio cords which are the devil to replace.) The charging cord also adheres to standards. A couple hours of charging gets you more than 10 hours of play time on Bluetooth. By the way, you need to "find your own" USB compatible charging source, as no wall-wart is supplied in the package.The only other durability question is about the pads on the earpieces. They are key to the comfort of the unit, so I hope they last, but I'm guessing they will.I give the unit five stars because of the quality engineering and good design, and excellent sound for the money. I have no hesitation in recommending these if you want a high-end headset for a mid-range price.

    Rating: 5

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-10-03: I bought this phone to replace a Kyocera Rise. I had that phone rooted, so I could tweak that one to reduce some of the rebooting and memory issues that I experienced about month into owning that phone. It was running fine, then one day in late Sep. 2013, I decided to try an app (AKA Pimp My ROM, LOL!) that would make some extensive tweaks possible. I went crazy... initially I meant to tweak the wifi part only. Then, I began to check a few more options... then some more... more... until I practically went through every damned option available. I saw a reset button somewhere, but didn't think of pressing it, though I should have.(Though now in hindsight, perhaps I'm glad I didn't. ;))Rebooted the phone, then... boot loop... boot loop... BOOT LOOP...After a few minutes of this, I tried to factory reset the poor thing. Didn't work. (That killed the option for me to debug the phone with a tool that works on PC's as I learned later.) At that moment, I 'bricked' it. Useless! GRRR!!!Enter the Event! Ha!After some research in several forums, including Android Forums (AKA Phandroid), I chose this one. I noticed the similarities with the Rise (same CPU and graphics processor). I don't mind the lack of a physical keyboard. Before the moment I bricked the Rise, I noticed myself using the keyboard less, and doing more typing on screen.The extra internal memory for app storage helps a little, and the OS on this phone lets users move some apps to the SD card. Interestingly, the available system RAM on this phone isn't much more than on the Rise (360 MB vs 357 MB!).Even with that issue, I've noticed that the Event is a snappier phone. I installed 30 apps on it. Among those apps, I installed two that kills unwanted apps in the background after a set period (every two hours), and another that controls wifi and 3g when the phone is idle.I noticed that the phone seems to warm a bit, mostly when watching long videos or playing 3d accelerated games for an extended period. Most smartphones exhibit this side effect anyway, so this is nothing new. Some users have complained of the phones being nearly too hot to handle. I'd say those phones are either defective, has a stubborn app that refuses to get out of memory (they're bad, delete 'em if you can), or lack an app killer. Even if an app killer is used (or not), swiping apps from the multitasker list can help reduce memory issues.As far as the appearance, it's nothing special. The phone is a featherweight device. All black, all the time, unless you buy one from Radio Shack that has the red parts, or buy a colorful protective case for it. There are even some Otterbox-like cases for this phone, including some that are sold here. I'm going for a metallic red rubberized case + screen protector that should be in my paws in a few days. Because this phone is so light, it can be quite easy to drop if you aren't careful.Out of the box, the phone should serve you well, if your needs are modest.If you want a little extra performance, you're going to have to root the phone. And yes, I've had it done to my Event.This page has a guide that will work as directed for the Event. It is aimed at Rise owners: [...]UPDATED November 10, 2013: I have had the phone for a month. So far, I have about 45 apps loaded onto it, and it's working smoothly.A few apps have failed to work for me, most notably the facebook app. I realize that the number of apps I have is affecting the performance of that app. facebook is a MEMORY AND CPU HOG, and is probably best left off lower end phones like this one, unless you only have a few apps installed (maybe 15 or less, rooted or not...). Not even a few of the largest games and apps I have installed have created serious memory issues as facebook has (even the free ones with banner ads)! To get around this problem, I have email updates activated for the social media sites I use, and then view them from the Gmail app. Uses less memory, and I get the updates I want frequently enough while I'm awake. I then created links to the sites as bookmarks on my home screen, so I view them from a browser. facebook has most of its functions on the mobile site anyway, so I don't miss the app much. Still not suffering from FOMO, haha!At least tc electronic's TonePrint app actually works with this phone. I use that with my BG250 bass amp to change effects between songs. :)update Nov. 18 (typed from Event): The phone is as solid as ever. In love with the spell check! I'm thinking of putting a full featured program that will let me hack code on it. Ah, the advantages of rooting + Link2SD! =) All on a phone that cost me $55 (including accessories).Update Dec. 3: I've had the phone for a full 2 months. Since I rooted it after 2 weeks of purchase, the phone has performed well and very rarely rebooted itself. I have applied one tweak, and that is to improve WiFi response. I use an app called Andromizer, and increased the WiFi Interval scan to 300 milliseconds (0.3 seconds). It's long enough to improve reception, but short enough to help keep battery use down when idle. The WiFi automatically cuts off and switches to 3g (or phone service only if you don't use 3g) after about 5-6 minutes if nothing is being downloaded in the background.There isn't much that can be done with this phone if you want to tweak it further without bricking it. It may be possible to get a faster launcher if you want, but that's about the only other thing I can recommend if you want to tweak.To sum it up, IMHO if you root you need:1. superuser app2. Link2SD app3. /system/lib/egl/egl.cfg tweak (leave adreno200 line uncommented, add # to other lines)4. increase wifi signal to 300 milliseconds (you can use longer values, Andromizer limits this to 300ms, which seems to work fine for me)5. change launcher to something more lightweight or one you likeOtherwise if you don't root, freeze the bloatware that can be frozen (or don't want to use), and limit the number of apps to around 20. If you choose to use twitter, facebook and other apps that need to run in the background, get a cache clearing app that can clear cache automatically at least twice a day to reduce the chance of random reboots.UPDATE DEC. 10, 2013:I am still using Andromizer for implementing some phone tweaks. In addition to the 300ms tweak for WiFi, I've also enabled the 3G/4G tweak at the highest setting to speed up 3G internet. As long as there's enough signal, it really works! Great for when you can't get a decent WiFi signal. Keep an eye on that 2.5 GB throttling limit with Minutes Checker. Also, I used the One Click optimization setting. I unchecked the remove debug logger, and kernel tweak settings. IT IS IMPORTANT TO MAKE SURE THAT KERNEL TWEAK (OR ANY OTHER KERNEL TWEAKS) STAYS UNCHECKED FOR THIS PHONE, if you use One Click optimization! If you leave that checked and then reboot, your phone is as good as dead. It will boot loop until the insects take over the Earth... ;)I have also added an app called Greenify. This activates the hibernate function of the Android OS that is only available to rooted phones. I wish I didn't have to root the phone for that, but worth it if you can. Greenify can be used to select apps that should hibernate when the phone is idle. The benefits come in handy when the phone is unplugged, and not charging. This will help save some battery, and reduce unwanted activity in the background. All of that helps reduce unexpected overheating, which seems to be a problem with many low end Android devices.With the tweaks I put on this phone, I've been able to reinstall a few social media apps I stayed away from, due to memory issues. I put back the official apps of facebook, twitter, Google+, and ELJay, an app for LiveJournal and other sites that use LJ's software.UPDATE 2/26/2014I've since dropped Greenify. I found that it bogs down the phone when used with some streaming music apps (Pandora, TuneIn, etc). I have also "debloated" my phone. Read more about this here: [...] BACKUP EVERYTHING FIRST before debloating. You may want to reuse some of the apps at a later date, or reinstall them before unrooting and reselling the phone.UPDATE 4/28/2014I've now relegated this phone to backup status, as I use a rooted LG Optimus F3 as my daily driver. Still, I've managed a few tweaks to this phone that still make it useful. If you're still in the market for a cheap phone for primary or backup use, this can still fit the bill if your expectations are modest. The updated version of Link2SD now allows data to be moved to the /data/sdext partition. Initially, I did try to move my data to the sdext partition, but it seemed to slow down some programs for me, so after two days, I moved data back to internal. If you don't mind it, moving data out of internal can further increase space for new programs. Just remember to back up your SD card, repartition it from a PC, then enlarge sdext (I recommend 2 GB, but you can go bigger than that).I also installed an app called GL2SD. It moves obb (opaque binary blobs) files to your SD card's main FAT32 partition. This is great for installing some large games that would otherwise be out of reach for a phone like this. As with all object linking apps for Android, the device must be rooted. I tried one game (so far) with this linker installed. It's a first person shooter game called Dead Trigger. Unrooted, one would have a hard time even putting a large game on a phone like this. But with Link2SD and GL2SD working together, it runs... and quite well for a 1 GHz single core CPU phone! The game does slow down a bit in high intensity scenes, but it's otherwise playable. :) So there ya go... if you're on a budget and willing to root, you can run some hefty programs on this phone! And be a member of androidforums.com. I'm listed there as daffyducknj. If you're lucky I might be able to help you out, or some other person will.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-13: Pretty cheap phone. You get what you pay for. With that said I wouldn't buy it again but wouldn't discourage someone who needs just a inexpensive starter phone

    Rating: 3

    2014-02-19: well this is a very nice phone. i have the Galaxy s 4 and if i didn't this phone would be the phone for me. its just a very nice phone and sounds great the phone is just so darn cute, i bought it for my daughter and we both love it.

Kyocera will not release access, because it is against their agreements with the service providers.     Rating: 1

    2014-02-28: Coming from an iPhone 4S that I kept in an Otterbox Defender from day 1, I like this case's tough protection.It doesn't have a full display cover like the Otterbox, so a cheesy stick-on screen protector is necessary, which I'm not real happy about, but it does the job. However, I'm not sure if it's the phone, or lack of a plastic display cover, but the image is MUCH clearer than it was on my iPhone in the Otterbox. So that may be one benefit... I know this is not an Otterbox review, but one thing I really liked about that case was it's complete enclosure of the phone. The case absorbed almost all shock. I'm not so sure this Trident case will have the same shock absorption as my old phone case.I used to drop my iPhone or toss it around casually in the Otterbox. I don't have that same confidence with this case, although I have dropped it a few times and it's done it's job protecting the phone.This case is still very tough. It's a supple rubber skin around the phone, with a plastic exoskeleton that keeps the rubber from wearing out prematurely, and give's it rigidity and protection from actually falling out of the case. This is inverse of the Otterbox, which is a plastic endoskeleton with a rubber skin.The rubber skin makes the phone usable for one-handed operation. Without it, I can't get enough of a grip on the thing to thumb the screen. With the rubber and appropriate bulking by the case, I can hold the phone in one hand and use my thumb to hit the screen. Makes it so much more convenient when I'm driving a school bus and feel like watching youtube or texting...I've only had the phone and case for a month, but there's no sign of wear or rubber stretching. That being said, it's had plenty of exposure to snow so far, and has held up fine. I suspect it's not going to handle lawnmowing dust the way the otterbox did (I used to stick it in the dishwasher), but we'll see in a few months.Another drawback to the case is the lack of a belt clip. Call me a geek, but not having a holster or belt clip for this phone is a major pain in the...pocket. It's a huge phone. I look like a 1985 nerd with it hanging out of my shirt pocket, and it's totally uncomfortable in the pocket of my jeans. Not to mention the lint it collects there. The case makes it difficult to find a generic phone belt-clip holster to drop it in, so I end up with a trade-off; Do I want to belt holster it with little to no protection, or do I want to protect it and have to constantly carry it or stuff it in my pocket?Overall, it's a good case. Much better than a simple skin or just a screen protector.I would give it 5 stars if it had a belt-clip and full display protection similar to the Otterbox.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-24: This was purchased for my son and he really likes it. It is a good protection for the phone which he already had dropped.

Well I should say I actually threw it up not just let the grasp go. Sure enough I was freaking out that the drop was just too much for the case; Opened it up and wham all nice and clean.     2014-07-21: Overall a great case for someone looking for a full-time case that offers good corner and front-face protection. It fits and looks really nice, there's no play or movement, it just becomes part of the phone. It can be a little difficult to remove, so I wouldn't recommend it to someone who switches cases frequently.Nearly the perfect case for a moto X. I'd love to give this 4.5 stars if I could, but there's just a couple things keeping it from being perfect:- Buttons are fairly stiff, even after a few months of break-in.- The edges are a bit sharp along the front/back mold joint line, and feel harsh against the hand.The material is a flexible TPU plastic that's a bit stiffer than most TPU cases, which I really like. There's no sticky feeling to the case; it adds just enough grip while still being easy to remove from a pocket.

    2014-07-13: I was hoping this case would be a little more the like Urban Armor Gear case for my Galaxy S3 (which I just replaced with the Moto X). Unfortunately, it is not.However, the case is as described, and for $10 shipped to my door, I can't really complain. The case adds very little to the phone and holds it very snug. The first time getting it on was a bit of a chore, but I'd rather that be the case than have a loose fitting case.The back is a hard frosted plastic, which allows me to see (kind of) the back of the phone. I don't have a custom Moto X, so I really don't care. It is cool to see the carbon fiber through it.As far as the edges go, they are a bit sharp from the molding process (I assume this is the cause). If I was getting really picky, I'd ask for a little bit more grip to it as well, however it doesn't slip from my hands and slides easily into my pocket.The biggest surprise with this purchase was the screen protector. Most of the time, they are complete garbage and I typically put them on until I can find my way to a Zagg Invisible Shield Kiosk, however this one fits amazing, and went on almost flawless! (Would have been flawless, but I hadn't anticipated a quality screen protector, so I didn't spend an adequate amount of time dusting the screen).Overall, good case, very good screen protector, excellent value.

    2014-07-16: I've had this case for about a month now and so far I really like it. The case follows the contours of the phone to continue making this phone easy to handle.     Rating: 4

    2013-12-17: The good points for this case is that it adds very little bulk to the phone and I think it works well for protecting from scuffs and short drops. I also like that it preserves the dimple on the back of the moto x. I did not find the edges to be uncomfortable as others reported.It looks and feels cheap, which, at this price, should be expected. I'm not a fan of the angular design; it seems to clash the design of the moto x. The case actually feels a little slippery, especially the back part (which is frosted transparent). The buttons on this case are too stiff; you have to really press them hard. I've had other cheap TPU cases with hard buttons, and I resolved that by taping a little "shim" on the inside of the case in the button area. The shim results in less pressure being required to press the buttons. You can adjust the pressure required by adjusting the thickness of the shim. A couple layers of thick card stock paper should do it.The case is okay, but I'm not a fan of the way it looks. I went with this one over others because this one preserves the dimple on the back of the phone.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-30: Good Case - Keeps the phone in great shape. I've dropped it probably 5-6 times without any issue. At first the edges felt like they dug into my hand but after a while I think they dulled down or I got used to it.

    2013-12-01: Awesome case, comes with screen protector included. The screen protector is thus far the easiest protector I've ever put on (out of about 10 portable devices I've owned in the past couple years). I still ended up with a few bubbles, but I blame that on myself, not the product!The case is phenominal. I was looking for something that didn't add too much bulk to my phone yet provided some sort of protection. The case feels sturdy, but not flimsy. It's made out of some sort of flexible plastic/rubber material. Furthermore, after measuring with calipers, the case adds .1 inch to each side.The following measurements without the case:H: 3.59" (9.11cm)W: 1.8" (4.56cm)D: 0.26" (.65cm)With the case, each dimension increased by exactly .1 inch (.26cm). The only anomaly is that I measured .27cm difference on the depth, as opposed to .26cm on the height and width.The case works with the motorola skip, I have confirmed it on all of my skips and they work great. All of the buttons still work. Just note that this case does not add flaps to either the USB port or the headphone jack, so this does not increase water resistance. It also does not allow for access to the SIM card, you will still need to remove the case to access it.

The Moto X was designed with one handed use in mind. That said, I usually hold my phone in one hand with my index finger, middle finger, and ring finger supporting the back of my device, while my pinky supports the bottom edge. That's where the problem lies. The bottom edge is hard plastic and the weight of the phone on your pinky really makes it uncomfortable. Due to this I switched to a different case, but I'll keep this one just in case.

    2013-06-08: As most of the other reviewers mention, this charge stand works with a cover on the device. That's not as common as it should be.I got this for my wife's Galaxy S4. She has a thick "wallet-style" case that covers the front and back of the phone. Very thick leather. Still, this charge stand allows her to dock the phone with the case cover open or closed. So, very high marks for convenience.It takes a little bit of jiggery-pokery to assemble the stand; the cord attaches with a very light-weight plastic gizmo and I had concerns about breaking it during assembly (as other reviewers have noted). But I managed to get it together without any incidents.I tried to dock my Note II in this thing, but -- despite the hefty weight of this stand -- that's heart-stoppingly scary; combining the height of this stand, plus the size of the Note II results in a wobbly, Tower of Pisa situation that I wouldn't do on a regular basis.It'd be nice to be able to find a dock for Samsung phones that permitted docking & charging in landscape mode; that would be ideal for bedside Netflix watching, or as an alarm clock, or... But until I find a landscape-mode charger, this one is very nice.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-16: UPDATE APRIL 19, 2014:I really loved this when I received it. BUT after one day of use, the charging cable that came with the product quit working. I didn't know this until the end of the second day when I undocked my phone to leave work and my phone was down to 34%!!! I fiddled around trying to figure out what was going on and realized the charging cord was not working. It may have actually damaged my phone, too. After one day in this charging dock, hardly any of my prior charging cables will work in my phone.I had seen in other reviews that the only thing holding your phone up is the charging pin and after more closely looking at the design, I realize this is true. I am now wondering if the constant pressure on the charging port messed it up?!?!?I am sending it back for a refund.I just got this today and already I love it. I have read the other reviews (before I purchased on Amazon) and see the negative points. This charging dock probably isn't the best for horizontal display. I like my phone vertical so it is perfect for me.I bought this to use in my office as I have my phone syncing throughout the day with my work calendar, to do lists, etc. When I first put this together, I tried to use the USB cord that I was already using. This did not work. You need to use the USB cord that comes with the kit.I also thought at first that this dock was not very stable. The phone does rock side to side a tiny bit if wiggled while in the dock which seemed unstable. But then I tried to just grab it out of the dock to take it with me and it did not come out with one hand. I had to use two hands and secure the phone to release the dock. This is nice. I have another docking station at home that is not this secure.My phone (Galaxy S3) has a double layer shock resistant case on it and it docks fine with the case on. I don't know what other reviewers are doing that their case doesn't fit. Maybe if they didn't use the USB cord that came with the unit, that might happen. When I tried to use a different USB cord, I couldn't even get the phone to match up with the pin.

    2014-04-07: Amazing sound, I carry this thing all over with me now. Battery truly is 8-9 hours. Can't think of one bad thing to say.

    2014-03-19: The Lepow Modre Bluetooth Speaker fits in the palm of your hand but offers superb sound in such a miniscule size. With its unusual shape and variety of colors to choose from, there is sure a match for everyone.It arrived enclosed in a reusable cool hard plastic storage cup. It was extremely easy to pair with my iPhone 5S and did not require a pin or code. The included instructions come in several different languages and have a brief summary of how to pair and use the speaker. Controlling the volume and answering calls are all done via your phone. The only controls the speakers has is an on/off switch and the outputs for the charging and auxiliary port. The speaker has two very small LED lights to show the charge and Bluetooth status.Besides using it in Bluetooth mode you can also connect via an auxiliary cable. Connect your laptops, tablets, MP3 players or anything that has an headphone jack.With so many Bluetooth speakers out in the market today it can be a difficult job to pick one. The biggest factors to me are audio and visual appeal. The Modre has got my attention with its stylish good looks, amazingly crystal clear sound and ability to fill a modest size room like a bedroom, kitchen or office with great sound. The bottom of the speaker has a rubberized ring to keep it from sliding around.Solidly built and has one year warranty.Sample provided for review.

    2014-06-29: 5 out of 5!!! It is aesthetically pleasing in terms of sound, looks, and design. It is easily connected via bluetooth and AUX. Pairing is painless and quick. I paired 3 of my phones with great ease. Look no further if you are looking for a portable speaker :)

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-12: Here my LePow's Modre Bluetooth Speaker review:Before reviewing the speaker, I would like to write a note about LePow's costumer service: they are really amazing, the best experience I have. Since one of my speakers came damaged they promptly send me a refund and my new order was sent in less than 2 days - Great!Now about the speaker:This little speaker has good quality and the sound is loud and enjoyable. They are ease to pair, the battery is long lasting, and they are really small so you can bring it with you everywhere you go.Having different brands of Bluetooth speaker under $100 I can classify them in following order:1) Braven 570 - The best sound in the list, open and clear with tight bass and soft treble, the mids are clear and very smooth. You have volume controls, hands free and a USB port to charge your phone in an emergency. Since the controls are in the right side of the speaker you have to get the speaker in your hands to use them. The Bluetooth range is great (30 feet). Price: around $100.2) LePow's Modre - Good sound, lack a bit of treble and bass, is very portable and has good construction. The only control available is the on/off at the speaker's bottom, you have to use your phone for volume and start hands free. The Bluetooth range is great (30 feet). Price: around $ 30.3) GoGroove BlueSYNC SRC - The sound is ok, but a little harsh in the treble and lacks some bass. Easy to pair, the controls works flawless and they are positioned on the speaker top, so they are very easy to access and to use. Price: around $304) Pyle PWPBT60 - The sound is ok, a lot of bass, but the mids and trebles are muffled. Lacks certain openness to the sound. They are sturdy, heavy, but have the worst Bluetooth connection. The connection drops all the time when someone or something is placed between the speaker and the phone, very annoying. The Bluetooth range is very limited. Price: around $70If you want a good sounding speaker that you can carry with you everywhere and don't want spend a lot of money, LePow's is the way to go. They come in a nice pack (a nice cup) with nice cables, they have a great design, very good construction. Enjoy !

The built in mic works great for phone calls and skype calls too! I would highly recommend it for $20 or even $30, I'm not sure for any higher than that though.

    2014-04-03: I have quite a few Bluetooth speakers. Most are OK, but usually leave me wanting more. More bass, more clarity, more battery life, etc. Finally, I've found one with the perfect combination of everything! This Modre is stylish, sounds great, connects easy, and comes in great packaging. And, as an added bonus, the packaging doubles as a bass-booster. As I was listening to the Modre at my desk and admiring the plastic coffee-sippy cup it came in, on a whim I put the speaker back into it's packaging and it made the already good bass response even deeper. Ultimately, this is a solid, well-made product in a sea of mediocrity and yet it's priced very competitively, which makes it a winner in my book.

    2014-04-17: I've looked at a lot of Bluetooth speakers but this has got to be the prettiest. The presentation of this speaker is just great. First of all, it comes not in a box but in a cup. The cup is about 6 inches tall and has a silicone cover that matches the color of the speaker inside.When you open it, you get the speaker, a small instruction sheet, a USB cable and a 3.5mm audio cable. I received this speaker for review purposes.Bluetooth connection is a cinch. I didn't even have to read the instructions. I just turned on the power at the bottom and my smart phone found it right away. Once powered on, the sound is amazing. This speaker is only about 3.5 inches tall but the sound coming from it belies its size. This is one of the few times where form and function come together. I'm really impressed by this speaker and highly recommend it.

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-26: From the reviews I read I was expecting a little more quality sound. Sure I don't expect this thing to compete with Bose or anything but I have bought less expensive speakers that sounded much better. After reading the reviews of people who swear by how good this thing is...I have to say I'm not very pleased with it. I really wanted to like it, when I opened the box I was very happy until I listened to it. Maybe I have a defective unit.UpdateShortly after receiving this speaker I was asked via email from Lepow about the item. I shared this review with them and they immediately apologized for my dissatisfaction and offered to send another speaker. I was so impressed with this kind of customer service that I had to raise my review to 4 stars. I listened to the new speaker as well. I still feel the bass could be a little better but I did find a little trick. If you keep it in the cup it came in it does seem to enhance the sound a little. These are very quality made speakers which you will notice right away.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-13: Using it in my office at work, the sound great for a mono-speaker setup, but good, not issue, and can go up really high. Would recommend.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-17: I recently moved thousands upon thousands of songs to the cloud and signed up for music streaming. So I started looking for speakers, specifically bluetooth speakers. This speaker produces a nice clear sound, although its size restricts it from producing any measureable bass. Volume is enough to fill a room and is clear even at the highest volume. This unit paired easily and does not lose connection to the device. My first unit had issues with the bluetooth dropping if you just waved your hand in between the devices. I contacted Lepow and they shipped me a new one immediately. They have excellent customer service and I would not hesitate recommending this product to friends and family. The new Modre does not lose connection and I can make it about 25ish feet without issue. I havent had the device on long enough to drain the battery as I normally play it while at work at lower volumes and then charge it overnight. It easily has played 6 hours without losing any quality whatsoever. I love the shape and size of the speaker and it makes a great portable speaker. I chose the green color and its a really great color. I know alot of people love the packaging but for me a normal/smaller carrying bag/case would of been preferred.Some things I am not fond of are that the unit does not have physical buttons to change the volume, or to answer calls. If you use the speaker during a phone call, people on the other end have issues hearing you unless you speak very loud. They also say it sounds as though you are in a tunnel. I didnt buy this speaker for talking on the phone, but since its a selling point, I thought I had to comment on it as well.I have a few other brands of bluetooth speakers coming in, so be sure to check my other reviews in the next week or two.

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-25: This is a cool little bluetooth speaker, and the sound will not disappoint. I had it out of the box and synched up and playing music from my itunes in less than a minute without reading the instructions. I was impressed with the big sound that came out of the small speaker. It is well designed, easy to use, and gives you impressive sound.What I particularly liked about this speaker is that it actually looks really cool. I am happy to have it sitting on my desk, and I think it is better looking than many competing products in this space.Looks good, sounds great, and a reasonable price . . . what more could you ask for?(I was provided a sample for review)

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-01: This is the coolest portable Bluetooth speaker we have ever tested, and the sound it produces is outstanding! I like this speaker; it charges quickly, was easy to pair with our phones, plays great sound, and each charge lasts a long time. Very recommended.The Lepow Modre is much more than just a speaker as we were not only able to listen to great music, but we could use it as a speakerphone to handle incoming calls... all through the mic on the speaker's base! Very cool - well worth purchasing. The unit comes in multiple colors and the one we received was green. It came with a USB power cord that we plugged in to our Samsung phone's wall adapter, and the speaker fully charged in about 1.5 hours as indicated by the red charging light going out.The excellent instructions made it easy to pair with our phones, and pairing was quick and trouble-free with the speaker's voice prompt letting you know when pairing starts ("Pairing") and also when it is completed ("Pairing Completed"). That was a nice touch. The phone paired with the speaker was always within three to 12 feet of the speaker, typically one to eight feet away, with relatively good line of sight between the two devices. At no time did we experience distortion or loss of volume due to those distances.Tested with my Samsung Galaxy S3 and our teenage son's HTC Droid DNA, the first thing that we noticed was how well this speaker responded to the equalizers on those phones. The DNA has Dre Beats audio on-board, and man-o-man did this speaker rock with that program! When placed on the counter or tabletop, the impact on bass volume and resonance was outstanding.If you would like to see pictures of the speaker that I took, please go back to the speaker's main sales page, scroll down to where the "Most Helpful Customer Reviews" section starts, and look to the right of that area for the "Product Images From Customers" section. It really is a neat looking and great sounding device.We played an eclectic selection including Linkin Park, Everlast, Bob Marley and even a little B.B. King, from sources including Amazon's MP3 Cloud, Pandora and our own audio files. The results were outstanding; with a little tweaking from the equalizers for the different mixes of music, we coaxed the Lepow Modre speaker into producing superb sound for several hours. If I didn't have to concentrate to write this review, I would still be listening to the great tunes right this moment.While enjoying the music, we tested the inbound call capabilities and were impressed by the sound quality of the mic and the speaker during the call. I took a walk outside and placed a call to my son's phone; he answered the call and then spoke with me via the speaker -- and then we switched. Perfect device to use as an impromptu speakerphone!How many times have you purchased electronics and found that the user manual is just worthless? NOT the case here; the manual that comes with this speaker is well written and easy to follow, and has versions in more languages than I have ever seen come with such a device. Glad to see that time and care was put into creating a useful, well written guide.The speaker's retail carton, aka the cup, seems to be a novelty; thought maybe turning it upside down and placing the speaker on top of it would allow some special acoustic properties to shine through... but nope, the speaker sounds best when place on solid furniture.The User manual notes that there is a one year limited manufacturer's warranty, so if an issue arises before that period expires I will return here to update the review and let you know what the issue was and how resolution was handled. I did receive this speaker gratis from the manufacturer, and have put it through the paces to objectively find out how well it performed. My statements here reflect that testing.If you are looking for a speaker of this style, size and functionality, for use similar to what I have described above, then we highly recommend the Lepow Modre to you. Neat, funky, fun, easy to use, great sounds... really a nice unit.Go for it and enjoy.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-05: This Lepow Bluetooth speaker has a somewhat quirky design and comes in quirky packaging, too. That's not necessarily a bad thing. The speaker provides ample sound, but compared to my Philips SoundShooter, the bass is lacking in this speaker.PROs+ Loud speaker: much better than the speakers built into a phone+ The "Power On" voice is not obnoxiously loud, which is an issue with some other bluetooth speakers+ No volume controls: which I prefer as there is only one volume level I have to worry about messing with+ Physical on/off switch: no holding down a button and trying to figure out if it is on or not+ Micro USB charging: works with the chargers you likely already haveCONs- Level of bass is lacking, but sound quality is still good. However, I prefer the sound quality of the Philips SoundShooter over this device.- Portions of the instructions are in broken English, but it is fairly easy to figure out how to use this device

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-05: The first thing you notice about the Modre when you open the shipping box is the... odd packaging. It's quirky. It's fun. And highly unique.The Modre comes shipped in a travel style "cup." It's not really a travel mug as the rubber lid has no opening for liquid, but you can remove the sticker from the cup and all the packaging, give it a good wash and have a perfectly usable cup to go with your Modre. This kind of solution is quite brilliant in my mind, as if the person who receives the Modre keeps the cup, that's kept some worthless packing material out of the land fill or recycle bin. Of course, it will eventually need to be tossed, but in a few years I would hope, meaning you really are making a small difference.Anyway, the packing is brilliant. Hands down.The other things that stands out to me is the design of the speaker. I've tried out many... way too many... Bluetooth speakers. Each sounds OK and each has some unique design cue to it. The Modre is the first that seems to be designed with the thought of true 360 degree music. I can confirm, by dancing around the speaker as it blares my music that the experience is, pretty much, the same in front as it is from behind the speaker.The performance itself is about what I've come to expect from a BT speaker. It sounds OK. It's not audiophile quality, and if that's what you are looking for in this price range you are deluding yourself for sure (it won't happen). Instead, if you lower your standards a tiny bit, you can jump into the Modre and enjoy truly portable, easily portable as the weight is minimal, BT audio from your speakers.It also includes a mic so that you can use the Modre as a speaker phone. My only complaint is that there are no controls on the device to answer the phone or change volume. That's a minor complaint given the performance and fun level.I used BT, which was simple to connect to my Lumia 1020 and my iPhone (don't ask why I have 2 phones). I also plugged the speaker into my computer using the line out. Sound is good out of the box. If you want a deeper bass experience, or tighter treble, plug the speaker into your computer or connect it via BT to your computer and use a program, such as J River Media Center, that allows you to do custom EQ. After EQ the sound is quite good. And no, I don't expect EQ capability on a portable speaker at this price, just pointing out that a little EQ can go a long way.Overall:I am quite happy with the Modre. The packaging is silly, quirky and fun. This is the first time I've mentioned PACKAGING in a speaker review for a BT speaker.Performance, for the price, is quite nice. With a little EQ, you get a great sound but unfortunately not all phones off that kind of capability.With the ability to plug the included 2.5mm plug into a device that doesn't have BT support, you can still enjoy the sound from the Modre and your chosen device.Highly recommended.I received a free sample from the manufacturer for review purposes. I would NOT hesitate to spend money on a Lepow product. Bar none.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-03: This little baby puts out good amount of volume, with nice clarity and not much muddiness to the sound. For the price I paid, great buy.

    2013-09-13: I tried on of those green stick to the phone things on a recent trip and found it worthless for me so returned it. There was 2 problems I had with it. First, if you are renting a car, you don't want to glue the disc that mounts to the dash on a rental and without that and laws that prevent windshield suction use, most cars don't have a place to suction such a device. Second, If you use almost any kind of case with your phone, that green stick to won't stay stuck to. This item solves both those problems. The weighted part can be used in almost any dash and is easily just lifted when done so can be used in multiple vehicles. It ratchets closed on your phone so it will not fall off and releases with a button. It also comes with one of those stick on disc that you can use in your on vehicle for a more permanent place to suction if you choose and just take the waited pad with you when you travel. This is a great item. I use it with a Note 2 so it will fit a large phone.

But for a universal dash friction stand, probably it is the best you can find. Be aware that the bottom of the friction stand is firm & does not shape to the surface of your dash, like Garmin that made like sand bag & molds to the shape of your dash. So you get the best out of this, if the surface of your dash is flat without any curves.

It fits the phone very snug and I never worried about its security.Overall I think this would work great for many people, but just didn't work out for me.     A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2012-09-28: Bought a Galaxy Nexus first but burned through a fully charged battery in less than a day (~4- hours of use) and kept dropping calls in first week of use on Verizon's usually excellent network. So turned it in and exchanged it for the Razr Maxx. What a GREAT decision. This phone holds a charge all day long (8+ hours) with heavy use. With light use while studing for an exam, I timed it and it lasted 74 HOURS before recharging! ARE YOU KIDDING ME???!!! NO!!!!!!! That is the ABSOLUTE TRUTH! Never even heard of a smartphone lasting 2 days, let alone 3! And my previous 2 smartphones I added extended batteries to them but none lasted this long. I suspect Motorola has optimized the software with the imbedded extended battery for primo extended use. Have owned this phone for a few months now and have not regreted it at all. Love it.

    Rating: 5

    2012-10-01: Like any new phone with a new OS, there's a learning curve. I've been on Android for four years, and I love it, and ICS is new to me with this phone. It's made some interesting, unexpected improvements over Gingerbread. But it's still Android, and performs as such (ie, well).This review is basically about the battery. Which is insane.My last phone was a Droid X running Gingerbread. Most days I didn't need to charge my phone until I went to bed at night, but I definitely needed to charge at night. Some days I'd come home from work and my battery would be just about dead (and die before I charged it at bedtime). Some days, if I was really hammering at it, I would need to charge during the day. This had become normal for me, and was only rarely a problem.The Maxx? I mean, I use it a lot, but I can't seem to kill the battery. One night, shortly after I got it, it was down to 30 or 40 percent when I was going to bed, so I played a graphics heavy game for a while, trying to kill it. After an hour of play, I backed out of the game to check my power level-- I had barely done any damage at all. Perhaps I should have tried downloading something at the same time.Yesterday I didn't use it much-- and I had it plugged in while I was using the navigation-- and 12 hours after leaving the house I was still at 100%. Any other phone I've had would have dropped some power in the interim, from processes and whatnot, but not this.Why all phones can't do this yet is beyond me. But this is magical, and now I look at other people's Android powered phones that are down to 20% battery at the end of the day and mock them with my 60%.

    Rating: 5

    2012-02-21: I upgraded to the Razr Maxx from the HTC Droid Incredible and could not be happier. All the reasons why I am completely satisfied with this phone: Large, crystal clear display; very responsive; 4G is excellent; no dropped calls; loud and clear sound; many great pre-installed apps; swype feature on keyboard is amazing and makes texting easy and fast; numerous ringtone options, far more to choose from than previous phones; solid build; gorilla glass is wonderful; battery life is quite extensive, allowing me to charge my phone about every 4 days with normal use, and every 2 or 3 days with heavier use; connects quickly to wi-fi when in range; recent upgrade shows all settings in living color; syncs with my Xoom and PC quickly and easily; and numerous others as you will experience for yourself. All in all, I am a big fan of the Motorola Razr Maxx and would highly recommend this phone.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-26: I have had two motorola phones and two iPhones before purchasing the Droid Razr Maxx. I had the Droid X and Droid X2. Both were good phones, but battery life wasn't the greatest and I wanted something more than Gingerbread had to offer. So, from there I bought the iPhone 4 and eventually the iPhone 4S. Battery life on those wasn't the best and iOS did not have the same functionality of Ice Cream Sandwich.The Droid Razr Maxx has been my favorite smartphone to date.Pros:-Superb battery life: It easily lasts me all day. I watch a lot of video on it, so I have to charge it every night. However, I don't have to charge it midday like I had to for my iPhone 4S.-Ice Cream Sandwich: Android 4.0 running on the Maxx is one of the least customized versions of Android. The slight tweaks that Motorola has made generally improve the use of the device.-MicroSD card slot: It seems as if the microSD card slot is disappearing. It is nice to see Motorola included it on the Maxx.-Excellent Call Quality: I get excellent Verizon coverage where I live, so my device has no problem keeping connected. Calls are quite good.Cons:-Bloatware: Verizon has loaded this device with bloatware. Thankfully, most of it can be either removed or disabled.-Screen: qHD resolution is a bit disappointing coming from the retina display on the iPhone. When viewing the screen up close, you can distinguish the individual pixels. Being Super AMOLED, bright colors are very vibrant. However, some colors appear washed out, such as skin tone. In direct sunlight, the screen is barely visible even with brightness at 100%. Overall, the screen isn't the best, but it is usable.-Rear camera: Motorola's camera technology has not changed much since the Droid X. The camera takes pretty good outdoor shots, but struggles in low-light situations.Overall, the Droid Razr Maxx is a decent device. I would definitely recommend it to someone looking for a relatively low cost phone with the superb battery life. If money is not an issue, get the Droid Razr Maxx HD.

    Rating: 4

    2012-02-04: The Razr Maxx is a great phone on the fastest 4G LTE network. The phone is basically the same phone as the Droid Razr but with a massively extended battery. That's important as the battery cannot be changed out to an extended batter on the Droid Razr and this phone gets the extended battery punch but still in the same slim form factor. This is the slimmest Smartphone still.Droid Razr and Razr Maxx have:+The fastest 4G LTE network. I'll routinely get 15-20 MBPS download and sometimes even better upload. This means almost no lag, super fast downloads and instant page loads on browsers. In case you aren't in a 4G LTE area, you still get the EVDO 3G network and the 1xRTT CDMA digital calling networks.+Verizon's voice network (still the best.)+Verizon's #1 customer service (just won J.D. Power's for second straight year.)+The new battery can get you more than a full day of full usage without constant charging, unlike almost every other 4G Smartphone and many other 3G Smartphones.+If you are looking for slim this is the slimmest Smartphone out.+Water-Resistent insides and coating. You may be able to walk through light rain without worrying. (I won't do that, but you probably could with this one.)+Gorilla Glass screen is way tougher than standard glass.+32 GB memory is more than enough for a ton of app downloads and music on your device. 16 GB is on a micro-SD and you could swap that out to 32.+Dual Core 1.2 GHz processors really make a difference on running multiple apps at the same time. I can run half a dozen memory eating processes at any time and swap back and forth. I also run as many as 6 or more tabs on my browser with no slow down (either FireFox or Dolphin HD.)+Motorola's UI is clean and easy to customize. It isn't as slick as HTC's Sense UI, but it also isn't clunky like LG's UI. It gives some extras that are helpful (widgets for social networking, for instance,) without getting in the way.-Kevlar back is more for looks than useful in my opinion. Unless you're James Bond and plan on carrying 30 of these under your shirt...-The weight of the phone makes it feel cheap to me. It is super light and the material isn't solid feeling like the Droid Bionic or even an iPhone.-No Ice Cream Sandwich (yet).Some people may balk at the $300 price tag, but the phone is smarter than most people's home PCs and you'll carry it with you almost every day, every where you go. Why wouldn't you think $300 is a good value for a device like that?Overall, this is a great Droid 4G LTE phone. The battery and processors make this phone the fastest and longest lasting of the Droid devices.

    2012-02-13: I returned two samsung Galaxy nexus to finally settle down on Droid Razr Maxx.I believe everybody has different expectations from cell phones.What i liked in Droid Razr Maxx:1) Excellent batter life. It's battery is the biggest selling point-with a heavy use - almost 2.5 to 3 hr of commute it can last for at least 7-9 hours with one single charge. I am just hoping to get Android ICS update asap. ICS is far better than Gingerbread.Used it for 3 weeks now...no issues in terms of battery...last at least 8 hours with moderate to heavy use-quite satisfied...one of the reasons to return back Galaxy Nexus was due to battery drainage.I purchased chargers(Wall and Car) of Motorola Droid Razr and they are working with Motorola Droid Razr Maxx.

    2012-10-22: Bought this phone as an upgrade for my wife,after years of service from a great Blackberry Tour 9630,problem free.Read MANY reviews on MANY phones and decided to go forward with this particular model,mainly due to battery life and screen size.Phone arrived in a timely fashion,after charging only took a few minutes to get it up and running,4G is quick,as is WiFi,3G is constant and reasonably quick.
