  • B009A51Y1U

    $B009A51Y1U

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-03-15: First, the negative: this wasn't particularly easy to put on. Even after working at it for a while, two bubbles remain. They're not that large, so it isn't disrupting the experience, but it is a little disappointing.Now to the positive: I love the texture of this screen protector. It has a matte finish that gives the iPhone's screen a tactile feel that enhances the experience of using the phone. As far as the anti-glare feature, it works perfectly.Great product dragged down a bit by our difficulties putting it on.

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-16: I have used numerous screen protectors over the years some were good, others not so. This 3M was a pleasant surprise. Only one protector is in the package and it is a screen protector, reduces glare and is scratch resistant. This product is a high quality protector, with careful packaging. Videos are available online to view the application process. I have done a number of these so I did not bother with checking them. I always read the directions first. The product has two flaps with color photos and instructions which help greatly. The one protector is neatly packaged and had a longer covering that makes removing the protector much easier. Many have a protector covering that is the same size of the protector that makes it hard to see which is which. This is a great help. There is a nice, large 3M cloth used to clean your phone screen and the protector after it is applied. This is another feature that 3M offers extra. The size of most protector cloths (if included) are short and small and hard to use. This nice large size makes it easy to use. One unusual thing 3M has done regards the applicator (used to smooth the bubbles out). Most protector packages give you a plastic one, generally short. 3M includes a stiff cardboard applicator that is part of the package (open carefully!) with a blue stripe to differentiate it. Believe it or not, this still cardboard actually works better than the plastic cards for smoothing bubbles. I was able to clean my screen and apply the protector on the first try. The cutouts for the front buttons are one larger button that makes it easier to place the top section. I had a previous one on my old 4 that separated the buttons with a thin strip in between that made it much harder to place. The cardboard applicator removed all the bubbles on my 5, something I have rarely seen before. This protector does have excellent touch capacity although it does have to be cleaned, fingerprints will show on it. It feels smooth and gives a more "protective" covering than just the usual screen shield. All in all this is an excellent choice. I do recommend this product. You are able to see the screen in bright light without glare and I love the scratch resistance.

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-13: I haven't been using a screen protector, although I have tried some samples of them I got. I ended up taking them all off because I didn't like the way they looked or felt. This one is different.Pros:* easy to apply (use credit card to smooth it out)* cleaning cloth included, a nice touch* does remove all glare from any angle* feels satin smooth, excellent tactile feel* fits perfectly* reduced fingerprints on screen* three in the package* thicker than other screen protectors, less flimsyCons:* anti-glare texture very slightly reduces sharpness of screen.I don't personally feel the slight reduction in sharpness is a big enough problem to stop using this. I like how it repells dirt, dust and fingerprints, and is thick enough to be sturdy and protective. I think 3Mhas a winner with this one.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-26: All screens that have a privacy feature or glare feature certainly do take away from the original clarity of you retina display. So there is certainly a small compromise if you need to protect your eyes. Especially if you spend long hours looking at your phone, this will certainly help with the glare but don't expect the same look of clarity you'd get without it on it. It does make a scratchy sound when gliding across the screen.

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-24: The newer iPhone screens don't really scratch easy but screen protectors just give an additional layer of protection that gives some impact resistance to the glass so the screen won't shatter easily if you drop your phone.By now most have figured out how to install screen protectors.Spritz a little alcohol or glass cleaner on the surface, polish away with a soft cloth till every speck of dirt is gone, inspect under bring light to make sure, then very carefully line up the protector, peel away the bottom and align again. The start at bottom going to top slowly, every so slowly laying down the protector on the glass screen while sliding a credit card on the just laid down protector so you keep eliminating any air pockets. Slow and steady is a job well done. Then peel away the top to reveal the perfect shiny new screen with no air bubbles and protector barely visible except at the edges.However, the thinner and cheaper no-name protectors are no good and no matter how well you lay them down they bubble up or get a weird orange peel effect due to cheap adhesive layer. The 3M protector eliminates that as well as some of the glare so you can see your phone screen in brighter light. The tactile feeling is pretty good, and I'd rather take a tiny bit of loss in the tactile feeling to keep it scratch and shatter free. It also keeps off messy fingerprints. Every now and then I just spritz a tiny bit of water on it and wipe it down with a soft cloth to keep it grime free.As long as you take the time to apply it as carefully as they do in electronics store or at the mall kiosks you should get great results with this protector. Or you could bring it to one of those mall kiosks and have them apply it for you for a few bucks.

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-19: As far as screen protectors go, this one is fine. It is priced decently, fits the iPhone 5 screen perfectly, goes on easily, leaves no bubbles, and reduces glare as advertised. For those reasons I give the product five stars out of five.However, here's a word of advice for those buyers who may not have used an "anti-glare" screen protector before: You should be warned that anti-glare screen protectors inherently reduce the quality of the screen due to a matte finish, which produces a somewhat "filtered" effect. If you want something truly clear, that won't inhibit the beauty of the retina display, you may want to try3M's "clear" screen protectorinstead.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-27: Either this is a great screen cover, or I'm FINALLY figuring out how to install these things! This is the first screen protector I have ever installed on my iPhone 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 (yes, I've had all 5 major releases) that didn't involve a frustrating process of applying, removing, realigning, etc. It just worked. I may have just gotten lucky, but it seems like the material was a bit stiffer, making it easier to manipulate. Another trick is to apply the cover in a humid environment (like the bathroom with the shower running) to cut down on floating lint particles.The anti glare finish does cut down on the clarity of the screen a bit, but it does really help in bright sunlight. I also have an anti-glare screen on my Macbook, so I have grown to prefer the matte finish that doesn't attract fingerprints as readily as a gloss finish.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-31: Highly recommend these screen protectors, especially if you use your iPhone out doors a lot. I also like the added protection they add to the screen.Have used the anti glare protectors when at the beach and recently when skiing where the snow glare was really bad, yet I was able to use my iPhone with no visual disruptions.Without the anti glare protectors I had to tilt the iPhone to see what I was seeing.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-18: If you want a screen protector that reduces glare this may be the one for you. It applies the same as all protectors do - you need patience, skill, and some luck to get it nearly bubble free. But if you like a clear matte look this one delivers while reducing that outdoor glare that makes it almost impossible to see your screen.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-25: I have mixed feelings on anti-glare protectors. They seem to help a little, but they also add a very slight distortion to the screen. I'm not entirely sure if anyone's come up with a solution that doesn't do this even a tiny bit, though, so maybe it's just one of the drawbacks of this type of technology.Mostly, this seems like a good product for what it is. I'm a little bugged by the idea of 1 per package on a product where it's so easy to mess up installation. If you have a lot of experience with this type of thing, that may not make a difference since you probably have a pretty deft touch with getting it on just right. If you're new to screen protectors, though, it's tough to recommend something that'll only give you one shot.I didn't really count that against it too much in the star rating, because I figure you only end up getting to USE one protector anyway generally, so you always have the option of getting help from someone who's mastered the skill. Just take the issue into account when you're making your choice.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-18: This applied easily and didn't seem to leave a lot of bubbles. I don't love the way that it blurs my screen. However, it actually does fight the glare. If you don't mind the reduced crispness, this works well.$12 seems ridiculously high for this product.

    Rating: 3

    2013-04-09: I picked these up for my iPhone 5, hoping that it would cut down the glare of the shiny new screen during my research while on lunch fun... it does indeed, cut the glare completely, but it also adds a bit of a filmy-like look to the screen. The other downside is the noise one's finger swipes make on the screen drives me nuts. It's not overly loud- but for someone swiping in a silent room, it's very audible to nearby friends and family. The sound is a bit like what your finger on a pair of jeans sounds like- or paper. It just makes a swishy sound.It isn't any easier or harder to apply than any other screen protectors I have had so there are no pro's and con's there. It also fits well under my case/cover. I have had it on for a month now- I take several conference calls a day, run my family all over town on the weekends, and check emails and voice mails constantly. Throughout all of this it still looks like the day I put it on. If you are looking for a protector that cuts glare- this does the job without disturbing the image too much. If the noise issue is an issue for you, look for something else.

    Rating: 3

    2012-10-30: This anti-glare screen protector is better than the one that came with the iPhone 5, at least the one we were provided with. The iPhone 5 is especially bright, so it actually could use an even stronger anti-glare protector than this one, but this one is fairly decent and the best we've found thus far. It goes on fairly smoothly and for the inevitable few bubbles that appear, there is a little tab like thing that comes with it to help push those bubbles out. It is better than nothing as the iPhone 5 is way too bright on its own.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-30: This screen protector provides good anti-glare properties. It was easy to apply and I really didn't have any problems with bubbles.     Rating: 4

    2013-02-21: I actually grabbed a couple of these for my sister and I to try on our iPhones 5. Here is the important warning: when they say don't touch the adhesive strip, they're serious. She accidentally touched just a very little part of the edge, and that part does not stick. Luckily it's not enough to cause any kind of issue, but we can tell that if you touch a bit more than she did, or if you touch a more important part of the adhesive, it could cause issues. It barely shows.Otherwise, very easy installation. Mine went on without a hitch. The applicator and tab are useful for getting the screen on and getting it centered and leveled.The touch screen works 100% (which is an issue that other brands have had). It also works well with phone cases, I can't imagine a phone case that would cause problems since this screen protector is so flat.The anti-glare is amazing. It works perfectly and without any problems. I recommend this protector heartily for iPhone 5 users that might be outside a fair amount.

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-19: The main issue is whether one is able to properly apply the screen protector. A good way to do this is the opposite motion of what one would do if it were peeled off at one corner. It can be applied in the reverse of this, starting with one corner and letting it adhere slowly. If done correctly, the applicator may be unnecessary.This provides excellent protection to the screen and cuts out glare - as expected.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-19: I have an iPhone 5 that I use for work and my work is 90% outdoors. I hated having to deal with the glare. This screen protector helped a lot in reducing glare outside. Indoors glare was non-existent. Application is super easy just like all the other screen protectors. At first there are little bubbles that I was not able to get out right after installation. The next day they were gone so no need to worry. The only drawback is it adds a bit of grainy look. All the anti-glare screens I have tried, even on my laptop give you that grainy look.     Rating: 5

    2013-02-18: Easy to put on and clear screen protector. The Anti glare seems to work as stated. The touch screen sensitivity is not affected by the screen protector. How can you go wrong with items made by 3M.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-29: This is a decent screen protector. I watched the installation video and had no problem. No bubbles, no slipping. This is made to stay put yet not difficult to remove. It leaves no residue or sticky stuff.The screen image with this installed is bright and vibrant.     Rating: 4

    2012-11-12: This screen protector features a matte surface for eliminating glare. It works very well. I also like the texture of the material. I slide my finger across my iPhone very frequently. The surface of the screen protector is a big improvement over bare glass. The reason is that my finger tends to "catch" and drag on the smooth glass. It is a suction effect. With the screen protector in place, pure sliding pleasure!The screen protector is thick and stiff. This should enhance durability and perhaps even offer a bit of impact protection.The matte texture is mostly great, but it definitely degrades image quality. I would describe the effect as "a field of tiny points of light."I got lots of air bubbles. After re-applying, I got most of the bubbles to vanish, except for some edge bubbles. Those are not going away without dynamite, sadly.The cutout around the iPhone speaker is needlessly asymetrical and, um, "blobby." It looks stupid, and it made it more difficult for me to get the screen protector on straight. I simply can't understand why 3M cut out the extra "blob" of material.Lastly, there is the issue of price. Relative to other screen protectors, the price is fair. But let's be honest. It's ridiculous to pay this much money for a little slip of plastic.

    Rating: 3

    Rating: 5

    2013-03-21: The term "Screen Protector" makes you think of a thick piece of plastic that would stop the screen from shattering when you drop a rock on it. Screen protectors are actually a very thin plastic sheet which adhere to the screen. They protect the screen from light scratches if you, say, put the phone in your pocket with keys or loose change. They protect it from oil should you answer the phone after putting lotion or oil on your hands. In the process, though, they sometimes trap dust between the screen and the plastic, causing air bubbles to interfere with the appearance of the image on the screen. And sometimes they interfere with the overall image quality.In this case, 3M provides a screen cleaning microfiber cloth to use initially as well as a small piece of cardboard to be used as an applicator. Used properly, you can get the sheet on the phone without air bubbles. For this screen to be anti-glare, there's a flat coating on the sheet that degrades image quality slightly. It's not a big deal, but it's noticeable, so it becomes a glare vs image quality question. If you primarily use your phone in sunlight or under overhead lighting at work, this is a perfect solution. But if glare never bothers you, get the non-glare screen protector instead.As you apply the sheet, do so in as dust-free an area as possible. The last thing you want is for static to attract dust to the protector as you apply it. Once dust has adhered to the plastic sheet, there's no getting it off.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-04: This 3M Natural View Anti-Glare Screen Protector for iPhone 5 works great. It is easy to install and the touch screen still works with it installed.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-27: This screen protector for the iPhone is one of the best. It reduced that awful glare in bright lights while protecting your phone from finger smudges. But the best feature of this screen protector is that it allows you to slige / glide you finger easily for ultimate touch power on you phone. Great screen protector.If looking of a great cover that portects from dings tryBelkin Grip Candy Sheer Case For New Apple iPhone 5 (Purple / Blue)orBelkin Flex Case for iPhone 5 - 2 Pack (Black & Clear)it does come in other colors.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-17: This screen protector works very well, and clings well too. Not sure how long it will last though. This is starting to show signs of wear after a month, but I've had others start to fail within a week.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-05: Screen protectors as a category are things I do not generally rave about. While I think these are quite good, I won't rave about thwem either (generally saving that for things which really make me happy). That said,these do not make me unhappy, as some others have. At this point I have purchased a dozen or more screen protectors for the various devices in our house and find that the 3m screen protectors are the best of the bunch. They go on easily, do not leave a nasty residue (like sonme I have tried) and are comparatively thick and durable. They are better than most at deterring fingerprints and also cut glarwe (an issue here in the tropics).Time was my biggest issue with screen protectoras was the cost (given that it is a little bit of plastic film,) but having used several generic screen preotectors as well as a few brand name, have to say that some are better than others. Among the various brands which I have tried, I find 3m to be about the best. They may not have you turbning cartwheels,but likely won't leave you frurated and angry either, and will do a pretty good job of keepibng your screen in good shape.Now I want to find a set of these for my camwera, since the LCD screen can be hard to see in the sun (and the screen protector which I am currently using doesn't do as good a job as these of cutting glare. It's a little thing which can make a big difference if you spend a lot of time outside, and an upgrade I can make without breaking the bank ;)

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-17: I'm not generally a big fan of screen protectors... I've never had much luck getting them installed without bubbles or getting them lined up perfectly square.However, I want to start running with my iPod which means it is going to be subjected to more abrasive conditions than my phone is usually subjected to.The screen protector is fairly thick and I get the sense that it will provide good protection. Installation is pretty typical for screen protectors -- if you are really lucky, you'll get it lined up correctly. They provide a "cardboard" piece to try to remove the bubbles but that piece is pretty worthless. Your standard plastic loyalty card from the grocery store is more effective.The biggest problem is that this does cause the display to be "crystallized" -- so the beautiful crisp display that Apple has spent so much time and technology developing and for which you have probably plunked down HUGE bucks has just been reduced to something with the clarity of a blackberry from the 1990s.If you use your phone to watch videos or anything that is higher def than email, then you will be disappointed with this protector. However, if you just want to keep the screen from getting hacked up and you don't worry the screen clarity, this will do the job...[NCJVR]

    2013-03-07: I'd prefer running around without a screen protector, as they don't feel right, my kid always pull the edges up and dust gets in there. However, my poor old iPhone 4 was scratched into premature age by occasionally sharing a pocket with a key. So this time, I'm being more careful. However, given the choice, I still prefer glossy versus anti-glare protectors as anti-glare has the problem of making everything a bit pebbly in its appearance and having a noticeable finger texture.Installation went quickly and without incident. There's a large cut out for the front facing camera, the earpiece speaker and the proximity sensor, so there is some leeway in putting the sheet down not quite perfectly. I squeegeed air out easily enough leaving a bubble free interior.Finger feel is not bad; something like satin, and the visual appearance is not as grainy as other screen protectors I've seen.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-04: If you are looking for a good screen protector, anti-smudges or fingerprints and is easy to apply, this is the one to get. Applying the screen is simple, the same way I applied the privacy screen for another iPhone 5 (in another review):1. Clean your screen with some alcohol based paper such as eyeglasses cleaning pad.2. Wipe the screen dry with the supplied cloth.3. Peel half of screen off, align the home button hole and press to the end.4. Press the air bubles out with the edge of a credit card.If you miss it the first time, you can peel it off and reapply. I had a couple tries before I got it right and it works well. The screen sure cut down a lot of glare out in the sun. But it also makes the screen less vibrant. But I think I will get used to it over time.

    2013-02-07: This is the third screen protector I've gotten for my iPhone, and so far, it's the best!The first was a generic three-pack, which was ok, but the film was so flimsy that it was hard to keep bubbles out. The second was horrible--it was the kind that makes the screen impossible to read from the sides to protect privacy (I nearly went blind with how grainy it made things look). This screen protector has the best overall score:Clarity: 3 starsThere is a bit of fuzziness added to the screen, sort of like a haze, that takes away from the retina display. It is not so bad that reading text is impaired, so it's not a logistical problem so much as an aesthetic one.Texture: 5 starsSome slick screen protectors almost feel sticky and can sort of catch on your fingers as you slide them across the screen. This one has a feel similar to the kindle display--almost papery, very smooth--no catching or sticking.Glare: 5 starsIt really does reduce glare! Great if you plan on using your phone outdoors.Application Process: 4 starsThis screen protector is a little thicker than the cheap ones, which makes it easier to install. The cleansing cloth helps get rid of some static, but for some reason, there's always a bit of a charge to the phone and to the SP. Some dust always manages to get in. Also, most kits come with a plastic or hard cardboard thing to push bubbles out. It's not a big deal--I just used a credit card, but I thought it would come with that. It went fine, though. No bubbles!

    2013-01-29: First off, I tried to be as careful as possible when applying this 3M Anti-Glare Screen Protector, but even then I was not able to prevent a few small bubbles from appearing in the middle of the iPhone. Fortunately these tiny bubbles are not visible unless the phone background is black (typically only when it is turned off).However, I don't like the way the anti-glare protector makes the screen slightly fuzzy, especially noticeable with white. Similar to computer screens, there is a tradeoff between the clearness / sharpness of the screen and it's susceptibility to glare - any film / coating / treatment meant to reduce glare is also going to reduce the sharpness of the display a bit. Since I've had no issues with glare on my iPhone 5 up to now, this screen doesn't really fix anything for me and reduces the quality of the iPhone 5 Retina display.I also want to agree with other reviewers that 3M should have included at least two protectors in the package, if for no other reason than it is so easy to mess up the application and having a second protectors as a backup would be nice. It seems liek the price charged for the single protector provided is *very* high.Now if glare is a real problem with your iPhone, this may work out for you. But if you're looking just for protection without an anti-glare treatment, perhaps the3M Natural View NV827748 Screen Protector for iPhone 5 - Clearmay be a better choice.Edit - since I first wrote this I tried out the3M Natural View NV827748 Screen Protector for iPhone 5. I was never able to test that one out, as I could not apply it without multiple bubbles under the surface of the film. There really seems to be an issue with applying these 3M screen protectors, and I cannot recommend them when they have proven to be so horribly difficult to apply properly.

    2013-02-22: 3M typically makes high quality products and this anti glare screen protector is no exception. It's good for glare and goes on without too much fussing.The good parts:- the plastic is just the right amount of stiffness to apply easily and not give me a nightmare of bubbles to deal with. The really limp screens by other companies have bubbles galore, and are hard to line up on the iphone screens. This is the point of the product, so full marks on that.- the touch screen on the phone works very well with the protector applied- the plastic protects the glass on my phone.Less good:- the matte surface really cuts down the pristine screen resolution of the iPhone. Not a plus.RECOMMENDATIONIf you are outside a lot, this Is a good 3M screen protector that allows you to actually use your phone in comfort.     Rating: 5

    2013-02-21: I've been using smart phones since their inception, and I have NEVER liked screen protectors. Nor have I ever liked them on my tablets, whether Windows based Tablet PC's or other things like my iPads or Kindles. They generally serve no purpose for me, since I don't have a habit of getting scratches on devices. Fingerprints are easy to wipe off with a microfiber cloth, and more often than not even if there are no bubbles under the film when you apply it, it seems there ends up being some at some point anyway. So for a couple decades now, going back to even just the first old PDA's, I've avoided them.I saw this one in the Vine program and decided to give it a try more for the anti-glare properties than anything else. I figured worst case scenario I'd pull it off.When I installed it, I had the typical frustration of some bubbles, no matter how carefully I was applying it and using a straight edge to help keep it on there. So far, just like any other protector. But with some judicious wrangling, I was able to get it on with only a couple bubbles out to the edges of the screen, none in the middle. And even just using a fingernail, I was able to push them out. And unlike most other protectors, they didn't reappear.The material is a bit thicker and stiffer than most I've used, and has a slightly rough feel to it, very different from the feel of the smooth glass. On my Macbook Pro computer, I LOVE the glass trackpad, and even though I use palm protectors on them, I never put a protector on the trackpad, as the feel and smoothness of it is one of the things that first drew me away from PC's. But despite that, I find I now prefer this feel on my iPhone for some reason. It just feels better to me. I don't use gestures on the iPhone like I do on the laptop, so the slightly rougher surface isn't a hinderance at all.The anti glare works pretty well, but it's not a total solution for glare since in some situations you just end up with a duller flat white spot rather than a glaring reflection, but that's pretty much when you position yourself using it as a mirror to an extremely bright light source, which isn't something people generally do when they're using these anyway. So for the most part, it does help improve visibility of the device, without any notable detraction in lower light situations. It also preserves a great wide angle viewability although you can notice some dimming at extreme angles.I use it with a case and it didn't cause any issues with getting the case on or off. The cut is about as perfect as I've ever seen, it fits exactly as it needs to, with the cutout for the home button and one for the top by the microphone and camera (and a cut to one side, for the ambient light sensor I assume).The only downside I've seen is bits of dust or pocket lint likes to gather around the edge of the protector by the home button, nothing that a brush of a finger or blowing at it won't dislodge.All in all I'm pretty impressed with it, compared to my history with this kind of product. I'm actually keeping it on the phone, something I hadn't really anticipated I'd end up doing.Edit December 2013 - after 6 months or so this started getting pretty awful looking around the edges. And it's not even the edges where you'd think maybe something caught it and started to separate, but around the ear piece speaker as well. Just dust and such that got under there and gummed up the exterior edge about a quarter inch from all the edges. Oddly enough the bottom half of the unit was totally unaffected by this, just the top half and around the cutout for the ear speaker. I ended up pulling it off and have my phone going commando again as far as screen protectors go.

    Rating: 4

    2013-03-24: I have always been a proponent of a screen protector film. When my iPhone 5 came along, I immediately set out to provide the highest level of screen protection available. I decided to give this product a try.Once you've cleaned your screen very carefully, the application of this protector is straightforward, though I haven't had ANY luck applying these things in the past. But this one went on just fine without bubbles, using just a credit card. It did seem to unsharpen the screen a tiny bit, which I have not seen with other screen protectors.Overall though, I am pleased with the protection this screen protector provides. To me, it is worth it if the protector saves you from just one scratch over the life of your phone. 3M is a brand I trust and this product seems to be of high quality. I would buy it again, but I would also spend some more time researching alternatives that are perhaps more clear.

    2013-04-09: The thing I hate most about anit-glare screen protector is the granularity it presents.     2013-02-06: I received three 3M screen protectors to review: the standard one, this anti-glare one, and the "privacy" one. I started with the standard one, and really didn't care for it much. Then, I moved on to this one, and I actually very much like it.First, I guess I should say that I generally don't care for screen protectors at all, as 1. they rarely go on without getting tiny pieces of lint/dust under them, no matter how careful you are, and 2. they don't feel right. Some of them make the phone's screen seem to stop responding correctly, or they feel filmy or streaky. The standard 3M one felt a little streaky and seemed to have something on it that rubbed off after just a few hours of usage. Not horrible, but I didn't like it near enough to keep it on my phone.So then I moved on to this anti-glare one, and I like it much better. As they mention in the description, it has a silky, kind of satin feel to it. When you look at it, it almost looks cloudy, though it doesn't look that way when you turn the phone on. It doesn't negatively affect the screen at all. And, despite my expectations, it actually feels very nice to use. They call it a "smooth touch", and it does feel smooth. It doesn't affect the screen's performance at all that I can notice, and it actually does cut down on glare. I've never noticed any particular glare on this (or any other) iPhone in the first place, but I must say that I notice a bit LESS of it with this protector on (if that makes sense). That is, once I got this on my phone, I noticed that I can turn it any direction and I don't see a glare with it...hadn't realized that I had made those tiny, subconscious adjustments previously, until I had this screen protector on and didn't have to make them.Your mileage may vary, but this screen protector actually has a chance of staying on my phone for a while...the first screen protector I've ever said that about.

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-25: I understand that this is the anti-glare product. I didn't really like the feel and look of it after I've applied it. I like the clear screen protector much better. It feels much more transparent and not noticeable every time I use it.

    Rating: 3

    2012-12-02: Unlike the iPad screen, this is dead easy to put on. It took my spouse less than five minutes to slip the screen on my phone--compared to fifteen for the iPad.Having the screen on definitely decreases glare particularly in daylight. I don't notice visibility decreasing in lower light, either.Best yet, it's easy to finger scroll around on the screen.Overall, a very good product and I think an enhancement to the iPhone 5.Rebecca Kyle, December 2012

    Rating: 5

    2013-03-26: The 3M Anti-Glare Screen Protector is a nice screen protector for the iPhone 5.Pros: Easy to apply. Close fit. No glare. Less smudging from fingers. Comes with a cleaning cloth.Cons: Screen protector surface is a strange texture that while stops the glare, takes away a bit from the quality of the display. A bit expensive for only 1 screen protector.

    Rating: 4

    2013-01-18: I'm a bit of an expert applying these types of things. I worked at the Apple Retail Store for nearly 5 years and I have probably put these types of films on at least 100 phones over the years... and I'd say these are really good films and do the job if properly applied. Let me share some tips to make this a great fit for your phone. It is crucial that dogs, cats, or any pet that bears fur or feathers be in another room and that children are not running around during the installation of the film. If you have any fans (oscillating, ceiling, etc.), make sure they are off and have stopped turning completely. Turn off the heat and/or air conditioning. Seriously - it's just for a few minutes - you need to have ZERO air movement. The air we breath is FULL of tiny, barely perceptible amounts of dust and lint hanging in near suspension in the air. As long as you stop the circulation of air, these particles begin to settle a bit. The little fibers and debris you can barely see in the air are magnified 50x the minute they get under the film. Once all air movement has settled down, it's time to prepare the phone. It should be removed from the case and cleaned thoroughly by applying an appropriate electronics cleaning fluid like iClean to a microfiber cloth. Never spray fluid onto your phone! Apply the fluid on the cloth and vigorously wipe and clean it, and examine under a bright light to make sure there are no fibers there. When you are ready to apply the film, be sure no part of your finger even grazes the edge of it - or your finger grease will be there - just enough to make the film peel back after time. Use the non-sticky backing of the film to help you line up the edges. Apply at one edge and very slowly peel it down toward the glass to avoid air bubbles. If a bubble is visible, pull back a bit and try again. Patience is key. Also - limit your breathing to slow, measured breaths - you can exhale debris right onto the sticky surface or onto your iPhone glass. Even though the films are cut precisely for an iPhone 5, you cannot just try aligning it using the corner. During the whole process, you should be watching the hole for the home button and the ear speaker to make sure everything is lining up and that it is not askew. Once applied properly, the film is secure. Your finger won't slide quite as smoothly as it does across bare glass, but it won't leave discernable fingerprints unless you were just eating fried chicken. It takes away the glare and the annoyance of greasy finger prints occluding the view of the icons, your photos, etc. Nice product.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-26: Overall, this is a quality product. It is cut to fit the iPhone 5, is sturdy, and enables you to still use the touch screen as if there is no cover on it. The anti-glare feature also works well, though glare wasn't something that was a particular problem for me. Most importantly, this product will protect your screen.It did take me several tries to get the protector on the phone without bubbles and even after multiple attempts, there are a few small bubbles that I can't seem to remove. I wish I had read the other reviews prior to installing this screen protector as several reviews offer helpful tips - be sure the phone is extra clean. This product comes with a cloth to clean the phone before installation - definitely use it. Also, read the instruction on the package and follow them in order.

    Rating: 4

    2013-01-24: If you can get this on yourself without bubbles, kudos to you. I got most of them but there were still a few tiny ones that annoyed me and I ended up taking this off. I did use it for a few days and it worked well, but the bubbles drove me insane.

    Rating: 4

    2012-11-13: It has a little bit of roughness to the surface as part of the anti-glare feature.When sliding a finger across the surface, you can actually hear the little bit of friction it creates, as a soft "swoosh: sound. The texture of the cover is evident when looking at something that is mostly white. It appears to put a slight "shadow" on the screen. Not enough to not use it.There is still a little glare to it, but it reduces glare pretty well.I had to get used to how it felt, having that little bit of roughness. If you are sensitive to textures, you may not like it.

    Rating: 4

    2013-04-17: The screen protector was very easy to put on and feels thick like it will really work. After a few days most of the bubbles under it went away so I have no complaints about this. The anti-glare is subtle but I can definitely tell a difference from my basic screen protector before.

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-09: This provides a decent amount of glare protection, goes on easily, and isn't too noticeable as an addition to the phone screen. Tapping isn't hindered at all. Of note, it does dull some colors, especially at the edges. And text especially won't be as crisp. But this has been the nature of all anti glare protects that I have used in the past.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-13: As expected of a 3M product, the screen protector is well-made and thicker than the average screen protector, which I believe will add to the overall durability of the product. With a little patience, the screen protector adhered nicely to the screen of my iPhone without any air bubbles. The screen protector TRULY does eliminate glare, but at the same time gives the letters and images a somewhat blurry or grainy appearance. The jury is still out on whether or not I like losing the high definition appearance in return for anti-glare. The product does what it promises to do, but it also has a negative impact on the quality of the images on your iPhone.

    Rating: 3

    2013-01-31: The quality on this is good to a degree, but it gives this hazy, grainy look that takes away from everything. Its like sacrificing quality for a little more protection and that's not really my thing

    Rating: 3

    2013-02-18: This works just like it said it would: easy to put on without bubbles, easy to remove, looks good, fits my iPhone perfectly. I expected the screen to be a little more fuzzy, as that is the nature of the anti-glare. It really does improve reading it in bright sunlight, so I am happy. Overall, a good product.

    Rating: 4

    2013-01-30: The antiglare material leaves the phones images to look a little grainy. It's definitely not crystal clear. It does provide some glare protection but the overall appearance isn't worth it to me. I much prefer the clear protector 3M offers.This cover is much thicker than many other protectors on the market. Instead of the traditional 3 ply installation method, it's only two pieces. A backing that is much larger than the protector and the protector itself. I like that better because I always had the protector pull off the screen when I moved the third ply with that method.The thickness of the protectors allows you to pull it back up and reposition it if needed.There is no "drag" when swiping the screen with this cover.Overall Im pleased with it.

    Rating: 3

    2013-02-04: This isn't a clear piece of plastic. If you hold it up and look through it, the images are completely diffused. This is how it acts as an anti-glare screen...reflections are diffused, but the screen image passes through it with minimal (not zero) diffusion. With a normal resolution screen, the added fuzziness wouldn't be very noticeable. With a Reina display, it is. Personally, I find the sacrifice in crispness to be unacceptable. Does it work? Yes. Will I keep it on my phone? No.

    Rating: 2

    2013-01-24: This is one of the easiest protectors I've installed, but watching 3M's video helped immensely. (The video runs under 4 minutes, saves you much more time in possible grief - the web site is in the printed instructions). No bubbles on my first try. Love the anti-glare, no fingerprint feature. Fits perfectly.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2014-01-15: Should have known. I started out thinking that the cheap ends on these cables maybe just weren't making solid contact because my phone wouldn't gain any noticeable charge, even overnight. However, I ended up downloading an app that tells you how much power your phone is getting from a charger and ended up throwing all 10 of these in the trash (with a couple of old chargers that weren't up to snuff)The charger that came with my phone and good cable feeds my phone about 1900 milliamps - these only allow between 200 and 350 milliamps to pass.Trust me - take a pass on these.

    Rating: 1

    2014-05-16: I tested this with some AC adapters and some PCs both on a Samsung Galaxy Note 2 and a Galaxy S5. Through an AC adapter, its throughput is ridiculously low: less than 400 mA. Through a USB port, just above 400mA. Bear in mind here that most AC adapters with USB cords plugged in will push 1,400-1,600 mA (1.4 to 1.6 amps) through to the phone. This is enough to trickle charge a phone which isn't being used, but if you're actually making calls, using data etc., the phone will use more power than is being received and will actually die while on the charger.Syncing works though I doubt these are USB 2 capable. Like I said, emergency trickle charge while phone isn't in use would be the best use for this, so stocking stuffers, throwing this in a shaving kit or glove compartment might work, but don't depend on it.

    Rating: 2

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2014-03-18: scroll down for updates to this postYou do the math, total battery power is going to be near 6kah (2.3+3.5)Because the case is adding a battery to the mix, you don't lose anything from your original battery, and can focus on having juice for the whole day.edit:this is going to be a long and updating review and opinion. while it may have qwirks, i still like this thing and cant find a valid reason to not.dont forget to give it a good charge before first full outing with it. yes, you can charge it while its unplugged from the phone. this case was worth the wait for me. will update with any other things down the road if i feel its neededa side note, its odd that there is a 1 inch area next to the camera that is unused, but it also seems to offer a place to plug in there, am i thinking that ZL may have a booster battery pack or wireless option there, time will tell. maybe when they offer standalone replacement batteries for this case.have not had a change to test the thermal retention (getting hot) of the case, but i will do that with a probe soon and post my findings if i see it being an issue. it doesnt feel too warm while its charging._____first impressions_____see below for updates that i will continue to addThe good:-Its a brick that feels nice in the hand and frankly better to grip and firmly hold-Rounded corners for those that have death grips on their phone-Heavy duty looking Screen protector that is built into the case is removable, be sure to clear out residual glue when taking it off.-Special dongle that connects the battery to phone is removable in those special cases, but may require something like a chip extractor , you'll see .-Speaker and mic are now directed forward.-buttons are VERY sensitive/responsive (kinda bad for me)-it does in fact seem to charge the phone first before taking power for the pack.The bad (or me just being nit-picky)(i already expected most of these):-Case does not block camera, it does however create slight ***shadowing of the flash*** on the bottom corners-Screen protector is thick but does not interfere much with the one you may already have on your N5, for now, I recommend removing it anyway (see above).-it appears that is does not have a ADB/USB passthru with battery pack in use, but thats why the dongle is removable i guess (i recommend setting up wireless ADB and playing around with android FTP servers (ES file explorer) if you dont want to remove things from the case for everyday use or transfers)-wireless charging is no longer possible, but thats expected, maybe a battery will be offered that will allow this down the road.-Charges as a USB plugged device. (this as far as i know is a technical limitation of charging from something that has power passthru. ) it may play havoc with my multi hour ingress jaunts, but i should just turn off the screen every now and then. also, it should keep the phone from getting too hot while charging, (see above), so thats a good.----update 1: if you want to get maximum life and use from the batteries , do not keep the pack on when you know the phone is sitting idle. it is my observation that keeping the battery pack on all of the time causes the phone to think its connected to permanent power source, and seems to keep the phone in a higher power state. this shows for all other battery packs, and is the design of all phones that i know.the charge lights stay blinking when when you know the phone and pack are fully charged, theory is because the pack has to maintain the charge of itself, and the phone (passthru) so it indicates there is still a charge going into them. hopefully (and apparently ) it reduces down to a trickle charge. also, as the pack is in use, the lights continue to blink, the LED's in the pack are only using mA's of power, but its not entirely necessary to be always on (unlike many external battery packs that turn off their lights after a few sec.----update 2 (2014-04-22): im only a few min. into the second purchase of this battery pack (1 month later),they have made the battery act more like other external packs, the lights do not stay on while in use, also, it seems to show you about how much is in the battery while the battery pack itself is charging. some minor updates to this battery, now if we could get an even larger battery that will fill the gap next to the camera id keep buying one each month. still waiting for battery only option since you can get the coloured cases separate

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-04: Received the order today, very satisfied and works perfect, exactly as described, may still early to say perfect but the fact it's superb, little bulky but this what you expect when carry a case included super power battery in it :)

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-28: I got this because the amount of time I would spend on my phone really took a toll on a batteries charge. This case will just about completely recharge your battery. My main draw back is that it is extremely bulky and the case does not fit the best in the world. The rubber/silicone cover is semi hard and not really flexible. This make the cover feel cheap. Buttons are hard to interact with through the cover. The built in screen protector interferes with the way the screen reacts to your touch. I took mine off, it is held in place by a double sided tape. If looks and feel are not important to you and the added battery life is then I would give this a try. If they are important to you I would stay away.

    Rating: 3

    2014-06-23: In reality, this is a 2.5 star product. I don't get that option on Amazon, and I'm an optimist. You're welcome, Zerolemon.SUMMARYIf you're looking for overkill protection AND a way to mitigate the Nexus 5's most significant short-coming (battery life), this is a great way to get it done for a reasonable price. Granted, I'd like to see instructions (not just better instructions, but ACTUAL instructions) regarding proper battery operation. I almost sent this back because I thought I had a bad battery because I didn't know what I was doing, and be prepared to sort out the proper protocol for your specific battery. This irritates me because I'm tech savvy and it took me a while to figure it out. It would be impossible for someone unfamiliar with these things, and that's bad for business.See you later 1 star: customer service starts from the moment the end user opens the product, and shame for leaving some of them puzzled. I imagine a lot of returns have happened because people can't figure out how to operate the battery, leading them to believe it's defective.Understand that this will make your Nexus 5 about three times it's girth, but I don't mind. It actually makes the phone more stable and comfortable to use, especially when moving through crowds and in the car. The little grippy texture on the sides is a major bonus. Yeah: this is a huge case, but guess what: if you're concerned about skinny jeans compatibility, buy a purse. Seriously. Skinny jeans are girl pants.Overall, I recommend this product to anyone.THE GOOD:Better build quality than my last Otterbox's hard plastic shell, though I would like to see a little more squish to the TPU outer-cover. The built-in screen cover is as good as Otterbox, or at least no worse. The fit and finish around the buttons is excellent; they're actually easier to use than a naked case.The battery gives me a solid 1.5 charges before it geeks, and charges at a current sufficient to increase my phone's charge while using it as a mobile hotspot.Also, kudos to Zerolemon for offering pass-thru charging. This is a great feature that only charges the external battery once the main phone is 100%. At that point, it trickle charges it while charging the backup. Some have mentioned that pass-thru doesn't work when the external battery is on. Why would you ever want to do that? Dumb dumb dumb.It also looks good clipped to the strap of my jump bag. I no longer work in EMS and SAR, but old habits die hard. I use a Maxpedition Tactical attaché (which rocks) when lugging the field content capture gear for my PR firm. This thing makes an otherwise unassuming murse-strap look tough. Kind of. What can I say: I'm a boot-fit kind of guy.THE WHO CARES:I noticed that the battery is positionally sensitive to causing interference. If I lay it screen down, my phone's data speeds slow and my hotspot becomes somewhat unreliable (unless I have more than twwo bars coverage). If I lay it screen up, all those problems go away and it functions just fine. I haven't noticed any issues with phone reception during normal usage.Also, the jumper is a little difficult to get out while everything is cased up if you're pulling it out with your finger nails. Don't use your finger nails. I carry a knife at all times: another habbit from my public service days. There are ridges, and you just use a little leverage after getting the blade positioned adequately. No problem.Other people have commented that they need deeper than normal mini USB cables to charge or access anything physically. This is a load. Every single USB cable will get in the holes I need them in, and the same goes for OTG. It would interfere with an OTG dock that fits close to the phone, but I've never been satisfied with any of the ones I've used. Cable and port access is fine.THE CONFUSING:Charge time on this battery is excessive. My Nexus 5 will charge from 4% to 100% in roughly 3 hours. This has about 1.5 times the capacity, however when both batteries are geeked, it takes more than 10 hours to charge both my phone and this pack to 100%. To me, it would appear it should only take 8hrs to do the job. What gives?THE BAD:First of all, the biggest detriment to this case is the complete absence of operation instructions. Yes, there are instructions on how to install your phone and the external battery, but a caveman could figure that out with ANY case. How about the battery's usage, which is the primary reason ANYONE would buy this?I've found that I need to press down on the battery button in a specific place with specific pressure for a few seconds to get the level lights to come on. THEN I need to press and hold again (you'll figure out that you have to bottom out the button) in order to kick on the charging. Sometimes it blinks for a few moments. Sometimes it doesn't. I'm just glad it doesn't blink constantly while charging.The reason I'd like to see a little more squish and flex to the TPU is because the port covers on this case are difficult to operate at times (I'm also getting older and less dextrous- thanks keyboards).Also, in my opinion, there is WAAAAAAY too much of the face exposed when in the case. The screen protector extends all the way down the Nexus 5. I imagine this is to allow the notification light to be visible, but there are better ways to incorporate that. This is a borderline "who cares?", but it does compromise the protection, if only slightly.Another thing that compromises the overall feel of quality is the belt clip. It holds the phone fine and looks okay, it also offers great stability and protection. However, the rotation of the clip itself leaves a lot to be desired: it moves way too easily. Maybe this is to make it more comfortable when changing positions during the day, but it makes it flop around when strapped to my bag, which is my primary carry method when on the go.I may be old school, but I'm a speakerphone guy. I hate bluetooth headsets. One: I'm not landing aircraft or calling in air strikes. Two: It doesn't matter what I'm working or, or for who: nothing I have to conduct over the phone requires that kind of urgency. Three: call quality sucks over bluetooth. Regardless how much you spend, it's only a matter of time before it degrades to unusable.This case renders speakerphone inoperable by creating a constant feedback loop due to 1) how the Nexus 5 designed its speaker/mic ports, 2) Zerolemon failing to mold in a divider between the mic and speaker grills in its case. Honestly, this is a fault of LG and Google in the design of the Nexus 5, but Zerolemon is supplying the aftermarket bits for it: they need to engineer a work around.In the mean time, I have to look at my bluetooth graveyard to find an acceptable device to use when I'm at the desk or in bed. I hate bluetooth for comms, but I'm even less of a fan of holding a microwave up to my head... especially when the case makes it the size of the 1969 phone in Men in Black 3.JUST END IT ALREADY:Yes: I'd like to see slightly better tactile impressions with better TPU. Yes, the instructions don't just suck, they're absent. Yes, the battery is a little confusing and slow to charge (time will tell if it's due to defect). Yes, there are other issues.However, when weighing the positives and negatives, I can easily recommend this product as it achieves all its objectives reasonably well. The instructions are an easy fix, and with them this would be a very good to excellent product. Buy it. Abuse it. Enjoy it.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-26: The case that comes with this battery is ridiculous.First of all, it breaks several of the Nexus 5's features:- Wireless charging of the internal battery does not work.- NFC does not work.- There's an unnecessary clear plastic layer over the screen that significantly decreases the screen's sensitivity.- The headphone port is made to be recessed by 3/4 of an inch so most headphones and accessory cables can't be plugged in.- The case recesses the camera and flash so you get blurring and fogging in your pictures.It is huge, cumbersome and difficult to put the phone into and take it out of.It does not fit into any car smartphone holder.It is actually 3 cases combined.There is a case you put the phone into, which goes inside another case, which goes inside a third case that has a gigantic belt clip on it.Like all Zero Lemon batteries this one has to be fully charged and discharged five or six times before it will hold a full charge.So in summary, the case that comes with this battery reduces your shiny new Nexus 5 to an android phone from 5 years ago.

    Rating: 3

    2014-06-13: The product works but is bulky. It makes the phone heavy. As a battery it's good but the feel and weight are a no no for me. I stuck it on the shelf.

    Rating: 3

    2014-06-18: I am a heavy data user, and can go almost 18 hours without having to plug thephone in. Lots of available power! Phone looks and feels like a brick but I'm willing to accept that for the utility of power. I do like the rubber protective case and screen cover. Reminds me of an Otterbox defender. Since they've chosen not to support this phone, I had to look elsewhere. This was a good find!

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-02: I purchased the case/holster bundle previously, but broke the clip on the holster, so I needed a replacement. The holster is great. If you have the Seidio Active case, this works nice. It holds the phone tight, pivots so you can have it horizontal or vertical, and the phone won't slip out.The only reason I didn't give it five stars is because the clip is plastic. It's really a good clip, and works well, but if you are someone who works in an environment where you can bump into things (like I do), running into something (like a wall or door frame) might break the clip. I'd love to find a holster where the clip hings was metal, just for durability. That says more about me and how I use it than an actual defect in the product. Under normal circumstances, it is quite durable and should last a long time.

    2013-04-19: I have bought Seidio cases and holsters for about 5 years and 3 phones now. Love their cases. The second one occurred after 2 years of use (out of warranty), but the latest one occurred after just 3 months of use -- no drops, no abuse. I might start looking for a different holster option. In the meantime, I need a case for my phone so here I am ordering another one because I know I can get it in 2 days via Amazon Prime, and then I'll probably play the warranty replacement game for a couple months. It just seems like they have a bit of a design weakness on their clips, but they're still the best cases and holsters I've found.

I also use invisheild and this doesnt make it bubble up. I have tried some other cheap front shields that have bubbled with this so you might wanna watch for that. Very easy to put together. It never comes apart unless you need it to. I pull the buttom off everynight before bed to put the phone on my ihome and every morning it slides right back together with no losening or anything like that. Stay tight.

    Rating: 5

    2010-06-12: Case is a nice red color and seems to be good construction. One thing I noticed is the opening around the charging connector is a little thicker than my last case and not as smooth, which makes it a bit harder to hold.

    Rating: 4

    2012-04-07: I liked this case. Had it on my phone for a few months. Then one day I noticed these weird lines that looked like veins. It started getting worse until I could see that the red layer on the outside of the case was shriveling up exposing a grey/silvery base. It was not exposed to extraordinary temperatures. This is not a case for a Florida summer. Maybe just a winter. It was attractive til the shriveling started though.

    2009-11-24: This is a very good case. Love the felt inside, phone slides in really smoothly. The only problem I had with this is the logo.     Rating: 4

    2010-01-11: Very smooth and sleek case that provides excellent protection from scratches and also has an inner layer of padding on the back that keeps the inside of the iPhone from being scratched from the case itself (unlike the iMorphe battery case). Plus the colors are just soooooooo cool!

    Rating: 5

Some of it got scraped away so don't put it in your pocket with your keys or other objects capable od scratching it. The red will wear a little around the edges but it still looks good.

It looks almost EXACTLY like the classic Game Boy I used to play back in high school down to the most remarkable detail.All holes for the headphone jack, volume buttons, speakers and charger are perfectly placed and I am MORE than a little impressed with the coverage that wraps all the way around to the border of the front screen!My only tiny complaint is that I would like the rubber to be the *slightest* bit thicker, as right now it's a pretty floppy material with a bit more extra "give" when it could possibly be a tighter fit.However, overall I am extremely happy with this cute little novelty protective rubber case.     2012-03-07: This is a reeeaallly cool case! I've gotten lots of "ooh is that a gameboy?" and "thats cool" comments with it, and i've barely had it a week.     2012-04-26: This case was very appealing to me since I have been a fan of gameboy since it debuted, and for only a couple dollars I decided why not! First of all the shipping took place from China so don't expect to receive the case in under a week. So about the case...The case is a simple semi-thick silicone case (much like the cheap silicone cases from ebay, amazon, etc). You can clearly see the seam from the machine, but again it was only 2 dollars. The gameboy detail is actually very well made, I originally assumed that it might be a print, but actually there are raised buttons and "gameboy screen". This case fits well and all ports and openings are accessible. However, the camera cut out provides a lot of flash back, and the long sides seem to be stretched out. All in all for two dollars it's a fun case to have and show your friends, also will provide adequate protection when having a night out on the town.

    2012-12-21: I won't be looking for another case for my Nexus 4.This case provides excellent grip, thank God I haven't had to test its durability but I feel better having this over the gel case I had while waiting for this one to arrive. I was pleasantly surprised by the button locations; they feel like natural extensions of the Power and Volume Rocker. I don't find myself having a hard time locating or pressing the button locations at all, they're also safely tucked at a lower level than then harder outer plaster shell so they're protected from potential side impact.This case also lends itself to coalescence with a fitted screen protector like the Skinomi I installed last night while the gel I had didn't at all–heck I didn't even attempt installing the Skinomi skin until this case came in!The MicroUSB and MiniJack audio openings aren't fit for a particular size and that's a really good thing. I see only later MicroUSB chargers have a slimmer connector while the older ones we have around the apartment have wider ones and this case facilitates them. The same for the MiniJack audio connector. Have a pair of headphones with a slightly wider plug? I'm sure it would fit.The dot pattern in back, whether an intentional design for utility or not, has its utility; it helps provide a super snug fit for the entire device and actually helps applying without much adjustment. It was easier to put on than the Ballistic case I last had.

    2010-07-15: Want an upscale looking genuine leather, lambskin no less, Blackberry Curve holder? There are quite a few to choose from and, in the extreme, some sport designer names and prices that near 3 digits. If you want the same upscale look and quality at a ridiculous price under $10 then I am pretty sure this is about your only choice. And what a good choice it is. This thing just reeks of quality and its only sin is it is a bit delicate due to being made of lambskin which can be marred in appearance due to abrasion. Lambskin is luxurious, however, and feels so rich and supple...Lambskin is also a strong leather as it has good elasticity and tensile strength for the same size and weight vs. cowhide. In other words cowhide as light and thin as lambskin tends to have less tensile strength and splits sooner (I am a shoe retailer and a third generation shoe repairer so I am around leather on a daily basis). So, this Blackberry Curve holder is excellent and the clip is very versatile as it rotates in no less than 6 locked positions, it is a screaming bargain...I don't know how they do quality like this at this price??? Oh well, the buyer wins so just get it.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2010-07-21: I was initially delighted when this case arrived! The leather is of excellent quality and is butter-soft. The stitching is perfect and gives it a stylish appearance. It has a magnetic closure which works smoothly. The design is well-thought out, with the side gussets low on either side to allow for easy holstering and retrieval of your phone. The interior is lined with a soft, napped fabric to avoid scratches to the phone. The belt clip is sturdy, neatly attached and swivels smoothly.This case would be perfect except for one key feature that was left off - a magnetic, proximity sensor which automatically turns the back light off and locks the touch screen when holstering and back on when retrieving your phone! This is an extremely important feature to most Blackberry users as it conserves battery life and eliminates "butt dialing". I am confused at why Amazon took the time to design such a nice case, specifically cut for a Blackberry Curve, and failed to add this. Would have been 5 stars had it not been for this.

    2012-12-27: I am pleased with this produce. It was purchased for a teenager and we didn't want to extend our contract. This phone was just as described and I would order again from this seller.

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-06: Was VERY happy with it for the first 4 months of owning it, and couldn't imagine a better phone. I could do my emails, read texts, and play music at the same time. I could GO ON THE WEB and stay in a phone convo at the same time. Just was amazing and the phone didn't limit what I did.The first issue I encountered was the battery. It barely lasted 8 hours, and that's with background syncing and all that stuff backlight all that turned down. You'd be lucky to get 1 hour at best if all that was on. I got the extended battery, and when it helped, it somehow made my screen go nuts. No joke, put the old one in and the device screen works and never an issue. The extended battery, it scrolls, clicks n things, and the landscape mode didn't work. Motorola tech support recommended a full reset, so I had to set up everything once more.The next issue I had was the music player integration. I can BLUETOOTH myself MP3 songs that AUTOMATICALLY are stored to the 8GB factory included SD card (finally), but they do not have any sort of identification. It says the track name- but with the track number, they are only in numeric order for example 01-"Only Time" The album names for everything that is Bluetoothed over is Bluetooth. It doesn't drag over the album name, and the artist simply reads unknown. I tried the USB with the same result, so i guess it's not all the bluetooth.And while the ANDROID 2.1.1 Android operating system is a joy to use, you cannot save APPS to your SD card. This leads to small lagginess, such as Angry Birds, takes literally 2 minutes to fling the next bird. As far as I was told, processor speed has nothing do with this, and as this was a premium phone, I'd think it had a good processor in it.Overall:It wows, but it could be better. Do I recommend it, yes, somewhat, if it can have it's issues fixed. I guess if you don't mind the SD issue it'd be a perfect phone, but unfortunately I decided it was something I didn't want to use and upgraded.

    Rating: 3

    2012-03-28: The Good: Excellent design, lots of power, superb features from Google, amazing cameraThe Bad: App store is still young, processes running in the background kills battery life, keyboard is a bit cumbersomeGoogle as been known for revolutionizing the internet and now they are with their Android phones. The Motorola DROID (A855) is the newest and most advanced phone on the market right now, and this bad boy does an awful lot. A lot of people are going to compare this phone to the iPhone, but the DROID trumps the iPhone in features, and freedom. I will discuss, first, the tech specs and compare them to the iPhone head-to-head so you can see how powerful the DROID truly is.Techno BabbleThe DROID has a 550 MHz processor, and to be specific the Arm Cortex A8 processor that is also present in the iPhone 3GS by Samsung. The 3GS is clocked only 50 MHz higher and can be overclocked to 800 MHz. To compare that the original Xbox has a 733 MHz processor. So can the DROID be overclocked to this as well? Most likely. With a monster processor the DROID can multitask and has one of the first actual mobile OS (besides Windows Mobile 7). This also means maintaining processes running in the background to gain battery life, uninstalling apps (not just deleting them), and a lot more, but we'll get to that later. The iPhone however can not multitask due to the OS running on it, and the processor is only used in games.When it comes to graphics the DROID still hasn't been pushed to its limits. There are very few 3D games on the Android market, but as of right now the iPhone stomps the DROID in the graphics department. The DROID has a 200 MHZz PowerVR SGX 530 GPU. The iPhone has the same, but due to the slightly better CPU is can currently outperform the DROID. The iPhone has been on the market for quite some time, so there are bigger better games available. The DROID should start getting the same quality soon. They both have 256MB of RAM, so under the hood they are pretty much the same.The DROID has a slightly bigger screen sizing in at 3.7' and the iPhone at 3.5'. Does 2 millimeters matter? Yes it does. There is a good 2 millimeters on the top of the iPhone that could be screen, but for some unknown reason it's not. The DROID has a higher resolution of 854480 and 265 ppi (pixels per inch). The 3GS has a 320480 resolution with only 163 ppi so the DROID has double the resolution of the iPhone. That is great for people wanting to watch high-res movies on their device.Both devices have the same input such as the 3 axis accelerometer (tilt sensor), digital compass, Multi-touch display, proximity and ambient light sensors etc. The DROID is a bit heavier than the 3GS, but only by 1.2 oz. The DROID wipes the floor with the 3GS' camera. The DROID camera is 5MP compared to the 3GS 3MP. The DROID has dual LED flash, and geotagging and it can even run higher than 30 FPS. The 3GS has all this except the dual LED flash and this is a huge plus.When it comes to storage the DROID wins with its external memory option. You can insert up to a 32GB micro-SD card, but you're stuck with the 3GS' internal memory and have to pay a huge price for more. The DROID even comes with a 16GB micro- card when you buy the phone. So when it comes to comparing junk under the hood they both have the same hardware, but the DROID has the extra tidbits that push it over the edge.GUI: Graphical User InterfaceThe DROID has an excellent GUI and the whole marketplace is run by the community. There are programs such as PandaHome, OpenHome, GDEHome etc that allow you to change "themes" for a small price or for free. These also change icons, clock widgets etc. The DROID has a great interface that is more like a computer that gives you a desktop, then a slide up menu where all your apps are stored. You can drag and drop as you see fit. The iPhone, however, is plagued with the mundane Apple OS that only show apps in a grid format with a black background. Sure you can change your "wallpaper" but this is only when the phone comes out of sleep mode so it's rarely seen. This makes every iPhone look the same so the DROID wins in customization by a long shot. There are four touch buttons located at the bottom of the screen which are your back button, menu, home, and search. You will use these buttons a lot so Motorola and Google were smart to put these here.Apps: Who's Better?It all comes down to the apps. Who has more right? Well the iTunes marketplace has hundreds of thousands of apps that the DROID doesn't have so the iPhone wins there. However, the Android market is ever-growing, and thanks to the user run community a lot of great apps are showing up that the iPhone can't run. These include a lot of customization apps and loads more. Apps are easier to run on the DROID since there is no iTunes type program. The app store is run off the phone, downloaded from the phone as well. If you don't want an app anymore you go to your settings and uninstall it. Google also allows you to refund anything you buy within 24 hours and Apple does not support this. While iTunes may have more stuff, Android has better customer service and a better community and setup. There are really no "hardcore" games for the DROID like there is for the iPhone, but it's getting there. You do not want to get a DROID for a gaming system just yet for sure; stick with your iPod/phone.Features: Welcome to Google TownThe DROID has a lot of little things going on in it. You can do everything a touch screen phone can do, but it also has a slide out QWERTY keyboard. The buttons were a little flat and the top row is hard to get at if you have big fingers, but it works well. If you tilt the phone sideways you can type with a landscape keyboard or use Google text-to-speech. I found this feature extremely useful when typing long messages or writing reviews for apps. Since this is a Google phone you get all their awesome apps such as Google Earth (yes it's in 3D and you can see every detail), and Google maps. Switch to your "car app" and press navigation. Speak your selection (i.e. Phoenix, Arizona) and Google will give you directions for a car, bus, or walking (God forbid you walk that far!). Press get navigate and the phone will speak you the directions. It doesn't update in real-time, but it does update as you drive down each block.Google Sky is a fun app that lets you point your phone in the sky and it will show you, in real-time, where each constellation and planet is. You get plenty of excellent Google apps such as Gmail, YouTube (yeah Google owns YouTube), and Google Goggles which allows you to take pictures of products or objects and the phone will scan it and search it for you. There's even a Google search bar on the desktop with a text-to-speech button next to it. Brilliant. There are plenty of other apps such as the Amazon store, eBay, Bank of America, MLIA, FML, and even ShopSaavy. This app allows you to scan a barcode and it will tell you where you can find it cheaper online or locally. Of course you have all your social networking apps like Twitter, Facebook, and MySpace which run great.When it comes to things like ringtones, pictures, and videos, so the DROID delivers. You can store any MP3, or picture and set them as wallpapers, notifications, or just ringtones. Mount your SD card via USB and just create the folders. No having to sync with a program on the PC. Total freedom is what Google gives you and this is what I love.Problems: It's Not PerfectThere are some issues with the DROID, but not many and they are minor. The biggest one is the running processes in the background that can kill your battery even in sleep mode. You have to get the Advanced App Killer app and every so often check everything you don't want running and kill the apps. Another problem I ran into was that since most of the apps are user made they can be glitchy and screw up your phone so watch out and read reviews before downloading anything. You could say that the major issue is the app store. There is a lot of apps, but some of it is junk. There aren't any excellent games available, and the app store doesn't have any sort feature except Top Paid, Top Free, and Just In.For a $550 phone (if you pay for it without a plan) the DROID delivers and trumps the iPhone in every direction except the apps. The DROID is a very advanced phone, and is for people who love using their phones constantly and make it a part of their every day life. With a sleek design, excellent features, sturdy hardware, and monster processing power the DROID should be the #1 phone in 2010.Update: 10/15/2011Now after I have had this phone for 18 months I don't like it as much. The phone started having issues with serious lag, slowdown, and just hardly responds anymore. The touch screen lost sensitivity after about a year, plus the hardware is ancient compared to what is out now. Due to that all the apps are now optimized for higher end phones so the Droid is left in the dust.Overall the phone just doesn't really work anymore internally. It won't come out of sleep mode some times, won't answer calls, turns off randomly, and the internet is just impossible to surf due to the now weak processor. Hardware wise it has stood the test of time with many drops, slides, fumbles, and kicks. Not a single crack or anything, but thankfully this phone is now discontinued. If you have the original Droid you are probably finding the same problems even after a factory reset. The phone was great 22 months ago, but now I just absolutely hate this thing. If I were to amend my score I would give it a 4/10 now, but of course that's unfair and should be remembered for how great it was at the time of release. Did I also mention that the appraisal price for the phone is about $20 now-a-days?

    Rating: 2

    2013-10-23: I bought this to replace my current phone because it was damaged. I got this in really great condition. This phone was just way to slow for me, couldnt complete simple tasks. So i sent it back.

    Rating: 2

    2014-03-18: THANKS SO IT TOOK SO LONG FOR THE REVIEW, I THOUGHT I DID THIS ALREADY BUT I SO LOVED THIS PHONE BUT IT OVER WITH NOW, I HATED TO LOSE IT

    Rating: 5
