    Rating: 1

    2012-01-04: Paid under $7 shipped from Eforcity, and can highly recommend the vendor and what they are selling.Turned out to be a 1600 mah battery, not the typical 1200.Seems to give a couple more hours run time, so it seems to be doing the job.Guess my original 2009 battery probably wasn't in such bad shape after all.But, iPhone 3GS was new to me - so I did an unnecessary battery change.Well, I learned a lot. ;)After changing the screen the previous week, the battery-ectomy was a walk in the park.Probably took an hour, but a very relaxed hour.Plenty of videos on youtube to show you what to do.There are maybe 10 screws, and some tricky wiggling to get the old battery out.I did run into one problem, but thanks to all the video watching, I didn't panic.A little gold clip on the board, down near the microphone, got under the silver bezel and prevented removal of the PC Board.Gentle wiggling and prodding solved that, and the rest was uneventful.The battery fit fine.Extra power didn't seem to translate into extra size.Also, the tools supplied were all I used.A very good supplier, and an excellent product.

    Rating: 5

    2012-09-06: I started having "issues" with my 3GS going from full charge to empty - with no warning! It was sporadic so I lived with it but knew that something had to be done. A colleague mentioned he'd had the same problem, had bought this replacement battery kit and that it worked perfectly. So I went ahead and got it. Being cheap and of the generation that keeps electronic equipment longer than disposable kleenexes like the younger folks do I figured the old 3GS actually used as a phone....like, to talk to people? had more life in it.So anyway, the kit arrived very quickly and armed with the Youtube "how to" set out to replace the battery.I cannot stress and emphasize enough how important it is to either get Instructions though a Google Search, or watch the video clip on Youtube that explains how to do this (do a search on Apple iPhone 3GS battery replacement).It took a bit longer than I expected, but that's because the screws and parts are tiny to take the phone apart - and you have to be really careful with the connectors (little flat cables with tiny contact snaps!).Once you get to the old battery and "pry" it out of the case (the glue is pretty strong) then it's a matter of sticking the new battery in and reversing your steps and snapping/screwing (did I mention that the screws are VERY tiny?) the phone back together. It's a bit tricky to get the little camera pod to seat back into its slot and ensure that all the cables are back connected properly.The moment of truth: Hit the on button and everything worked as expected!Some have mentioned they didn't get the battery pictured. This was NOT my case and I now have a 1600 mAH which has actually allowed me to routinely go 2 days without a recharge - which NEVER happened with the OEM battery.Editorial note: I did read (I think) in Steve Job's (RIP) biography that he was so ticked off when he heard that people were actually opening up the iPhones to do this type of repair (and jailbreaking and glass replacement) that he made it even harder to do ANYTHING to repair the newer generation iPhones (4 and 4s). I don't know if it's as simple to do this on newer phones.I highly recommend this to those that don't throw away their phone every 6 months and enrich Apple or the Phone companies.I give it 4 stars because the plastic tool that comes with it is not very useful and the instructions useless.I've had it in for the last 6 months without a hitch!

    Rating: 4

    2014-02-12: As soon as I received the product I decided to immediately install it.After unscrewing the screen I realized that it's impossible to lift it without a suction cup. The kit does not come with a suction cup tool, which is essential for removing the display.I decided to drive to a local pharmacy to pickup a Kitchen Towel Hook with a suction cup. They didn't sell one. Most of the products they sold had a double-sided tape instead. I drove off to a supermarket - the same picture. I then went to a hardware store and again the same thing. Finally, on my 5th attempt I found a kit with 2 hooks with suction cups several miles away. Bought it for $4.95. It took me over 1.5 hours to find a suction cup. I was very frustrated - wasted so much gas, time and money that I had to spend to buy the suction cup.

    Rating: 3

    2013-03-02: I installed it following youtube video and it wasn't that hard. After installation, the phone would not charge. I reinstalled the old one and it works. this battery is a SCAM along with all those 5 star reviews!

    2013-12-22: I have been using this for about a month now and it's o.k. I feel that it runs down faster than the original OEM battery, but since I recharge it every night it doesn't matter. Also, the selling price for this battery is so cheap that I can't complain.Note: after I installed this in my Iphone after about 4 hours the charging halted at 80% and would not go up any more. I emailed eForCity and they replied within 2 hours and offered to send me a new battery. However, after 3 more hours the batter finally quickly charged up to 100% and is now operating normally (so, I declined their offer for a replacement). Based on their response, I think this is a good company to order from.

    2014-05-15: Great replacement for a dying IPhone 3GS battery. However I would not attempt this battery replacement if you don't have an IT repair background or experience.     2013-01-01: I thought I would give this a try since my old 3GS was replaced by a Galaxy Note. The inside components of the phone were not identical in the videos so check out a few to make sure your parts match. The battery fit well and seems to be lasting about the same amount of time as the original - we will see after a few weeks. THe suction cup did not hold tight enough to pull off the screen...... in the end I improvised and worked through it. Having done it now once I would just buy the battery next time and forgo the extra for the tools.....

Tip - Put a small piece of masking tape across one corner of your screen to make the protector easy to lift if you don't get it right the first time. Then when you're satisfied just pull the tape away from under the screen. Works great.

    2011-05-01: We've had this product for several months now and are glad we purchased it (through Amazon). The price was right and it works as advertised. Now that my wife and I have matching phones (HTC Evo's)it's so convenient to be able to plug in either or both phones while driving. The unit comes packaged with one cord so we just bring along an extra one so we can charge both phones at the same time.Usually, my wife seems to always forget to charge her phone at home so she's used it quite a bit more than I. When we're on long road trips we leave the phones plugged in so we can use them as we travel and when we get to our distination, our phones are (usually) fully charged for a day of sight-seeing.I use the GPS (Sprint service) feature on the phone, so my old Magellan GPS is now obsolete. Besides, the battery had gone out (dead) on the Magellan and it would have cost what I paid for one of the phones (with rebate), and I was just about to pay out nearly a hundred dollars to update the navigation system. Thank goodness we bought the new phones.By the way, the blue light on the plug (the part that goes into the car's cigarette lighter) is just right and bright enough to let us know the connection is working. The phones have battery-charging indicators also.Rate a 10 on a scale of 1-10. Great product and well made.

    2014-01-07: The charger charges slowly. It takes about an hour for me to gain much. I would not purchase this again.

    Rating: 1

    2014-03-07: As a data cable, it's flawless. As a charging cable? Not so much, provided you don't have a Samsung AC USB adapter. Samsung uses something specific in it's hardware that prevents their cables from charging the tablets when used in anything but a branded AC unit, PC USB or a compatible pigtail cable. These can be purchased separately, but it's rather obnoxious to require a measure like that, especially when it's a proprietary cable.If you already have the AC unit and just need to replace a cable that a pet, child, drunk friend chewed on, then this'll work a treat for you. If however you don't have any charging accessories, keep in mind you'll likely need some additional hardware if you want to charge out of anything other than your PC.
